We operate leading digital used vehicle marketplaces (both business to business (“B2B”) and consumer to business (“C2B”)) in the UK and B2B marketplaces in continental Europe and are a leading provider of associated automotive services, including vehicle movement, logistics, storage, pre-delivery inspections, fleet management, de-fleeting services and refurbishment in the UK. We have physical presence in 10 countries across the UK and continental Europe as well as unmatched sourcing, data, technology and logistics capabilities. As of March 28, 2021, our business comprises: - a leading B2B digital used vehicle marketplace across the UK and continental Europe, which facilitated the sale of approximately 1.5 million vehicles in the fiscal year 2020 and 1.2 million vehicles in the fiscal year 2021; - a leading C2B digital used vehicle marketplace in the UK, WeBuyAnyCar, with sold volumes of 321,000 vehicles and 300,000 vehicles in the fiscal years 2020 and 2021, respectively, reflecting the COVID 19 restrictions on the business that now has an annualized run rate of 461,000 vehicles (based on trading in March, April and May 2021, which was the most recent three-month period); and - a leading automotive logistics service business in the UK, which moved more than 2.8 million vehicles in the UK in the fiscal year 2020 and 2.4 million vehicles in the fiscal year 2021, and stored, refurbished and processed more than 950,000 vehicles in the fiscal year 2020 and 675,000 in the fiscal year 2021. We estimate that for the fiscal year 2020 we came in contact with approximately one in every three vehicles in the UK (approximately 29 million touch points, of which approximately 13 million were unique vehicles out of a vehicle parc of approximately 41 million, and including approximately 24 million digital touch points). Through our digital used vehicle marketplaces (the “Marketplace”), we are a critical liquidity provider to the used vehicles market across the UK and continental Europe, matching the complex requirements of both vendors and buyers and also facilitating the purchase of individual vehicles from consumers. The Marketplace facilitates speedy disposal of high volumes of vehicles and offers a broad range of consistently graded vehicle stock, thereby providing efficiency, liquidity (i.e., fast disposal of vehicle stock) and choice. Moreover, we are the UK’s leading provider of automotive services solutions. By providing a full suite of auction and automotive services, we offer our customers solutions for almost all stages of the vehicle life-cycle, beginning as soon as the new car arrives at the port. Our scope of services provides synergistic benefits across our divisions, as our vehicle sales platforms, together with our automotive services solutions, generate vehicle and pricing data used in both our vehicle remarketing and vehicle buying operations. Throughout the COVID 19 pandemic, we have accelerated our digital transition and now transact digitally almost 100% of our volumes through online channels. We integrate our digital and physical assets to provide innovative multi-service solutions, maximizing speed, intelligence and performance across our comprehensive offerings. In the fiscal year 2021, 100% (2020: 37%) of our auction volumes in the UK Vehicle Remarketing division and 96% (2020: 84%) of our auction volumes in the International Vehicle Remarketing division were transacted online, which is a testament to our successful shift towards a predominantly digital online business model moving forward. In the 53-week period ended May 30, 2021, we generated £253.1 million of IAS 17 COVID Adjusted EBITDA, as compared to £232.8 million, £204.1 million and £174.4 million in the 52-week period ended March 28, 2021, the aggregated 52-week period ended March 29, 2020 and the 52-week period ended March 31, 2019, respectively. We operate through three main business lines: (i) the B2B Marketplace business line, which is comprised of our UK Vehicle Remarketing division, our International Vehicle Remarketing division and our Vehicle Buying division’s operations in continental Europe, (ii) the C2B Marketplace business line, which is WeBuyAnyCar, our Vehicle Buying division’s operations in the UK, and (iii) the Automotive Services business line, which is accounted for in our Automotive Services division. ----- - B2B Marketplace: B2B Marketplace is our core business that facilitates the exchange of used vehicles between vendors and buyers through primarily digital auctions. As of March 28, 2021, our digital auctions are supported by 21 physical sites in the UK (23 as of June 1, 2021) and 30 physical sites in continental Europe at which vehicles are stored, inspected, repaired and refurbished. B2B Marketplace (which excludes WeBuyAnyCar) does not take title to the majority of vehicles that it sells, but instead serves as an agent between vendor and buyer and recognizes revenues through auction transaction fees as well as fees for a suite of value-added digital and physical pre- and post- auction services such as inspections, appraisals, repairs, refurbishment, imaging, storage and handling. We also purchase vehicles directly from certain corporate vendors under outsourced remarketing contracts, whereby we directly buy our vendors’ inventory and have discretion over the remarketing channel through which we sell the vehicle. B2B Marketplace takes title to such vehicles until the time of resale and recognizes revenues for the full sale value of the vehicle less the cost of acquisition. Vehicles acquired pursuant to outsourced remarketing contracts are typically resold within 15 to 30 days of acquisition and in turn generate additional revenue above the auction fees. B2B Marketplace also includes our Vehicle Buying division’s operations in continental Europe, which is focused on purchasing batches of vehicles primarily from corporates in continental Europe. In the 52-week period ended March 28, 2021, our UK Vehicle Remarketing division generated £90.5 million of IAS 17 Adjusted EBITDA (aggregated 52-week period ended March 29, 2020: £116.3 million; 52-week period ended March 31, 2019: £109.4 million). In the fiscal year 2021, our UK Vehicle Remarketing division sold approximately 867,000 vehicles (2020: 1,063,000 vehicles; 2019: 1,030,0000 vehicles). In the 52-week period ended March 28, 2021, our International Vehicle Remarketing division generated £29.2 million of IAS 17 Adjusted EBITDA (aggregated 52-week period ended March 29, 2020: £34.2 million; 52-week period ended March 31, 2019: £33.7 million). In the fiscal year 2021, our International Vehicle Remarketing division sold approximately 334,000 vehicles (2020: 401,000 vehicles; 2019: 388,000 vehicles). - C2B Marketplace: C2B Marketplace is our C2B vehicle buying business which operates in the UK through WeBuyAnyCar. WeBuyAnyCar purchases used vehicles directly from consumers, leveraging its proprietary online pricing quotation systems and efficient physical inspection processes to facilitate purchases from such consumers. WeBuyAnyCar has carried out a total of 2.2 million vehicle purchases since its inception in 2006, and in the fiscal year ended March 28, 2021, WeBuyAnyCar recorded more than 22 million unique visitors to its website and performed approximately 15.6 million valuations online. As of March 28, 2021, WeBuyAnyCar operates in 357 locations across the UK, which are located within an average drive time of under 14 minutes to customers. In addition, WeBuyAnyCar offers swift services to its consumers, allowing them to obtain a quote in under 60 seconds and to then subsequently receive monies for the purchase of their vehicle within 30 minutes of the sale being concluded. C2B Marketplace remarkets the vehicles it purchases exclusively through B2B Marketplace within approximately 10 days and accounted for 35% of the vehicles sold in the UK Vehicle Remarketing division in the 52-week period ended March 28, 2021. This allows us to actively manage the volumes and mix on the Marketplace, while helping to de-risk the supply of vehicles to the auction. C2B Marketplace’s consistent and growing profitability over the past years demonstrates our ability to generate “metal margin” (accounted for in our Vehicle Buying division) on C2B vehicles in addition to core auction buyer fees (accounted for in our UK Vehicle Remarketing division). Vehicles sourced via our C2B Marketplace therefore result in higher profitability per vehicle for the CA Group. Our sophisticated and proprietary pricing mechanism and real-time market data enable us to more accurately price the purchase of vehicles to generate a profitable onward sale. In the 52-week period ended March 28, 2021, the Vehicle Buying division generated £44.0 million of IAS 17 Adjusted EBITDA (aggregated 52-week period ended March 29, 2020: £27.7 million; 52-week period ended March 31, 2019: £24.1 million), which was predominantly generated through C2B Marketplace (i.e., WeBuyAnyCar). - Automotive Services: Automotive Services provides vehicle movement, logistics, storage, pre-delivery inspections, fleet management, de-fleeting services and refurbishment in the UK. With our refurbishment offering (which has a 250,000 yearly vehicle refurbishment capacity), we are able to bring vehicles to either wholesale standard or a “Retail Ready” standard (which refers to vehicles that are cosmetically and mechanically prepared to be immediately placed for sale to end consumers and are therefore particularly attractive to online car dealers). These standards increase prices achieved at auction and render it simpler for dealers to on-sell the vehicle to consumers. We seek to develop a relationship with vendors and endeavor to act as a one-stop shop for vehicles throughout the majority of their lifecycle, expanding our revenue ----- streams along the value chain and also positioning ourselves to be the preferred provider of remarketing services when the vehicles come off lease or roll out of the fleet. Our overall infrastructure and logistics network allow us to efficiently cover all key locations and major transport hubs in the UK. Automotive Services helps maximize the benefit of operational leverage and intragroup efficiencies derived from the wide-ranging scope of services offered, benefitting both our customers as well as our own operations. Automotive Services generates revenue in the form of service fees. In the 52-week period ended March 28, 2021, Automotive Services generated £12.5 million of IAS 17 Adjusted EBITDA (aggregated 52-week period ended March 29, 2020: £22.6 million; 52-week period ended March 31, 2019: £19.1 million).

We are a leading operator of digital used vehicle auctions in the UK and continental Europe and associated automotive services across the UK. From continental Europe, we serve over 40 countries, leveraging our ability to engage in cross-border activity across continental Europe. We believe our leading market positioning and scale enable us to better serve used car buyers and sellers compared to many of our competitors as we are able to price, source, inspect, refurbish, transport, service, market, arrange auctions and provide digital and physical services and solutions in an efficient, comprehensive and effective way. We believe our B2B Marketplace is the largest used vehicle auction operator across the UK and continental Europe combined, with approximately £10 billion in gross merchandise value in connection with sales for the fiscal year 2020. We believe that B2B Marketplace is the clear leader in the UK, having sold approximately 1.1 million vehicles in the UK in the aggregated 52-week period ended March 29, 2020, as well as approximately 400,000 vehicles sold in continental Europe in the same period. These attributes mean that we can continuously meet the requirements of both professional vendors and buyers, including improved value, liquidity, efficiency and choice, and are a key part of the reason that more than 25,000 active buyers used the exchange in the fiscal year 2021. Through our UK Vehicle Remarketing division, our Automotive Services offering in the UK and our brand WeBuyAnyCar, we come into contact with approximately one third of all vehicles exchanged in the UK each year. We believe that C2B Marketplace, through our brand WeBuyAnyCar, is the leading vehicle buying service in the UK, purchasing and selling over 321,000 vehicles in the fiscal year 2020. On an annualized basis based on trading in March, April and May 2021, which was the most recent three-month period, we purchased and sold approximately 461,000 vehicles through WeBuyAnyCar. With greater than 22 million unique visitors to its website in the fiscal year ended March 28, 2021 and having performed approximately 15.6 million valuations online and purchasing vehicles at 357 physical sites, each as of and for the 52-week period ended March 28, 2021, we believe that C2B Marketplace is significantly larger and has a significantly greater presence than any other vehicle buying service in the UK. C2B Marketplace’s leadership position is continuing to strengthen with an increase in the number of repeat customers in recent years, demonstrating consumers’ trust in the brand and satisfaction around the value attached to the vehicle disposal process. As of the date of this Offering Memorandum, WeBuyAnyCar has over 100,000 Trust Pilot reviews with an average 4.6 rating. In Automotive Services, we operate one of the largest automotive vehicle movement, logistics, storage, predelivery inspections, fleet management, de-fleeting services and refurbishment capability in the UK. As of March 28, 2021, we own the largest transporter fleet in the UK, comprising 901 trucks capable of providing bulk vehicle movements, thereby connecting the physical marketplace and increasing the integration between our divisions. We also offer the full range of single vehicle movement services to support customers through the process of vehicle delivery, handover and collection. In the fiscal year 2021, we moved 2.4 million vehicles (2020: 2.8 million), including 563,000 single vehicle movements, and our in-house and sub-contracted transporter fleet completed 94% of transport arranged for customers by the UK Vehicle Remarketing division. We offer the full range of single vehicle movement services to support customers through the process of vehicle delivery, handover and collection. We also operate one of the UK’s largest inspect and collect businesses with over 400,000 vehicle inspections made in the fiscal year 2021, are one of the UK’s leading new vehicle storage handling and preparation businesses and are among the UK’s leading de-fleet, refurbishment and alloy wheel businesses with more than 675,000 vehicles stored, refurbished and processed in the fiscal year 2021. -----

Subsubsection Title: Superior Business Model Addressing the Full Value Chain and Difficult to Replicate
Subsubsection Text: We operate under a marketplace model and benefit from self-reinforcing dynamics where each of our business lines feeds into and reinforces the others. Our business model enables us to extract intragroup efficiencies and synergies derived from operating across almost all stages of the vehicle life-cycle, at high volumes sufficient to provide a level of information, liquidity and market recognition that drives further volume growth. Our B2B Marketplace operates vehicle auctions that bring together vendors with a highly fragmented and diverse buyer base. Our large, robust and transparent digital platforms combined with our full suite of preand post-auction digital and physical value-added services provide an efficient marketplace to facilitate the exchange of used vehicles. B2B Marketplace sold approximately 1.5 million vehicles across the UK and continental Europe in the fiscal year 2020. This significant scale creates a virtuous business cycle by providing access to a wide variety and large volume of vehicles through our auctions, thereby attracting more buyers to our platform and enabling optimum pricing and quick throughput, which in turn attracts more sellers and provides more volumes. Moreover, we obtain valuable insights for our pricing engines based on the information we have available about a vehicle and its condition, color, auction sale price and bid levels. The B2B Marketplace benefits from multiple sourcing channels targeting different types of vendors. The C2B Marketplace creates a highly complementary and enhancing growth engine to that of the B2B Marketplace. The B2B Marketplace provides WeBuyAnyCar with a highly efficient route to dispose of the vehicles it purchases from consumers (typically within 10 days) and, through WeBuyAnyCar, we have the ability to purchase a greater volume and variety of vehicles, which directly helps supply the B2B Marketplace. The Vehicle Buying division provides significant volumes to the UK Vehicle Remarketing division, having accounted for 35% of the vehicles sold through the Marketplace in the UK in the fiscal year 2021. This synergistic model, which leverages WeBuyAnyCar’s market share within the framework of our wider marketplace, creates a platform which we believe would be difficult to replicate. Our ability to dynamically source used vehicles combined with our knowledge and insights on pricing and other demand side dynamics enable us to find an optimum and tailored match for buyers and sellers swiftly, which is key in driving profitability per vehicle. This is further strengthened by the additional services we offer, which increase consumer and vendor experience as well as help us generate greater profitability per vehicle. Our scaled B2B Marketplace and C2B Marketplace provides our pricing model with over six million relevant historic used vehicle transactions. This data enables us to accurately and efficiently price vehicles both upon sourcing and sale. This scale is further supported by our Automotive Services business line and our full suite of pre- and post-auction digital and physical value-added services. This completes the value chain allowing us to cover the full life-cycle, deepen relationships with vendors and customers and maximize profitability per vehicle. Moreover, our Automotive Services business line and our value-added services enable us to record information relating to vehicle condition, maintenance and upkeep, further contributing to the pricing model and further supporting the reliability of pricing decisions. With the launch of B2C Marketplace, outside the restricted group, we have further diversified our buyer and vendor base as cinch acts as another buyer through our auction channel, thereby generating auction fees for our UK Vehicle Remarketing division, as well as additional income for our Automotive Services division. Furthermore, cinch also generates additional supply for the B2B Marketplace via part-exchange vehicles that are remarketed by us and allow us to generate additional auction fees. See “Certain Relationships and Related _Party Transactions—Agreements with cinch.”_ ----- As the scale of each of the business lines has grown and has reached greater volumes and touch points, it has contributed to the further growth of each of the business lines in a virtuous cycle. We believe we are the only operator of digital used vehicle auctions in the UK and continental Europe that offers the scale and the range of services we provide. Our advantages in scale, reputation, relationships, access to proprietary data as well as our established infrastructure and logistics network, which we believe would be difficult for a competitor to replicate.

Subsubsection Title: Resilient Financial Profile and Strong Cash Flow Generation
Subsubsection Text: We believe that our scale, unique business model, reputation and robust financial policies have contributed significantly to our long-term financial resilience, attractive growth and cash flow generation profile. Despite turbulent times such as the global financial crisis of 2008, we were able to consistently maintain and grow volumes and our EBITDA metric (as defined and prepared on the basis of the accounting policies of the relevant parent entity at the time), with such metric having grown at a CAGR of 14.3% from the fiscal year ended December 2004 to fiscal year ended March 2020 and such metric divided by vehicle volumes sold in the respective trading year having grown from £37 per vehicle sold to £137 per vehicle sold over the same period, as shown in the following chart. Our business model’s resilience to market shocks can be further evidenced by our strong organic performance. For example, during the period between 2008 and 2010, we were able to grow volumes by 66,000 vehicles and the applicable EBITDA metric by £24 million in a market backdrop of reduced used car transactions in the UK, which fell from 8.3 million in 2008 to 8.0 million in 2009 before recovering to 8.1 million in 2010. Despite a market backdrop of reduced used vehicle transactions during the fiscal year 2021, our volumes between July 2020 and December 2020 were higher compared to the period between July 2019 and December 2019. In times of a consumer downturn and due to rate of loss in value generally associated with used vehicles, liquidity is of paramount importance to businesses as well as consumers. Our business is also highly cash generative, having generated £145.9 million, £175.1 million and £202.7 million of COVID Adjusted Operating Cash Flow in the 52-week period March 31, 2019, the aggregated 52-week period ended March 29, 2020 and the 52-week period ended March 28, 2021, respectively. This strong cash generation is the result of our ability to grow our IAS 17 COVID Adjusted EBITDA while following a disciplined approach to capital expenditure with the majority of sites being held on long term leases (excluding WeBuyAnyCar retail locations) and most of our transporters and properties being refinanced through sale and leaseback. Adjusted cash conversion (measured by subtracting Underlying Cash CAPEX from IAS 17 COVID Adjusted EBITDA and comparing the result to IAS 17 COVID Adjusted EBITDA) was 84%, 86% and 87% in the 52-week period March 31, 2019, the aggregated 52-week period ended March 29, 2020 and the 52-week period ended March 28, 2021, respectively.

We operate in the used vehicle market across the UK and continental Europe which has grown consistently since 2012, driven by a relatively stable vehicle parc churn and growing vehicle penetration rates. Vehicle ----- penetration rates are expected to continue to grow for most markets. In addition, the used car market is larger and more stable than the new car market. The chart below sets out the volumes of used car sales and new car sales in the UK between 2008 and 2020 as an example of the development of these market. The European vehicle parc has exhibited a CAGR of approximately 1.7% over 2012 to 2019, currently standing at approximately 320 million units as of 2020. As per projections from IHS, the European vehicle parc is expected to exhibit approximately 0.8% CAGR over 2021 to 2026, driven by growth in the penetration of vehicles per population. Assuming churn rates remain the same, this should support growth in the used car market. See “Industry—Overview—UK and Continental European Vehicle Parc.” In 2020, the European used car market was estimated to be worth €410 billion (Source: Roland Berger report _(Apr-21)). Significant fragmentation of buyers and vendors across the UK and continental Europe helps to_ make exchanges a critical channel for both vendors and buyers. For example, the largest used car dealership in the UK is limited to approximately 3% market share, while the largest continental European used car dealership has a market share of less than 1% (Source: IHS and ICDP). In addition, online vehicle buying services are still operating typically at low levels of overall market penetration (e.g., WeBuyAnyCar has ~4% share of total UK used vehicle sales volumes, as of 2020). The COVID 19 pandemic has also accelerated favorable structural trends affecting the markets in which we operate. In particular, consumers have recently begun placing increased emphasis on the importance of owning a car. This has been driven by a variety of different reasons, including people moving away from urban areas due to the ability to work from home and a reluctance to rely entirely on public transport. In addition, the lockdown measures imposed by governments and related closure of car dealerships has made digital channels a principal means of conducting used car auctions. In particular, by the start of 2021 almost all of our auctions were digital as the COVID 19 pandemic and related social distancing regulations accelerated our digitalization plans and encouraged the adoption of digital auctions by our customers. This digital shift allows us to reach a wider range of potential customers and has increased the amount of auctions being held, reducing our daily sales’ costs and allowing us and our customers to receive more vehicle data. Finally, we also benefit from increasing sales of used vehicles as government support and a push towards new technology, including tighter emission controls, encourages vehicle owners to renew their vehicles, driving more exchanges.

Subsubsection Title: Best-in-class Management Team with Successful Track Record of Delivery
Subsubsection Text: We operate with a management team that has significant experience in the automotive sector and has a proven track-record of executing value-accretive initiatives, whether organically or through acquisitions. Our Executive Chairman, Avril Palmer-Baunack, has over 25 years’ executive experience with leading businesses in the automotive, support services, industrial engineering and insurance services sectors, having previously served as Executive Chairman and Deputy CEO of Stobart Group and CEO of Autologic Holdings, where she joined from Universal Salvage and also held the position of CEO. Avril was the founder of Haversham Holdings plc in 2014 and led the acquisition and strategic build of the CA Group where she continues to lead as Executive Chairman. Tim Lampert, our Chief Financial Officer, joined Autologic Holdings in 1997. Tim joined Haversham Holdings plc in January 2015 for the purchase of the BCA Group from CD&R and the subsequent acquisitions prior to the group being de-listed and sold to TDR in November 2019 and has remained as CFO with the formation of the current CA Group. Together, our best-in-class management team brings over 30 years of relationships with major participants across every layer of the UK and continental European automotive sector both at the division and group levels, and more than 100 years of collective experience in the industry across four managing directors as well as legacy knowledge from some of our founders, who are still employed within our Vehicle Buying division. Thanks to its extensive experience, our management team has a proven track record of delivery, with applicable EBITDA growing from £86.0 million in the fiscal year 2014 to £200.8 million in the fiscal year 2020 ----- (as presented under “—Resilient Financial Profile and Strong Cash Flow Generation”) through, among others, the acquisition of multiple infrastructure and logistics businesses. During the same period, B2B Vehicle Volume increased from 999,000 to 1,463,000. Since the fiscal year 2014, C2B Vehicle Volume also increased from 144,000 to 321,000 vehicles and 300,000 vehicles in the fiscal years 2020 and 2021, respectively, with an annualized run rate of 461,000 vehicles (based on trading in March, April and May 2021, which was the most recent three-month period), reflecting the COVID 19 restrictions on the business. The track record of our senior management in delivering cost-effective organic scale growth and successfully integrating acquisitions, is one of our key strengths in a complex and continually evolving industry. In addition, our management is backed by TDR Capital, a leading private equity firm with an integrated investment and operation team of 46 professionals with an average of 15 years of relevant experience and a deep knowledge and track-record in the automotive industry via investments in LeasePlan, CarNext, EuroGarages and International Car Washing Group. The TDR Capital team, together with management, intends to continue our trajectory of consistent volume and profitability growth. We have also created a strong culture of innovation and transparency, winning a number of industry awards for technical innovation, including for BCA Dealer Pro and our website. We believe this has allowed us to maintain a high retention rate of key staff and develop a workforce that is dedicated to delivering high-quality services.

We believe our business platform is strategically positioned for growth in our markets through market share gain from the consumer to consumer (“C2C”) and part-exchange markets (whereby consumers “trade-in” their used vehicle directly to a dealer). The growth of C2B Marketplace supports the growth of our B2B channel as WeBuyAnyCar provides us with used vehicles that would otherwise go to C2C markets or partexchanges and allows us to supply a greater volume and variety of vehicles to our B2B Marketplace. We believe we can drive higher volumes through our auctions through continued market share gain and higher auction penetration in the UK and continental Europe. Our relationships with businesses such as LeasePlan or CarNext, including entering into exclusive service agreements that provide support for our multi-channel strategy, further enhance our sourcing capabilities and drive growth in the vehicle remarketing segment. See “Certain Relationships and Related Party Transactions—Relationship with LeasePlan.”Moreover, by leveraging our “One Europe” strategy via more seamless cross-border transactions, we believe we can create a truly pan-European B2B marketplace for future growth. In addition, COVID 19 restrictions have accelerated consumers’ willingness to adopt digital purchasing as a means to buy a car from current low levels, favoring the growth of online B2C retailers, such as cinch. Our relationship with cinch has increased supply for the B2B Marketplace via part-exchange vehicles that are remarketed by us and allow us to generate additional auction fees. See “Certain Relationships and Related _Party Transactions—Agreements with cinch.” Through cinch, we are also able to develop a B2C channel,_ which enhances our position as an end-to-end service provider. In particular, sales volumes for the B2C channel increased from approximately 4,000 in October 2020 (based on a 7-day rolling annual run-rate) to approximately 38,000 in May 2021.
We believe that, by virtue of the key strengths described below, we are well-positioned to benefit from structurally favorable trends in the used vehicle market.

Subsubsection Title: Enhance our competitive advantage across the value chain as an integrated end-to-end service provider
Subsubsection Text: We plan to drive growth by increasing our B2B Marketplace and C2B Marketplace penetration to increase transaction volumes and scale across our geographies. The increase in scale will serve to provide even deeper access to vehicles, as well as more pricing and vehicle information, and is expected to continue to solidify our position as a leading operator of digital used vehicle auctions across the UK and the continental European countries in which we operate. We also expect to continue leveraging upon and investing in our UK and continental European network and infrastructure. ----- To further increase our scale, we intend to deepen our relationships with other participants in the used vehicle ecosystem, including OEMs, leasing companies, finance companies and dealers, to improve access to used vehicle supply and generate volumes. We plan to provide dealers with additional offerings that suit their business models, to leverage the strength of WeBuyAnyCar’s brand to capture additional supply volumes as consumers become increasingly willing to sell their vehicles through digital channels, and expand our reach to serve customers through partnerships with other B2C platforms. In order to maintain our competitive advantage across the value chain, we will leverage the close relationship between our C2B Marketplace and B2B Marketplace and work on integrating further the insights and data points we are able to collect at different stages, further supplemented by our data sharing agreement with cinch. See “Certain Relationships and Related Party Transactions—Agreements with cinch.” Multiplying our data touchpoints for vehicles entering our ecosystem will enable us to base our decisions on more precise and efficient processes and pricing input. We intend to continue to develop both our digital and physical service offerings to retain and grow the customer base and deliver enhanced profitability. By increasing the penetration of value-added services over time, we expect a compounding effect of fueling Marketplace growth by driving supply and buyer demand, as the comprehensive end-to-end solutions significantly enhance user loyalty. We also intend to further deepen the penetration of services provided by Automotive Services to continue to improve relationships with vendors, both to provide additional vehicle information to benefit our other divisions and to become the preferred choice for vehicle remarketing.

Subsubsection Title: Further deliver on our international expansion strategy
Subsubsection Text: We believe we are well positioned in Europe to become a truly pan-European leader in the used vehicle auction market. Our “One Europe” strategy is focused on leveraging and optimizing our already existing capabilities to provide more seamless cross-border transactions not only in countries where we have physical presence but across the European continent. In continental Europe, which we believe is underpenetrated relative to more developed markets such as the UK, we intend to grow our B2B Marketplace offering as well as our coordinated logistics network and infrastructure to capture further market share and develop scale.

Subsubsection Title: Strengthening our infrastructure and logistics network
Subsubsection Text: As we look to increase our scale and continue to capture more volumes via our platforms, we will continue to invest and strengthen our infrastructure and logistics capabilities in order to serve customers across the value chain, while remaining asset light through the continued use of sale and leaseback transactions. We also intend to develop and modernize our transport vehicles used for vehicle movement. Our aim is to remain a major component of the UK used vehicle market backbone and extend this know-how to our other geographies.

Subsubsection Title: Capitalize on favorable structural industry trends to accelerate our growth
Subsubsection Text: Online penetration for sales of used vehicles has grown significantly, particularly in the UK, in recent years and the associated structural trends further accelerated during the COVID 19 pandemic. During the COVID 19 pandemic, there has been a significant increase in online penetration for sales of used vehicles, as physical venues were shut for lockdown periods and social distancing restrictions and health concerns otherwise caused many consumers to avoid physical venues. Despite the recent acceleration in online penetration growth, we believe the online used car market remains underpenetrated relative to other mass retail markets such as markets for toys and games, consumer electronics and apparel. Further enhancing our digital presence will also allow us to capitalize on additional structural trends that could drive more volumes through our Marketplace and strengthen our positioning and market share on both the supply and demand sides of the ecosystem. In particular, we believe that on the demand side consumers will continue to favor used vehicles for individual transportation to avoid public transportation systems, and that more vehicles will be necessary as consumers move away from city centers to areas where public transportation is inconvenient or unavailable. On the demand side, we look to attract wider audiences via our digital auctions with no limitations linked to historical physical sites. Finally, we will seek to benefit from increasing sales of used vehicles as government support and a push towards new technology, including towards electric and other alternative fuel sources for vehicles, encourages vehicle owners to review their vehicles, driving more exchanges. -----

Subsubsection Title: Continue to enhance our data capabilities
Subsubsection Text: Our business model is built on leveraging data and technology and we intend to continue to invest in our IT infrastructure and data capabilities to scale up along with volume growth. We use data and technology throughout our business, from providing instant price quotes and targeted marketing campaigns to valuation tools, logistics and inventory management to optimization of refurbishment costs. Through our end-to-end positioning we have access to one of the largest pools of real-time data. As such, we are invested in ensuring that our IT infrastructure remains state-of-the-art to secure better knowledge of our customers and their needs, which in turn is expected to enable us to develop better products and more tailored service as well as more accurate pricing which is expected to help underpin our profitability.

Subsubsection Title: Increase our operational efficiencies and drive strong cash flow and deleveraging
Subsubsection Text: As we look to increase volumes flowing through our Marketplace, we believe we will have an opportunity to improve our profitability per vehicle. Driving continued penetration of automotive services will help maximize the benefit of operational leverage and intragroup efficiencies. Enhancing our data capabilities will allow us to optimize pricing, leading to better unit economics, while we also look to ensure an optimal management of our inventories to ensure a strong cash flow conversion at all times. To support our strong cash generation, we will maintain our disciplined approach to cost management, which proved to be effective in helping us navigate through the COVID 19 pandemic and its associated challenges, maintaining an optimal capital structure and strong deleveraging profile while continuing in investing to grow the business.

We seek to create value for stakeholders through organic growth, acquisitions and partnerships in the automotive sector in the UK and continental Europe. We continue to work with major market participants to develop and adapt integrated solutions to solve and meet the needs of the participants across the automotive sector, maximizing value for all stakeholders. To achieve this goal, we are focused on enhancing our competitive advantage as an integrated end-to-end service provider, further expanding internationally, strengthening our infrastructure and logistics network, capitalizing on favorable industry trends, continuing to enhance our data capabilities and improving our operational efficiencies, cash flow and leverage.

Based on our preliminary financial results for the 53-week period ended May 30, 2021, we generated £253.1 million of IAS 17 COVID Adjusted EBITDA, as compared to £232.8 million, £204.1 million and £174.4 million in the 52-week period ended March 28, 2021, the aggregated 52-week period ended March 29, 2020 and the 52-week period ended March 31, 2019, respectively. ----- _These preliminary financial results are based solely on internal management accounts and our estimates, which were prepared by us and are based on assumptions that are subject to inherent uncertainties. These preliminary financial results have not been audited, reviewed or verified and you should not place undue reliance thereon, accordingly, PwC do not express an opinion or any other form of assurance with respect thereto. The auditor reports included in this Offering Memorandum relate to the Parent’s and BCA Marketplace’s previously issued financial statements. It does not extend to the preliminary financial results and should not be read to do so. Our current fiscal quarter, which includes the nine-week period ended May 30, 2021, closed on July 4, 2021. However, we have not completed our quarterly closing procedures, during the course of which we could identify items that could require us to make adjustments or consider other developments which may arise between now and the time we finalize our financial results for the 14-week period ended July 4, 2021. Accordingly, these preliminary financial results may change and those changes may be material. Moreover, our preliminary financial results represent monthly data, which may not be illustrative of quarterly performance, particularly in light of uncertainties relating to the ongoing COVID 19 pandemic. We therefore caution you that these preliminary financial results should not be regarded as an indication, forecast or representation by us or any other person regarding our financial performance for the nine-week period ended May 30, 2021 or any future period. See “Forward-looking Statements,” “Risk Factors” and “Operating and Financial Review” for a discussion of certain of the factors that could affect our performance and results of operations._

On April 22, 2021, we made a tactical acquisition of a third-party site in Corby, United Kingdom, for £12.0 million. On May 12, 2021, we completed the sale of another site in Corby, United Kingdom, for £23.4 million, having retained a lease with respect to such site and after previously purchasing the site for £19.7 million. On May 20, 2021, we acquired Rockingham (RT) Limited, Rockingham (GW) Limited and Rockingham (CP) Limited for a combined consideration of £80.0 million (the “Rockingham Acquisition”). Through the Rockingham Acquisition, we expect to be able to increase our specialist automotive reconditioning and logistics capabilities.

Due to the unprecedented level of disruption to society and the automotive industry, including to car dealers, leasing companies, fleet providers, original equipment manufacturers (“OEMs”), wholesale traders and private consumers, as well as our employees and the way we operate our business, interactions at the Marketplace were significantly reduced during the first quarter of the fiscal year 2021 with average weekly trading volume dipping to 4,000 at the start of the quarter, compared to 29,000 at the start of the fourth quarter of the fiscal year 2020. The changes in operating environment spurred by the COVID 19 pandemic have led us to accelerate our shift towards a fully digital online business model with increased focus on the functionality and usability of our digital platforms, as a result of which we were able to earn new contracts and increase our market share in spite of the challenging market conditions. The scale of the transformation is demonstrated by the fiscal year 2021 ending with 100% of UK auction sales having occurred online, compared to 37% in the fiscal year 2020. In addition to the enforced cessation of physical auctions in the UK, we faced restrictions such as site closures impacting the operation of the WeBuyAnyCar retail estate and recorded a reduction in the movement and inspection of vehicles within Automotive Services. Our customers evolved their business models, for example by motor dealers operating a click-and-collect process during 2020 to be able to better deal with social distancing restrictions and, by August 2020, average weekly trading volumes bounced back up to 31,000. With the continuing progress on vaccinations across European countries, and the UK in particular, as well as governments lifting restrictions to public life, we expect the demand for our services to be increasing. The shift towards a more digital operation model has, to an extent, mitigated the impact of COVID 19 and the lifting of COVID 19 restrictions is expected to increase demand in the long term as dealers look to restock their inventory. _Impact on Operations_ We have been and actively continue to monitor the impact of the COVID 19 pandemic on our operations, and our priority has been the safety of our employees and other stakeholders. As governments in the jurisdictions where we operate introduced restrictions at the outset of the COVID 19 pandemic, we quickly ceased physical auctions and introduced social distancing and other modifications to our ways of working to remain compliant. In response to the closure of our physical auction sites, we adopted swift measures to significantly ----- reduce cash outflows by reducing our operating cost and implementing cash control measures, with the aim of maximizing our liquidity position. Specifically, we adopted the following measures, which were only necessary during the time of the first lockdown in the UK during March 2020 to July 2020 and were not implemented during the subsequent second and third lockdowns: - successfully negotiated with debtors and creditors on payment terms; - put on hold all non-essential and discretionary spend within the business, including any growth, expansionary or investment capital expenditures and increased controls around the cash disbursement process, including sign off by senior members of the finance team for any payments in excess of certain reduced thresholds; - negotiated tax deferrals with HM Revenue & Customs (“HMRC”) in respect of value-added taxes (“VAT”) and employment taxes; and - entered into arrangements with landlords to defer rent payments during the period of closure. We also made furlough arrangements for those staff unable to work in the UK where we furloughed as much as 80% of our staff at the peak of the COVID 19 pandemic in April 2020 and, in parallel, applied for employee salary support schemes introduced by certain governments in continental Europe. Such schemes allow companies to place employees on paid leave or on reduced working hours, with the difference to an employee’s ordinary salary being partially reimbursed by the respective government. As of March 28, 2021, approximately 4% of our employees remained on short-term work. In the 52-week period ended March 28, 2021 furlough income across all jurisdictions totaled £35.5 million and rates relief totaled £8.3 million. As of March 28, 2021, remaining deferrals comprise VAT deferrals of £15.8 million, which are expected to be settled in full in instalments during the fiscal year 2022. As a result of the numerous cost-cutting and transitory measures taken at the beginning of the first lockdown in the UK, we came out of that lockdown with greater liquidity compared to our liquidity going into such lockdown. From the end of the first lockdown in the UK, we have managed to remain positive in terms of IAS 17 Adjusted EBITDA even in periods with government restrictions comparable with the first lockdown in the UK. Given the success of our digital offering with our clients and the level of profitability and efficiency achieved, we currently have no intention of reverting back to our previous predominantly physical auction model. _Impact on Results of Operations and Liquidity Update_ For the unaudited aggregated 52-week period ended March 29, 2020, IAS 17 Adjusted EBITDA and IAS 17 COVID Adjusted EBITDA were £190.1 million and £204.1 million, respectively, reflecting an estimated COVID 19 impact of £14.0 million in the fiscal year 2020. For the 52-week period ended March 28, 2021, IAS 17 Adjusted EBITDA and IAS 17 COVID Adjusted EBITDA were £168.0 million and £232.8 million, respectively, reflecting an estimated COVID 19 impact of £64.8 million in the fiscal year 2021. For the 52-week period ended March 31, 2019, we reported an operating profit of £100.2 million. For the unaudited aggregated 52-week period ended March 29, 2020, we reported an operating loss of £224.5 million. For the 52-week period ended March 28, 2021, we reported an operating profit of £47.4 million. We had cash and cash equivalents of £113.2 million and £247.2 million as of March 28, 2021 and March 29, 2020, respectively. We seek to maintain sufficient amounts of liquidity with an appropriate balance of cash, debt and equity to provide financial flexibility. On April 29, 2020, we entered into the Existing Liquidity Facility Agreement, providing us with increased liquidity and capacity for future investment and vehicle buying. As of March 28, 2021, £110.7 million (2020: £2.3 million) was available for borrowing under the Existing Revolving Credit Facility, in each case after giving effect to outstanding letters of credit. _Impairment Review_ As of March 28, 2021, the intangible assets on our balance sheet totaled £1,937.9 million, including £938.5 million in goodwill relating to the CA Acquisition. While goodwill impairment is tested annually, the COVID 19 pandemic and its impact on our business constituted an impairment indicator that we assessed with respect to all intangible assets as well as goodwill. The impairment review is performed on a “value-inuse” basis, which requires estimation of future net operating cash flows, the time period over which they will occur, an appropriate discount rate and an appropriate growth rate. Any impairment charge is then recognized in the income statement for any amount by which the carrying value of goodwill exceeds its recoverable amount. As a result of our impairment review conducted as a result of the COVID 19 pandemic, we recognized an exceptional goodwill impairment relating to the CA Acquisition in the amount of £266.4 million in the 42-week period ended March 29, 2020. The impairment charge thereby specifically represented a change ----- in the timing of vehicle volumes and associated discounted cash flows, which were expected through the Marketplace over the short term as economic activity recovers. See “Risk Factors—Risks Relating to Our _Business—The COVID 19 pandemic has had, and will continue to have, a significant adverse effect on our business, operations, financial condition, operating results and liquidity, and the ultimate outcome of the COVID 19 pandemic is uncertain” and “Operating and Financial Review—Factors Affecting Our Results of Operations—COVID 19—Impairment Review.” We caution you that these impairment charges should not be_ regarded as an indication, forecast or representation by us or any other person regarding impairment charges for any future period. See “Forward-looking Statements.”

Constellation Automotive Group Limited (the “Parent”) was incorporated as a private limited company under the laws of England and Wales on June 10, 2019 in contemplation of the CA Acquisition. The Parent was known as BBD Parentco Limited before it was renamed Constellation Automotive Group Limited on October 26, 2020. The registered office of the Parent is Headway House, Crosby Way, Farnham, GU9 7XG, United Kingdom. Constellation Automotive Limited (“Constellation Automotive”) was incorporated as a private limited company under the laws of England and Wales on June 10, 2019 in contemplation of the CA Acquisition. Constellation Automotive was known as BBD Bidco Limited before it was renamed Constellation Automotive Limited on October 23, 2020. Constellation Automotive is a wholly owned subsidiary of the Parent. The board of directors of Constellation Automotive is our main board. The registered office of Constellation Automotive is Headway House, Crosby Way, Farnham, GU9 7XG, United Kingdom. Constellation Automotive Financing plc (the “Issuer”) was incorporated as a public limited company under the laws of England and Wales on June 29, 2021 in contemplation of the Refinancing Transactions. The Issuer is a wholly owned subsidiary of the Parent. The registered office of the Parent is Headway House, Crosby Way, Farnham, GU9 7XG, United Kingdom.

TDR Capital is a leading private equity firm which managed funds of over €10 billion of committed capital as of the end of 2020. It was founded in 2002 by Manjit Dale and Stephen Robertson, who were previously partners at DB Capital Partners. TDR Capital has an experienced team of investment professionals and operating partners and has a low-volume investment strategy based on principles developed by the investment team over the past two decades. TDR Capital seeks to spend significant resources on each investment and to focus on operational excellence through a tested and integrated operating partner model. Intense pre-investment analysis and post-investment involvement mean that TDR Capital is selective, typically making only one to three investments a year. TDR Capital takes an active role in overseeing the operations of its investments, working in partnership with management through board representation and professional support. -----

_The following diagram summarizes our corporate structure and principal outstanding financing arrangements after giving effect to the Refinancing Transactions. For a summary of the material financing arrangements identified in this diagram, see “Capitalization,” “Description of the Notes” and “Description of Other Financial Arrangements.” The diagram is intended for illustrative purposes only and does not include all legal entities. All entities shown below are 100% directly or indirectly wholly-owned, unless otherwise mentioned._ (1) Funds managed by TDR Capital control the Parent and its consolidated subsidiaries. Other shareholders include various investment funds managed by NB Alternatives Advisers LLC, members of senior management and other leading global institutional investors. Funds managed by TDR Capital have, directly or indirectly, beneficial ownership of 73.81% of the Parent’s stock. See “Principal _Shareholders.”_ (2) Constellation Automotive Group S.à r.l. was incorporated as a private limited company (société à responsabilité limitée) under the laws of the Grand Duchy of Luxembourg and is the direct holding company of the Parent. (3) The Parent was incorporated as a private limited company under the laws of England and Wales on June 10, 2019 in contemplation of the CA Acquisition. The Parent was known as BBD Parentco Limited before it was renamed Constellation Automotive Group Limited on October 26, 2020. As of the Issue Date, the Parent will be an Initial Guarantor. (4) The Issuer is a wholly owned subsidiary of the Parent and was incorporated as a public limited company under the laws of England and Wales on June 29, 2021 to facilitate the offering of the Notes. The Issuer has no business operations or material assets and, following the Offering, will have no business operations or material assets, other than its rights under the Proceeds Loan Agreement. (5) Constellation Automotive Limited (“Constellation Automotive”) is a wholly owned subsidiary of the Parent and was incorporated as a private limited company under the laws of England and Wales on June 10, 2019 in contemplation of the CA Acquisition. Constellation Automotive was known as BBD Bidco Limited before it was renamed Constellation Automotive Limited on October 23, 2020. The board of directors of Constellation Automotive is our main board. As of the Issue Date, Constellation Automotive will be an Initial Guarantor. (6) The Issuer is offering £650,000,000 in aggregate principal amount of its % senior secured notes due 2027. On the Issue Date, the Notes will be senior secured obligations of the Issuer. The Notes will be guaranteed on a senior secured basis (i) on the Issue Date, by the Initial Guarantors and (ii) within two business days from the Issue Date, by the Additional Guarantors. The Guarantee of each Guarantor will rank equal in right of payment with such Guarantor’s existing or future obligations that are not ----- subordinated in right of payment to its Guarantee. For the 52-week period ended March 28, 2021, the Issuer and the Guarantors represented 68% of IAS 17 Adjusted EBITDA. The Guarantors will also guarantee, subject to the Agreed Security Principles, borrowings under the Senior Term Loan Facility, the Revolving Credit Facility and the Second Lien Facility. See “Description of _the Notes—Guarantees.” Any company that is, or becomes, a guarantor in respect of the Senior Term Loan Facility, the Revolving_ Credit Facility or the Second Lien Facility will also be required, subject to the Agreed Security Principles, to become a guarantor in respect of the Notes. On the Issue Date, subject to the release of security in respect of the Existing Senior Term Loan Facilities, the Existing Revolving Credit Facility, the Existing Second Lien Facility and the Existing Liquidity Facility (collectively, the “Existing _Facilities”), the Notes will be secured on a first-priority basis by the Initial Collateral, and within two business days from the Issue_ Date, the Notes will be secured on a first-priority basis by the Post-Closing Collateral (together with the Initial Collateral, the “Collateral”). The Collateral will also secure borrowings under the Senior Term Loan Facility, the Revolving Credit Facility, the Second Lien Facility and certain hedging obligations, if any. (7) On or about the Issue Date, the Parent, Constellation Automotive and certain other Guarantors propose to enter into the Senior Facilities Agreement, providing for the Senior Term Loan Facility and the Revolving Credit Facility. The Senior Term Loan Facility is in an amount of £785,000,000 (equivalent) and will mature on the date falling 84 months after Issue Date. The Revolving Credit Facility is in an amount of £250,000,000 and will mature on the date falling 66 months after Issue Date. We do not expect to borrow cash under the Revolving Credit Facility on the Issue Date but expect to utilize ancillary facilities and letters of credit under the Revolving Credit Facility for ordinary course operations. Subject to the Agreed Security Principles, borrowings under the Senior Term Loan Facility and the Revolving Credit Facility will be guaranteed by the Guarantors and secured on a first-priority basis by security interests over the Collateral. See “Use of Proceeds,” “Capitalization” and “Description of Other Financial _Arrangements—Senior Facilities Agreement.”_ (8) On or about the Issue Date, the Parent, Constellation Automotive and certain other Guarantors propose to enter into the Second Lien Facility Agreement, providing for the Second Lien Facility. The Second Lien Facility is in an amount of £325,000,000 and will mature on the date falling 96 months after Issue Date. Subject to the Agreed Security Principles, borrowings under the Second Lien Facility will be guaranteed by the Guarantors and secured on a first-priority basis by security interests over the Collateral but will only receive proceeds from the enforcement of the Collateral following the recovery by the holders of the Notes, Senior Term Loan Facility and the Revolving Credit Facility in full. See “Use of Proceeds,” “Capitalization” and “Description of Other Financial _Arrangements—Second Lien Facility Agreement.”_ (9) BCA Central Limited (“BCA Central”) is a wholly owned subsidiary of Constellation Automotive and was incorporated as a private limited company under the laws of England and Wales. As of the Issue Date, BCA Central will be an Initial Guarantor and a borrower under the Senior Facilities Agreement. (10) On the Issue Date, each of Constellation Developments Limited, BBD Rock Limited, Rockingham (RT) Limited and Rockingham (GW) Limited will be an Unrestricted Subsidiary (as defined under “Description of the Notes”) under the Indenture, the Senior Facilities Agreement and the Second Lien Facility Agreement. (11) During the fiscal year 2020, we incurred certain start-up costs with respect to cinch, an online classified business, which was sold to an affiliate of a parent company of the Parent in September 2020. See “Certain Relationships and Related Party Transactions— _Agreements with cinch.”_ -----

You should carefully read this Offering Memorandum in its entirety, including the Consolidated Financial Statements, before making an investment decision. See “Risk Factors” for certain factors that you should consider before investing in the Notes._

_The summary below describes the principal terms of the Notes, the Guarantees and the Collateral. It is not intended to be complete and certain of the terms and conditions described below are subject to important exceptions. You should carefully review the section of this Offering Memorandum entitled “Description of the Notes” for more detailed descriptions of the terms and conditions of the Notes._ Issuer . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .** Constellation Automotive Financing plc Notes Offered . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .** £650,000,000 aggregate principal amount of % senior secured notes due 2027. Issue Date . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .**, 2021 Maturity Date** . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . ., 2027 Interest Rate . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .** % Interest Payment Dates . . . . . . . . . . .** Interest will accrue from the Issue Date and will be payable in cash semi-annually in arrear on each and, commencing on, 2021. Issue Price . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .** % plus accrued interest, if any, from the Issue Date. Denomination . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .** The Notes will have a minimum denomination of £100,000 and any integral multiples of £1,000 in excess thereof. Notes in denominations of less than £100,000 will not be available. Notes . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .** The Notes will be: - senior secured obligations of the Issuer and will rank equal in right of payment with all of the Issuer’s existing or future obligations that are not subordinated in right of payment to the Notes, including the Issuer’s obligations under the Senior Facilities, the Second Lien Facility and certain hedging obligations, if any; - secured by the Collateral as set forth below under “—Collateral,” along with borrowings under the Senior Facilities, the Second Lien Facility and certain hedging obligations, if any; - senior in right of payment to any future indebtedness of the Issuer that is expressly subordinated in right of payment to the Notes and any Guarantee; - effectively senior in right of payment to any existing or future unsecured obligations of the Issuer to the extent of the value of the Collateral that is available to satisfy the obligations under the Notes; - effectively subordinated in right of payment to any existing or future indebtedness of the Issuer that is secured by property or assets that do not secure the Notes, to the extent of the value of the property or assets securing such indebtedness; and - unconditionally guaranteed on a senior secured basis on the Issue Date, by the Initial Guarantors and within two business days from the Issue Date, by the Additional Guarantors. Guarantors . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .** The Notes will be guaranteed on a senior secured basis (i) on the Issue Date, by the Initial Guarantors and (ii) within two business ----- days from the Issue Date, by the Additional Guarantors. See “Description of the Notes—Guarantees.” For the 52-week period ended March 28, 2021, the Issuer and the Guarantors represented 68% of IAS 17 Adjusted EBITDA. Guarantees . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .** The Guarantees will be full and unconditional guarantees of the Issuer’s obligations under the Notes, but will be subject to contractual and legal limitations, and may be released without the consent of the holders of the Notes under certain circumstances. See “Description of the Notes—Guarantees” and “Certain Insolvency and Local Law Limitations.” The Guarantees will be: - senior secured obligations of each Guarantor and will rank equal in right of payment with such Guarantor’s existing or future obligations that are not subordinated in right of payment to its Guarantee; - secured on a first-priority basis by the Collateral as set forth below under “—Collateral,” along with borrowings under the Senior Term Loan Facility, the Revolving Credit Facility and certain hedging obligations, if any; - senior in right of payment to any of such Guarantor’s existing and future indebtedness that is subordinated in right of payment to its Guarantee, including the Second Lien Facility; - effectively senior in right of payment to any existing or future unsecured obligations of such Guarantor to the extent of the value of the Collateral that is available to satisfy the obligations under its Guarantee; and - effectively subordinated in right of payment to any existing or future indebtedness of such Guarantor that is secured by property or assets that do not secure its Guarantee, to the extent of the value of the property or assets securing such indebtedness. The Guarantees will be subject to contractual and legal limitations, including the Agreed Security Principles, and may be released under certain circumstances. See “Description of the _Notes—Guarantees” and “Risk Factors—Risks Related to Our Financial Profile, Our Structure, the Notes and the Guarantees.”_ Collateral . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .** On the Issue Date, subject to the release of security in respect of the Existing Facilities, the Intercreditor Agreement, the operation of the Agreed Security Principles, certain perfection requirements, any Permitted Collateral Liens and certain material limitations pursuant to applicable laws, the Notes will be secured on a first-priority basis by an English law governed debenture granted by the Initial Guarantors, including securing the Parent’s shares in the capital of Constellation Automotive (the “Initial Collateral”). Within two business days from the Issue Date and subject to the Intercreditor Agreement, the operation of the Agreed Security Principles, certain perfection requirements, any Permitted Collateral Liens and certain material limitations pursuant to applicable laws, the Notes will be secured on a first-priority basis by: ----- - an English law governed debenture granted by the Issuer, the Parent, Constellation Automotive, BCA Central, BCA Marketplace Limited, BCA Osprey I Limited, BCA Osprey II Limited, BCA Remarketing Group Limited, Pennine Metals B Limited, We Buy Any Car Limited, BCA Trading Limited and British Car Auctions Limited; - a Jersey law governed security interest agreement granted by BCA Marketplace Limited in respect of the shares of H.I.J. Limited; - a Jersey law governed security interest agreement granted by H.I.J. Limited in respect of material bank accounts and material intercompany receivables; and - an English law governed share pledge granted by H.I.J. Limited in respect of the shares of BCA Osprey I Limited, (the “Post-Closing Collateral” and together with the Initial Collateral, the “Collateral”). Notwithstanding the foregoing, certain assets may not be secured or such security may not be perfected in accordance with the Agreed Security Principles. The Collateral will also secure borrowings under the Senior Term Loan Facility, the Revolving Credit Facility and certain hedging obligations, if any, and the Second Lien Facility but the Second Lien Facility will only receive proceeds from the enforcement of the Collateral following the recovery by the holders of the Notes, Senior Term Loan Facility and the Revolving Credit Facility in full. Any proceeds received upon any enforcement action over any Collateral will be applied, first, pro rata in repayment of all obligations under the Indenture, the Notes, the Senior Facilities Agreement and any other indebtedness of the Issuer and the Guarantors permitted to be Incurred and secured by the Collateral pursuant to the Indenture and the Intercreditor Agreement on an equal basis with the Notes and certain hedging obligations, if any and, second, in repayment of all obligations under the Second Lien Facility Agreement and any other indebtedness of the Issuer and the Guarantors permitted to be Incurred and secured by the Collateral pursuant to the Indenture and the Intercreditor Agreement on an equal basis with the Second Lien Facility Agreement. See “Description of the _Notes—Security—The Collateral,” “Description of Other Financial Arrangements—Intercreditor Agreement” and “Certain Insolvency and Local Law Limitations.”_ The security interests over the Collateral may be released under certain circumstances. See “Risk Factors—Risks Related to Our _Financial Profile, Our Structure, the Notes and the Guarantees”_ and “Description of the Notes—Security—Release of Liens.” Optional Redemption . . . . . . . . . . . . .** Prior to, 2023, the Issuer will be entitled, at its option, to redeem all or a portion of the Notes at a redemption price equal to 100% of the principal amount of the Notes redeemed, plus accrued and unpaid interest and Additional Amounts, if any, to, but excluding, the date of redemption, plus the ----- applicable “make whole” premium as set forth in this Offering Memorandum. Prior to, 2023, the Issuer will be entitled, at its option, to redeem up to 40% of the aggregate principal amount of the Notes with the net proceeds of one or more specified equity offerings at a redemption price equal to %, plus accrued and unpaid interest and Additional Amounts, if any, to, but excluding, the date of redemption, provided that at least 50% of the aggregate principal amount (including any additional Notes) remains outstanding after the redemption (unless all Notes are redeemed substantially concurrently). Prior to, 2023, the Issuer may also redeem during each calendar year commencing with the Issue Date up to 10% of the aggregate principal amount of the Notes outstanding, at its option, from time to time, at a redemption price equal to 103% of the principal amount of the Notes redeemed, plus accrued and unpaid interest and Additional Amounts, if any. See “Description of the Notes—Optional Redemption.” On or after, 2023, the Issuer will be entitled, at its option, to redeem all or a portion of the Notes at the redemption prices set forth under the section of this Offering Memorandum entitled “Description of the Notes—Optional _Redemption,” plus accrued and unpaid interest and Additional_ Amounts, if any. Redemption for Taxation Reasons . . . .** In the event of certain developments affecting taxation, the Issuer may also redeem all, but not part, of the Notes at a price equal to 100% of the principal amount plus accrued and unpaid interest and Additional Amounts, if any. See “Description of the _Notes—Redemption for Taxation Reasons.”_ Additional Amounts . . . . . . . . . . . . . .** Any payments made by the Issuer, the Successor Company (as defined “Description of the Notes”) or any Guarantor with respect to the Notes will be made without withholding or deduction for or on account of taxes unless required by law. If the Issuer, the Successor Company or the Guarantors are required by law to withhold or deduct amounts for or on account of tax imposed by the UK (or certain other relevant taxing jurisdictions) with respect to a payment to the holders of the Notes, the Issuer, the Successor Company or the relevant Guarantor will, subject to certain exceptions, pay the additional amounts necessary so that the net amount received by the holders of the Notes after the withholding or deduction is not less than the amount that they would have received in the absence of the withholding or deduction. See “Description of the _Notes—Additional Amounts.”_ Further Issuance of Notes . . . . . . . . . .** Pursuant to the terms of the Indenture, the Issuer will be permitted to issue additional Notes. Additional Notes shall be treated, along with all other notes issued under the Indenture, as a single class for the purposes of the Indenture with respect to waivers, amendments and all other matters which are not specifically distinguished for such series. For all purposes other than U.S. federal income tax purposes, additional Notes shall be deemed to form one series with any notes previously issued under the Indenture if they have terms substantially identical in all material respects to such other notes. In the event that any ----- additional Notes issued after the date hereof and sold pursuant to Rule 144A are not fungible with any notes previously issued under the Indenture for U.S. federal income tax purposes, such non-fungible additional Notes shall be issued with a separate ISIN, Common Code, CUSIP or other securities identification number, as applicable, so that they are distinguishable from such previously issued notes under the Indenture. Additional Notes sold pursuant to Regulation S from time to time may be issued with the same ISIN, Common Code, CUSIP or other securities identification number as the applicable series of notes previously issued under the Indenture without being fungible with such series of notes for U.S. federal income tax purposes. If you are a U.S. holder (as defined under “Tax Considerations—Certain U.S. _Federal Income Tax Consequences”) considering the purchase of_ Notes sold pursuant to Regulation S as part of this offering of Notes or in the secondary market, you should consult your tax advisors concerning the particular U.S. federal income tax consequences to you of the purchase, ownership and disposition of such Notes, including with respect to the potential issuance of additional Notes that are not fungible with the applicable series of initial Notes issued under the Indenture for U.S. federal income tax purposes, but which nevertheless are not capable of being separately identified. In the event additional Notes are issued pursuant to Regulation S that bear the same ISIN, Common Code, CUSIP or other securities identification number as Notes belonging to the same series previously issued, without being fungible with such series of initial Notes for U.S. federal income tax purposes, Book-Entry Interests (as defined under “Book-Entry, Delivery and Form”) in the Regulation S Global Notes (as defined under “Book-Entry, Delivery and Form”) that form part of that series, including in respect of investors that hold Book-Entry Interests in the Regulation S Global Notes on or prior to the date of issuance of such additional Notes, will not be eligible for transfer to Book-Entry Interests in a Rule 144A Global Note (as defined under “Book-Entry, Delivery _and Form”), if any, representing Notes of that same series. Such_ a restriction could adversely impact the liquidity of sales of Book-Entry Interests in the Regulation S Global Notes. See “Risk Factors—Risks Related to Our Financial Profile, Our _Structure, the Notes and the Guarantees—Additional Notes sold pursuant to Regulation S may not be fungible with existing Notes for U.S. federal income tax purposes,” “Book-Entry, Delivery and Form—Transfers” and “Description of the Notes—Additional Notes.”_ Change of Control . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .** Upon the occurrence of certain change of control events, the Issuer may be required to offer to redeem the Notes at 101% of the principal amount redeemed, plus accrued and unpaid interest and Additional Amounts, if any. A change of control, will not be deemed to have occurred on one occasion if a specified consolidated total net leverage ratio is not exceeded in connection with such event. See “Description of the Notes— _Change of Control.”_ Certain Covenants . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .** The Indenture relating to the Notes, among others, restricts the ability of the Parent and its restricted subsidiaries to: - incur or guarantee additional indebtedness; - pay dividends or make other distributions or purchase or ----- redeem our stock; - make investments or other restricted payments; - enter into agreements that restrict our restricted subsidiaries’ ability to pay dividends; - transfer or sell assets; - engage in transactions with affiliates; - create liens on assets to secure indebtedness; - impair security interests; - merge or consolidate with or into another company; and - amend certain documents. Each of these covenants is subject to significant exceptions and qualifications. See “Description of the Notes—Certain _Covenants.”_ Transfer Restrictions . . . . . . . . . . . . .** We have not registered the Notes or the Guarantees under the Securities Act. We have not agreed to, or otherwise undertaken, to register the Notes under the Securities Act. You may only offer or sell the Notes in transactions that are exempt from, or not subject to, the registration requirements of the Securities Act, or pursuant to an effective registration statement. See “Transfer Restrictions.” No Prior Market . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .** The Notes will be new securities for which there is currently no established trading market. Although certain of the Initial Purchasers have advised us that they intend to make a market in the Notes, they are not obligated to do so and they may discontinue market-making at any time without notice. Accordingly, there is no assurance that an active trading market will develop for the Notes. Listing . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .** Application will be made to the Authority for the listing of and permission to deal in the Notes on the Official List of the Exchange. There can be no assurance that the Notes will be listed on the Official List of the Exchange, that such permission to deal in the Notes will be granted or that such listing will be maintained. Use of Proceeds** . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . We expect to use the gross proceeds from the Offering, together with the proceeds from other Refinancing Transactions described herein, to (i) repay in full the outstanding borrowings under the Existing Facilities, (ii) make a distribution to the direct parent company of the Parent and (iii) pay costs, fees and expenses (including prepayment costs) incurred in connection with the Refinancing Transactions. See “Use of Proceeds.” Governing Law . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .** The Indenture, the Notes and the Guarantees will be governed by the laws of the State of New York. The Senior Facilities Agreement, the Second Lien Facility Agreement and the Intercreditor Agreement will be governed by English law. The Security Documents will be governed by English law or the laws of Jersey, as applicable. Security Agent . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .** HSBC Corporate Trustee Company (UK) Limited ----- Trustee** . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . GLAS Trust Company LLC
