For the unaudited aggregated 52-week period ended March 29, 2020, this includes amortization of acquired intangible assets (£53.5 million), transaction costs relating to the CA Acquisition (£60.0 million), restructuring costs (£2.3 million), debt fees written off on refinancing (£0.4 million) and impairment of acquired intangibles relating to the longer term impacts of the COVID 19 pandemic (£266.4 million). For the 52-week period ended March 31, 2019, this includes amortization of acquired intangible assets (£40.2 million), restructuring costs (£2.9 million), credit arising on a compulsory purchase order (£2.3 million), aborted transaction costs (£0.3 million) and pension costs in connection with a guaranteed minimum pension equalization adjustment (£2.2 million). (b) IFRS 16 (Leases) became effective on January 1, 2019 and we have adopted IFRS 16 on April 1, 2019 under the modified retrospective approach with the cumulative effect of applying IFRS 16 recognized on adoption as an adjustment to opening equity. Under this approach, comparative information for the 52-week period ended March 31, 2019 is not restated and, as a result, no IFRS 16 adjustments have been made to the Fiscal Year 2019 Consolidated Financial Statements. For all other periods presented in the table above, we have made IFRS 16 adjustments representing the removal of IAS 17 operating lease costs previously reported within cost of sales and operating costs. For the 52-week period ended March 28, 2021, the adjustments relating to COVID 19 are calculated by replacing the results of operations for the first quarter of the fiscal year 2021 (£2.0 million) and the fourth quarter of the fiscal year 2021 (£43.9 million) with the results of operations for the first quarter of the fiscal year 2020 (£44.5 million) and the fourth quarter of the fiscal year 2020 (£66.2 million), respectively, thereby presenting the results of operations during a more normalized period of trading. For the unaudited aggregated 52-week period ended March 29, 2020, the adjustments relating to COVID 19 are calculated by adding back an amount of £11.3 million (based on management forecasts using operating results for March 2020 immediately prior to lockdowns, reflecting restrictions on operating activities due to COVID 19) and an amount of £2.7 million (representing provisions relating to bad debt and inventory). For the 52-week period ended March 31, 2019, no adjustments relating to COVID 19 were made. Subsubsection Text: (a) Applies the current incremental run rate C2B Profitability Per Vehicle for the period from February 22, 2021 to May 30, 2021 ----- of £61 per vehicle to the WeBuyAnyCar COVID Adjusted Vehicle Volume for the fiscal year ended March 29, 2020 (326,000 vehicles). For the purposes of this calculation, we define “incremental” as the annualized amount of C2B Profitability Per Vehicle for the period from February 22, 2021 to May 30, 2021 in excess of the WeBuyAnyCar COVID Adjusted Profitability Per Vehicle for the fiscal year ended March 29, 2020. (b) Applies the current incremental run rate C2B Vehicle Volume for the period from February 22, 2021 to May 30, 2021 of 135,000 vehicles to the current run rate C2B Profitability Per Vehicle for the period from February 22, 2021 to May 30, 2021 (£159 per vehicle). For the purposes of this calculation, we define “incremental” as the vehicle volume in excess of the WeBuyAnyCar COVID Adjusted Vehicle Volume for the fiscal year ended March 29, 2020. (c) Applies the current incremental run rate B2B Profitability Per Vehicle for the period from February 22, 2021 to May 30, 2021 of £30 per vehicle to the B2B Vehicle Volume for the fiscal year ended March 29, 2020 (1.5 million vehicles). For the purposes of this calculation, we define “incremental” as the amount in excess of the B2B Adjusted Profitability Per Vehicle for the fiscal year ended March 29, 2020. (d) Applies the current incremental run rate B2B Vehicle Volume for the period from February 22, 2021 to May 30, 2021 of 59,000 vehicles to the current run rate B2B Adjusted Profitability Per Vehicle for the period from February 22, 2021 to May 30, 2021 (£136 per vehicle). For the purposes of this calculation, we define “incremental” as the amount in excess of the B2B Vehicle Volume for the fiscal year ended March 29, 2020. (e) Represents the decrease in IAS 17 Adjusted EBITDA for our Automotive Services division for the current run rate period from February 22, 2021 to May 30, 2021 compared to the 42-week period ended March 29, 2020. (f) Represents an adjustment for certain relief in respect of rates made available to the CA Group as a result of the COVID 19 pandemic, which were non-recurring in prior periods and are not expected to be offered on an ordinary course basis going forward. (16) We define Profitability Per Vehicle as IAS 17 Adjusted EBITDA per vehicle in the UK Vehicle Remarketing division, the International Vehicle Remarketing division and the Vehicle Buying division, as applicable. (17) We define Adjusted Cash as cash and cash equivalents, as adjusted to give effect to the Refinancing Transactions, including £55 million of estimated costs, fees and expenses (including prepayment costs) associated with the Offering, and assuming the Notes are issued at par. (18) We define Adjusted Total Senior Secured Debt as bank borrowings (excluding finance leases and borrowings under the Receivables Facility), as adjusted to give effect to the Refinancing Transactions. (19) We define Adjusted Net Senior Secured Debt as Adjusted Total Senior Secured Debt less Adjusted Cash. (20) We define Adjusted Total Debt as bank borrowings (excluding our finance leases), as adjusted to give effect to the Refinancing Transactions. (21) We define Adjusted Net Debt as Adjusted Total Debt minus Adjusted Cash. (22) We define Adjusted Cash Interest Expense as interest expense of the third-party financial indebtedness of the CA Group following the Refinancing Transactions, including borrowings under Senior Term Loan Facility and the Second Lien Facility, the issuance of the Notes offered hereby and the use of proceeds therefrom, as if the Refinancing Transactions occurred on March 30, 2020, and excluding (i) any interest expense with respect to other indebtedness of the Group which has since been extinguished, (ii) interest expense with respect to the Receivables Facility since borrowings under the Receivables Facility do not constitute indebtedness under the Indenture, (iii) interest expense with respect to our finance leases and (iv) commitment fees with respect to the Revolving Credit Facility since these are treated as interest expense for accounting purposes. -----

The auditor reports included in this Offering Memorandum relate to the previously issued financial statements of the Parent and BCA Marketplace. It does not extend to non-IFRS measures and should not be taken to do so In addition, we have included certain unaudited adjusted data, which gives effect to the Refinancing Transactions, as if it had occurred on March 30, 2020. Such summary unaudited adjusted consolidated financial information has been prepared for illustrative purposes only and does not purport to represent what the actual consolidated financial position or financial information of the CA Group would have been had the Refinancing Transactions actually occurred on March 30, 2020, nor does such summary unaudited adjusted consolidated financial information purport to project the CA Group’s consolidated financial position and financial information at any future date or for any future period. The unaudited adjusted data presented below includes non-IFRS measures and is based on available information and certain assumptions and estimates that we believe are reasonable and may differ materially from the actual amounts. The results of operations for prior fiscal years may not be necessarily indicative of the results to be expected for any future period. This summary historical financial and other information should be read in conjunction with the Consolidated Financial Statements and the 2020 Predecessor Financial Statements included elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum and discussed in “Presentation of Financial and Other Information,” “Selected Historical Consolidated Financial Information” and “Operating and Financial Review.” We have not included financial information prepared in accordance with U.S. GAAP in this Offering Memorandum. IFRS differs in certain significant respects from U.S. GAAP. In making an investment decision, you should rely upon your own examination of the terms of the Offering and the financial information contained in this Offering Memorandum. You should consult your own professional advisors for an understanding of the differences between IFRS and U.S. GAAP, and how those differences could affect the financial information contained in this Offering Memorandum._

Subsubsection Title: The COVID 19 pandemic has had, and will continue to have, a significant adverse effect on our business, operations, financial condition, operating results and liquidity, and the ultimate outcome of the COVID 19 pandemic is uncertain.
Subsubsection Text: In December 2019, an outbreak of the novel strain of coronavirus SARS-CoV-2 (“COVID 19”) was identified in Wuhan, China. This COVID 19 outbreak has since spread and grown globally, including in each of the countries in which we operate, and was declared a global pandemic by the World Health Organization in March 2020. Although the ultimate severity and impact of the COVID 19 pandemic remains uncertain, the COVID 19 pandemic and measures taken to combat it have had, and are expected to continue to have, a significant negative impact on the economy in the countries in which we operate and the automotive industry as a whole. The measures taken to combat COVID 19 include restrictions on public life, curfews, forced temporary business closures (including the closure of significant elements of our business) and lockdowns as well as social distancing protocols and the general advice to stay at home given the health risks associated with COVID 19. As a result, all aspects of our business have been, and we expect will continue to be, materially negatively impacted. In the used vehicle market, car registration agencies and car dealerships were temporarily closed, car dealers sought to reduce their inventory and some consumers chose to delay or abandon car purchases. Due to the unprecedented level of disruption to society and the automotive industry, including to car dealers, leasing companies, fleet providers, original equipment manufacturers (“OEMs”), wholesale traders and private consumers, as well as our employees and the way we operate our business, interactions at the Marketplace, particularly at physical auction and logistics sites were significantly impacted during the fiscal year 2021 with average weekly trading volume dipping to 4,000 at the start of the first quarter of the fiscal year 2021, compared to 29,000 at the start of the fourth quarter of the fiscal year 2020. In a number of countries our physical auctions and other operating sites have been required to close as a result of government legislation, as have many WeBuyAnyCar sites for periods of varying length. Interruptions to the businesses of our customers (including OEMs, leasing companies, dealers and fleet providers) resulted in unpredictable and reduced volumes of vehicles being handled by our Automotive Services division and a negative impact on trading performance. A significant proportion of our workforce (such as those involved in the physical movement of vehicles) cannot work remotely and potentially face additional risks as a result of the COVID 19 pandemic. In addition, some of our sites are visited by customers as part of their normal operations. We cannot guarantee that measures we take in order to limit the risks posed to such individuals will be sufficient and we may be subject to potential litigation or enforcement action as result of staff or customers alleging that our working practices are unsafe in this regard. Such litigation or enforcement action could result in material financial cost and damage to our reputation and brands. On July 10, 2020, out of an abundance of caution, we proactively and successfully negotiated certain covenant waivers with respect to certain of our existing debt facilities in order to mitigate the anticipated effects of the COVID 19 pandemic. These waivers were extended on January 22, 2021. However, a prolonged negative impact due to the COVID 19 pandemic or other factors may adversely affect our ability to comply with the financial covenants included in the Senior Facilities Agreement or any other similar agreement, and there can be no assurance that we would be able to successfully negotiate the covenant waivers with our lenders in such an event. The breach of a financial or other covenant or the failure to meet any of the obligations under our ----- financing agreements governing our debt may result in a default or event of default under such agreements, which in turn could result in a number of adverse consequences, including cross-defaults, the acceleration of the outstanding amounts requiring immediate repayment of the related debt in part or in whole, significant increases in interest rates and other financing and reputational costs. There is also no guarantee that debt financings will be available in the future to fund our obligations, or that they will be available on terms consistent with our expectations. The COVID 19 pandemic has caused, and is likely to continue to cause, severe economic, market and other disruptions worldwide. It cannot be assured that conditions in the credit lending, capital and other financial markets will not deteriorate as a result of the COVID 19 pandemic, or that our access to capital and other sources of funding will not become constrained or expensive, or that the credit or capital markets will be available in the future to fund our obligations. In addition, the terms of future debt agreements could include more restrictive covenants or require incremental collateral, which may restrict our business operations or make such debt unavailable due to our covenant restrictions then in effect. If we are unable to access the credit or capital markets in the longer term, on commercially reasonable terms or at all, our ability to carry out growth and business development initiatives would be limited, thereby potentially limiting our future growth opportunities. We also carry significant intangible assets on our balance sheet. As of March 28, 2021, the intangible assets on our balance sheet totaled £1,937.9 million, including £938.5 million in goodwill relating to the CA Acquisition. Pursuant to current accounting rules, we are required to assess goodwill and other intangible assets for impairment at least annually or more frequently if impairment indicators are present. Impairment indicators include, but are not limited to, significant underperformance relative to historical or projected future operating results and negative industry or economic trends. If such events were to occur, the carrying amount of our goodwill and other intangible assets may no longer be recoverable and we would be required to record an impairment charge. The COVID 19 pandemic and its impact on our business initially constituted an impairment indicator that we assessed and, accordingly, we recognized an exceptional goodwill impairment of £266.4 million in the 42-week period ended March 29, 2020. The impairment charge represented a change in the timing of vehicle volumes and associated discounted cash flows, which were expected through the Marketplace over the short term as economic activity recovers. See “Summary—Recent _Developments—Impact of COVID 19—Impairment Review” and “Operating and Financial Review—Factors Affecting Our Results of Operations—COVID 19—Impairment Review.”_ As a matter of ordinary business operations, we are subject to potential credit risk related to our buyer finance services, BCA Partner Finance. The negative economic impact of the COVID 19 pandemic may increase such risk. While we maintain a well-established credit scoring matrix it cannot be assured that buyers repay their debt owed to us on a widespread and systemic basis over an extended period of time. We have participated in available government schemes designed to support businesses negatively impacted by the COVID 19 pandemic. These schemes include mechanisms to allow companies to place employees on paid leave or on reduced working hours, with the difference to an employee’s ordinary salary being partially reimbursed by the respective government. In the UK, we have furloughed as much as 80% of our staff at the peak of the COVID 19 pandemic in April 2020, such number subsequently dropping below 60% by June 2020, and as of March 28, 2021, approximately 4% of our employees remained on short-term work. In addition, we have also applied for and made use of employee salary support schemes introduced by certain governments in the UK and continental Europe. While we are carefully tailoring our use of these COVID 19 prompted measures to ensure retention of the necessary knowledge and expertise to support the business going forward, as a result of these measures, there could be a loss of institutional knowledge, experience, and/or expertise which could limit our ability to manage the business effectively, react to external developments, retain vendors and make necessary technological developments. Similarly, these measures may negatively impact the morale of our workforce, leading to voluntary departures of additional employees. In addition, there can be no guarantee that similar schemes will be available in the future in the event of further COVID 19 or similar public health related disruption. In the event of future disruption and in the absence of similar support schemes, related costs may be significantly higher than experienced during the previous periods of COVID 19 restrictions with a negative impact on our ability to operate. The overall impact of the COVID 19 pandemic on our business remains uncertain and will ultimately depend on a number of factors that cannot be accurately predicted at this time. These factors include, but are not limited to, the duration (including the extent of any resurgence in the future) and the ultimate severity of the COVID 19 pandemic, the timing of and manner in which containment efforts are reduced or lifted and the ----- length of time it takes for normal economic and operating conditions to resume, which are all beyond our knowledge and control. Moreover, there are no comparable recent events that provide us with guidance. For these reasons, we cannot reasonably estimate the impact of the COVID 19 pandemic on our business with any certainty nor can we provide any assurance that the COVID 19 pandemic will not continue to have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition or results of operations. To the extent the COVID 19 pandemic continues to adversely affect our business, financial condition or results of operations, it may also have the effect of heightening other risks described in this section of this Offering Memorandum entitled “Risk Factors,” including those relating to our high level of indebtedness, our ability to generate sufficient cash flows to service our indebtedness, and our ability to comply with the covenants contained in the agreements that govern our indebtedness, including the indenture governing the Notes. In addition, as a consequence of the significantly increased volatility and instability experienced during periods of challenging macroeconomic conditions, it is difficult for us to forecast demand trends. We may be unable to accurately predict the extent or duration of cycles or their effect on our financial condition or result of operations and can give no assurance as to the timing, extent or duration of the current or future macroeconomic cycles. A decline in demand due to adverse macroeconomic conditions may also have an adverse impact on the business of the automotive industry and require us to substantially increase the amounts of financial assistance, to carry on our operations.

Subsubsection Title: We are exposed to general economic, political and regulatory conditions and risks in the countries in which we have operations and customers.
Subsubsection Text: We operate in the UK and in a number of continental European countries while selling vehicles to buyers in a wider geographic area. Consequently, our business and financial results are affected, directly and indirectly, by global economic conditions, such as instability in credit markets, declining consumer and business confidence, interest rates, volatile exchange rates, and other challenges such as uncertain or changing political or regulatory environments. A potential prolonged economic slowdown in the UK and continental Europe resulting from the COVID 19 pandemic poses a risk to our customers, our suppliers, our employees and the communities in which they and we operate. The current status of the COVID 19 pandemic around the world remains serious, and while there is cause for optimism (with the continuing progress on vaccinations across European countries and the UK in particular), there can be no assurance that vaccinations are effective and reopening will not be reversed in response to a resurgence in COVID 19 outbreaks. Negative economic developments, including due to global or local recessions, higher unemployment rates, diminished levels of consumer confidence, declines in income levels and the loss of wealth, have resulted in the past, and may result in the future, in decreased demand in the automotive industry. The ongoing COVID 19 pandemic may be associated with further or continued decline in economic activity and increase in unemployment levels which may negatively impact the demand for vehicles from consumers and business users. Since we rely on strong demand for the used vehicle market, we are particularly dependent on consumer confidence and spending power, two factors that are strongly influenced by overall economic conditions. Moreover, national and local governments may impose limitations and restrictions on the operation of our business in response to any future COVID 19 resurgence, and the impact of those restrictions may have a detrimental effect on our ability to operate (including but not limited to social distancing and other health and safety related measures, and possibly preventing or restricting some elements of our business from trading at all). Compliance with such regulations requires the application of financial and human resources and increases costs to the potential detriment of our business. Failure by us to comply, or the perception of non-compliance, with any such regulations may lead to enforcement action against us with possible financial costs and could also damage our brands and reputation. Although the used vehicle market has some countercyclical characteristics, adverse economic conditions in the countries where we have operations may negatively impact our financial results, and that of our vendors and buyers. Activity levels in the automotive industry can be affected by such factors as the availability of consumer credit, the growth of average wages and the level of unemployment, among others, which in turn could impact the volume of vehicles we handle. In addition, if OEMs in the UK were to experience declining new vehicles sales, the used vehicle market could in turn be negatively impacted, which would affect our Vehicle Buying division and Vehicle Remarketing division. Due to the relative size of our UK operations, compared to our operations in continental Europe, we are more exposed to changes in the UK economic environment. ----- The wider geopolitical environment in the UK and continental Europe is also beyond our control. Our business and operations are adversely affected by unstable or deteriorating international trade conditions. For example, the withdrawal of the UK from the EU effective December 31, 2020 (commonly referred to as “Brexit”) have resulted in substantial regulatory uncertainty regarding international trade and trade policy. Moreover, our international operations are subject to risks associated with the prevailing local political, economic and regulatory climate. For instance, it may be more difficult in certain jurisdictions for us to enforce contracts, collect receivables, terminate labor contracts, receive dividends and transfer funds. In addition, we may face risks associated with unexpected changes in the regulatory environment, particularly in relation to complexity of domestic and international customs and tariffs, potentially adverse tax consequences, restrictions on foreign trade or investment, currency exchange and capital controls, nationalization and expropriation and cancelation of our contractual relationships without full compensation for loss. Any of the aforementioned changes to general economic, political and regulatory conditions, and in particular any changes in the regulatory environment and potentially adverse tax consequences as a result thereof, could have a material adverse effect on our business, prospects, financial condition and results of operations.

Subsubsection Title: We are dependent on the supply of vehicles to the Marketplace.
Subsubsection Text: Our business is vulnerable to fluctuations in the supply of vehicles to our sales platforms, including our digital and physical auction sites (together, the “Marketplace”), which in turn depends on a variety of factors. For example, declines in demand in the automotive industry resulting from adverse macroeconomic conditions have historically adversely impacted used vehicle trade-ins to dealers, which has in turn reduced our auction volumes, as dealers represent a large proportion of our vendors. In addition, the supply of vehicles from corporate vendors, including contract hire, leasing and finance companies, can also be affected by adverse economic conditions if corporate vendors reduce the size of, or delay the renewal of, their fleets during an economic downturn. OEMs have also in the past reduced the number of vehicles manufactured during periods of macroeconomic decline, which, over time, can adversely affect the number of used vehicles in the market and thus the supply of vehicles to the Marketplace. Additionally, legislative and regulatory changes could adversely affect the supply of vehicles to the Marketplace. Furthermore, the supply of vehicles could also decrease if our vendors elect to sell their vehicles directly to our buyers, including private consumers. If, as a result of the foregoing factors or for any other reason, the supply of vehicles to the Marketplace declines, our business, prospects, financial condition and results of operations could be adversely affected. Furthermore, our ability to provide a large, attractive offering of used vehicles within our Vehicle Remarketing division depends on the number and quality of used vehicles we are able to purchase through WeBuyAnyCar, and the public’s willingness to tender their vehicles to our Vehicle Buying division. There can be no assurance that the supply of suitable vehicles at competitive prices will be sufficient to meet our needs and to continue to grow our offering. In addition, difficulties in sourcing a suitable inventory of used vehicles may arise, among others, due to errors from the proprietary pricing model we use to calculate purchase prices within WeBuyAnyCar, or a failure to adjust our pricing model in order to meet the most recent market trends. If we are unable to source a suitable inventory at competitive prices as a result of any of these factors, our business, prospects, financial condition and results of operations could be materially adversely affected.

Subsubsection Title: We depend on a limited number of vendors for a substantial portion of the vehicles we sell.
Subsubsection Text: Historically, a limited number of vendors have collectively accounted for a substantial portion of the vehicles sold through the Marketplace, notwithstanding the fact that WeBuyAnyCar (which sources vehicles from individual consumers) contributed 35% of all vehicles we remarketed in the 52-week period ended March 28, 2021, thereby partially de-risking our supply. The majority of sales arrangements with our vendors do not guarantee the provision of a minimum number of vehicles to us. Accordingly, we cannot give any assurance that our largest vendors will continue to provide us with a supply of vehicles, or that we would be able to replace the volumes of vehicles provided by these vendors were they to materially decrease. In addition, if one or more of our vendors’ financial condition deteriorates, or if a vendor were to restructure its operations, our loss of access to the vendor’s vehicles could have a material adverse effect on our business, prospects, financial condition and results of operations.

Subsubsection Title: Our business is vulnerable to declines in demand for used vehicles.
Subsubsection Text: If the demand for new or used vehicles decreases in the markets in which we operate, the volumes of, and the prices paid for, vehicles sold through the Marketplace may decrease, which in turn could reduce our margins. Although the used vehicle market has some countercyclical characteristics, no assurance can be given that ----- such market remains stable in times of economic downturn. A decline in demand from our buyers could be caused by a variety of factors, including adverse changes in macroeconomic conditions, such as stagnant growth, a decline in disposable income or consumer confidence and restricted access to consumer financing. High fuel prices may also disproportionately affect demand for vehicles with poor fuel-efficiency and lead to a reduction in the miles driven per vehicle, which could affect the number of vehicles sold through the Marketplace. Additionally, rising interest rates may depress sales of new or used vehicles because many purchasers finance their purchases. Furthermore, adverse changes in the credit quality of our buyers, arising from macroeconomic conditions or otherwise, could also lead to lower sales, as well as increase our counterparty risk. Any reduction in demand for used vehicles caused by these or any other reason could have a material adverse effect on our business, prospects, financial condition and results of operations.

Subsubsection Title: We may be adversely affected by a general decline in vehicle ownership or sudden changes in demand for certain types of used vehicles.
Subsubsection Text: Demand for our used vehicles may be adversely affected by trends that lead to an overall decline in demand for vehicles. For example, environmental concerns surrounding certain types of vehicle (older diesel vehicles, for example) or a growing share of younger people choosing not to purchase or lease their own vehicles, opting for ride-hailing services, ride-sharing services, car rental services and public transportation instead. These trends may continue or even intensify, in particular as urbanization continues and a growing share of the population migrates to major cities. As a result, overall demand for vehicles, including for used vehicles, may decline, which could adversely affect our business prospects. Furthermore, demand for certain types of used vehicles may suddenly decline due to the introduction of innovative technologies for new vehicles (e.g., autonomous driving systems). There is no guarantee that we will be able to quickly source more innovative vehicles as it may take several years before they become available in the used vehicle market. Consequently, sourcing and selling such vehicles may be more complex. Likewise, actions by OEMs or car dealers may have a significant impact on demand in the used vehicle market. If these parties decide to offer greater incentives for the sale of new vehicles (e.g., discounts or attractive financing), or generally lower prices for new vehicles, this could make buying a new vehicle more attractive. As a result, prices for used vehicles and our associated fees may decline. Prices may also decline due to insolvencies of rental car companies or other companies with large fleets or an increased number of returns of leased vehicles, which could result in oversupply. Conversely, any significant increase in market prices due to a scarcity of used vehicles could impact our ability to source desirable inventory at acceptable prices and our volume turnaround, which could have a material adverse effect on our continued growth and margins.

Subsubsection Title: We face competition and may not be able to successfully adapt to industry changes.
Subsubsection Text: Across each of our divisions, we face competition from other market participants (both established and new entrants). The Vehicle Buying division and the Vehicle Remarketing division face competition from other vehicle buying and remarketing companies both in the UK and continental Europe. In the Automotive Services division, we face competition from a broad range of competitors. Due to the increasing use of the Internet and other technology as remarketing and distribution channels, we also face increasing competition from online wholesale and retail vehicle selling platforms as well as from our own vendors when they sell directly to end consumers rather than remarket vehicles through the Marketplace. Increased competition could result in reduced profitability and/or loss of market share. Our future success may be impacted by our ability to respond to evolving industry trends, changes in buyer and vendor requirements and new technologies. Furthermore, some of our competitors may have greater financial and marketing resources, may be able to respond more quickly to evolving industry dynamics and changes in vendor or buyer requirements or may be able to devote greater resources to the development, promotion and sale of new or emerging services and technologies. If we are unable to compete successfully or to successfully adapt to industry changes, our business, prospects, financial condition and results of operations could be materially adversely affected.

Subsubsection Title: A disruption in supply chains may adversely affect our Vehicle Remarketing division and Automotive Services division.
Subsubsection Text: Our Vehicle Remarketing division and Automotive Services division offer a wide range of non-auction services, such as inspection, appraisal, repair and refurbishment, storage and handling. These services expose us to supply chain risks, as we are dependent on the availability of certain automotive parts and skilled labor ----- to ensure that vehicles can move seamlessly along the automotive value chain, from collection through inspection, repairs and onwards sale. Any reduction, or any delays or disruptions, in the supply chains of the materials and components used by our Vehicle Remarketing division or Automotive Services division could result in a significant disruption to our operations and affect our ability to meet our commitments. Similarly, the lack of skilled labor to undertake inspection, appraisal, repair and refurbishment, storage as well as handling services could result in a significant disruption to our operations. These disruptions may result from many reasons, including increasing demands for certain automotive parts, closures of suppliers’ plants or critical manufacturing lines due to strikes, mechanical failures or breakdowns, electrical outages, fire, explosions, political upheaval, competition for skilled labor as well as logistical complications resulting from severe weather or other natural disasters and delayed customs processing. Financial difficulties of our major suppliers may also lead to delays in the delivery of materials and components. The unavailability of any automotive parts or skilled labor required to deliver our inspection, appraisal, repair and refurbishment, storage and handling services could cause our Vehicle Remarketing division and Automotive Services division to incur significant delays. The risk of disruptions in the supply of materials and components that we use is heightened due to the greater political, economic and social instability created by Brexit, which may lead to further complications with respect to customs processing and/or may lead to limited transportation infrastructure and difficulties in finding alternative reliable, costefficient and qualified suppliers that can freely move between the UK and continental Europe. Brexit and the related restrictions on free movement of labor across the English Channel has also heightened the risk that skilled labor may be unavailable. See “—We are exposed to general economic, political and regulatory conditions _and risks in the countries in which we have operations and customers.”_

Subsubsection Title: Our business is dependent on certain information and technology systems, and the failure to effectively maintain, protect, develop or update these systems or cyber security attacks could have a negative impact on our business.
Subsubsection Text: Our business and financial performance depend on the effective operation of our information and technology systems, increasingly including our cloud-hosted and digital selling platforms. It is therefore essential that key systems, software and hardware are operational at all times. Substantially all of our remarketing buyers access our systems via websites and/or mobile applications to view vehicles coming to auction prior to participating in our auctions, and to participate in the various types of auctions and Bid Now/Buy Now sales themselves. In addition, our customers also use WeBuyAnyCar’s online vehicle pricing quotation system to obtain a valuation of their vehicle. We are therefore reliant on the operation of WeBuyAnyCar’s online platform, as well as a number of mobile applications, which offer vehicle search functions, bidding features and access to live information such as pricing, vehicle condition, and individual lot/auction timings. Our digital services are accessed by a large number of users, often at the same time, and if user traffic increases, we may not be able to scale our technology to accommodate increased capacity requirements, which may result in interruptions or delays in service. The business is also reliant on the systems that power the Automotive Services division’s remote operations, such as transporters, inspect and collect operatives, appraisers and imaging. We rely on a large range of computer and other information systems which are essential to our operations and which became even more important during the COVID 19 pandemic, when our operating model shifted towards an online business. Accordingly, the continued and uninterrupted performance of those systems, along with their development and implementation, are vital factors in the operation of our business. We depend on our technical infrastructure for all aspects of the day-to-day management of our business and the delivery of our services. Any material disruption to the operation of such infrastructure, including as a result of legislative and regulatory changes regarding online sales and e-commerce, may materially and negatively affect our business, prospects, financial condition and results of operations. Interruptions in these systems, whether due to system failures, computer viruses, software errors or physical or electronic break-ins, or other factors could affect the security or availability of our products and services on our websites or mobile applications and prevent or inhibit the ability of vendors and buyers to access our services. Electronic break-ins and cyber security attacks continue to increase in both prevalence and sophistication throughout the digital world with the potential to corrupt, affect or destroy key systems and data, including the confidentiality, integrity and availability of our data and systems. Given that techniques used in these break-ins and attacks change frequently and often are not recognized until launched against a target, it may be impossible to properly secure our systems. In addition, technical advances or a continued expansion and increased complexity of our digital offering could increase the likelihood of security breaches. The risk of electronic break-ins and cyber security attacks includes breaches and attempted breaches not only of our own products, services and systems, but also of those of our customers, employees, contractors, business partners, and other third parties as well as of third-party systems on which we rely to operate our digital platforms. ----- Successful breaches, employee malfeasance, or human or technological error could result in, for example, unauthorized access to, disclosure, modification, misuse, loss, or destruction of our data or systems or those of our customers or other third parties, theft of sensitive, regulated, or confidential data including personal information and intellectual property, loss of access to critical data or systems through ransomware, destructive attacks or other means, and business delays, service or system disruptions or denials of service. In addition, the fast-paced, evolving, pervasive and sophisticated nature of certain cyber threats and vulnerabilities, as well as the scale and complexity of the business and infrastructure, make it possible that certain threats or vulnerabilities will be undetected or unmitigated in time to prevent an attack on one of our customers and its customers. Furthermore, these risks will increase as we continue to shift of our operating model towards an online business in response to the COVID 19 pandemic. Problems with the reliability, availability or security of our systems and digital service offerings could harm our reputation, result in a loss of vendors or buyers or necessitate additional costs, fines or penalties, any of which could harm our business, prospects, financial condition and results of operations. Certain vendors, as a condition of operating through us, audit our information and technology systems. These audits may require significant management time to address and could result in costly changes to information and technology systems as a condition of continued operation. The loss of the supply of vehicles from a vendor or the cost of changes to our information and technology systems following an audit could have a material adverse effect on our business, prospects, financial condition and results of operations. Robust back office systems, including auction information systems, are also critical to our ability to attract visitors to our websites. These systems are also imperative for the operation of our website and mobile applications, pricing, third-party data feeds, customer service, internal and external communications, procurement, logistics, administration and financial reporting. In addition, we are dependent on certain third-party information and technology systems, particularly with respect to payment processing, vehicle licensing checks and fraud detection. In particular, we face liability risks in connection with online credit card fraud and problems adequately securing our payment systems, despite using market-standard protocols designed to ensure enhanced security and strong identification for our customers when they use their debit or credit cards for vehicle purchases. The failure or unavailability of any of our information and technology systems to detect such type of fraud or other errors with respect to payment processing or vehicle licensing checks could have a material adverse effect on our business, prospects, financial condition and results of operations. Much of our physical information and technology infrastructure (including servers, website hosting, database storage and wide area networks) is supplied by service providers via managed services contracts. Technical or other service problems faced by our managed service providers could adversely affect the experience of our vendors and buyers. Any financial or operational difficulties faced by our managed service providers or any of the third-party service providers with whom they contract may have adverse effects on our business, the nature and extent of which are difficult to predict. Furthermore, any disruption of the distribution channels or networks used by our mobile applications could adversely affect the ability to access or update our mobile applications, which could have a material adverse effect on our business, prospects, financial condition and results of operations. Our success also depends on our continued innovation and ability to provide features that make our websites and mobile applications user-friendly, particularly through the development of specific software and applications under a variety of new platforms and operating systems, which are generally expected by users to offer the same features or flexibility and to be as easily and intuitively operated as desktop interfaces. As technology improves and as our operations grow in size, scope and complexity, we will need to improve and upgrade our systems and infrastructure, which may require substantial financial, operational and technical resources. Delays or difficulties in implementing new or enhanced systems may impair our ability to provide digital services to our vendors and buyers or may reduce the effectiveness of digital auctions, which could have a material adverse effect on our business, prospects, financial condition and results of operations.

Subsubsection Title: Acceptance of our digital platforms and mobile applications as suitable platforms for the sale and purchase of used vehicles may decrease or fail to improve.
Subsubsection Text: The restrictions on physical sales activity (including physical auctions) due to the COVID 19 pandemic has significantly increased the volume of vehicles traded digitally across the used vehicle market and via the Marketplace. While the acceptance of our digital platforms has been strong by both buyers and vendors, there is no guarantee that overall online acceptance in the used vehicle market will be maintained or increased. If the acceptance of our digital offering decreases or fails to grow, we may not be able to achieve the future growth we target. -----

Subsubsection Title: Our inventory and vehicles held on behalf of others may be damaged by extreme weather or other events outside our control, and the insurance we carry may be inadequate.
Subsubsection Text: During the handling of new and used vehicles across the business, large numbers of vehicles are transported and stored by us in both covered and open-air facilities. We are liable for the vehicles we own (the majority of which are purchased through the Vehicle Buying division) and, in many cases, we are liable for the vehicles supplied by vendors for auction through the Vehicle Remarketing division, as well as when we collect and deliver vehicles through our logistics services. Extreme weather, such as hail storms, fire and flooding, which has in the past damaged vehicles in our possession, natural disasters (such as extreme precipitation or extreme temperature) or other catastrophic events (such as terrorism and large-scale accidents) may adversely affect our physical facilities or damage vehicles awaiting sale or vehicles generally stored by us. Such risks are particularly prevalent in respect of our open air facilities. In addition, there is no assurance that used vehicles in our inventory will be properly protected (e.g., against theft or vandalism). This may result in an increase in costs, delay or cancelation of auction sales, any of which could have a material adverse impact on our revenue and profitability. Our failure to meet vendors’ or buyers’ demands in such situations could further adversely affect our reputation, reduce customer satisfaction, damage relationships with both vendors and buyers and result in a loss of future business. We maintain insurance cover for risks including property damage, business interruption, employers and public liability, as well as for certain other claims consistent with customary practice in the industry in which we operate. However, claims not covered by our insurance or in excess of our insurance coverage may arise, such as from a natural disaster, theft or other causes outside our control. Moreover, we may be unable in future periods to obtain insurance coverage on acceptable terms, without substantial premiums increase or at all, particularly if there is deterioration in our claim experience history. A successful claim against us, which is not covered by or in excess of our coverage could have a material adverse effect on our business, prospects, financial condition and results of operations.

Subsubsection Title: We are subject to complex taxation in multiple jurisdictions, in particular relating to valued-added taxes.
Subsubsection Text: We are subject to taxation in multiple jurisdictions, including in the UK and continental Europe. Because of the complex interplay between our business and the various taxation regimes to which we are subject, the provision made for taxes in the accounts involves a significant amount of judgement and uncertainty regarding the interpretation of relevant facts and laws in the jurisdictions in which we operate. Changes to existing tax laws or tax reporting obligations, or the introduction of new tax laws or obligations (for instance with regards to online sales), in any of these jurisdictions could adversely impact our business, prospects, financial condition and results of operations. The risks associated to unforeseen changes to existing tax laws or tax reporting obligations are compounded by the uncertainty created by Brexit and legislatives changes in connection thereto (see “—We are exposed to general economic, political and regulatory conditions and risks in _the countries in which we have operations and customers”) and the shift of our operating model towards an_ online business in response to the COVID 19 pandemic (see “—The COVID 19 pandemic has had, and will _continue to have, a significant adverse effect on our business, operations, financial condition, operating results and liquidity, and the ultimate outcome of the COVID 19 pandemic is uncertain”)._ Additionally, we are subject to complex laws and regulations in many countries involving VAT and other indirect taxes. In the jurisdictions in which we operate, we are responsible for collecting any VAT amounts due on the vehicles we sell, and we rely on our vendors to provide accurate and complete information relating to the VAT status of each vehicle to enable us to calculate the amount of any VAT due. We also rely on purchasers of our vehicles at auction to provide accurate information regarding their residency in order to assess appropriate treatment of VAT for sales invoices. If a vendor or buyer provides incorrect or incomplete VATrelated information, or if we fail to implement or fully comply with local VAT rules and regulations, we may be exposed to VAT claims and fines from relevant authorities. In the ordinary course of our business, we are frequently subject to VAT and other tax audits by relevant authorities throughout Europe, and these audits can relate to matters that arose many years in the past. The outcome of these audits could result in additional VAT claims and/or regulatory actions against us, which could have a material adverse effect on our business, prospects, financial condition and results of operations.

Subsubsection Title: We may not successfully implement our strategic initiatives.
Subsubsection Text: Our future operating results are dependent, in part, on our success in implementing our strategic and tactical initiatives. These initiatives are focused on enhancing our competitive advantage as an integrated end-to-end ----- service provider, further expanding internationally, strengthening our infrastructure and logistics network, capitalizing on favorable industry trends, continuing to enhance our data capabilities and improving our operational efficiencies, cash flow and leverage. These initiatives will require extensive planning and management attention and entail substantial execution risk. Notably, our strategy is focused on meaningful growth of vehicle volumes transaction through our marketplaces. Such volume growth requires simultaneous success in several different domains including: (i) commercial success with vendors, so they supply higher volume to our marketplaces; (ii) maintained data leadership in order for the marketplaces to provide efficient liquidity to all participants; (iii) digital product leadership to make our integrated services offering the most relevant in the market; and (iv) best-in-class logistics and services footprint to deliver an integrated end-to-end digital and physical service. Failure to maintain our competitive advantages in any of these dimension could have a material could have a material adverse effect on our business, prospects, financial condition and results of operations. In addition, new digital platforms will also require substantial IT support and infrastructure and, as we grow, we will need to ensure our back-office IT systems are integrated across our operations. With respect to the Vehicle Buying division, our strategy places particular importance on expanding WeBuyAnyCar’s operations. However, there can be no assurance that WeBuyAnyCar will continue to grow in the UK. As we seek to expand car buying into new markets, we may also need to comply with unfamiliar regulatory regimes. In addition, because car buying involves purchasing vehicles and holding them as inventory until their sale (in contrast to our UK Vehicle Remarketing division and our International Vehicle Remarketing division, which do not include WeBuyAnyCar’s operations, and do not take title to the majority of vehicles that they sell), the expansion of such operations may increase our cash requirements and inventory risk, thereby increasing our depreciation and impairment charges. Similarly, recalls by OEMs are a common occurrence and have accelerated in frequency and scope in recent years. In case of such recalls, we may have to temporarily remove the affected used vehicles from our inventory and may be unable to liquidate such inventory in a timely manner or at all. The same may occur if regulatory changes (e.g., the introduction of stricter emission standards) prevent consumers from driving certain used vehicles in cities or at all, consequently reducing demand for the affected vehicles. If we are unable to sell the vehicles purchased at an appropriate price, or at all, we may incur write-downs or our business, prospects, financial condition and results of operations may be adversely affected. In addition, the implementation of our strategic initiatives in certain international markets may not produce the benefits achieved in markets where we already have established operations. Each new market that we enter will require us to address the particular economic, currency, political and regulatory risks associated with that new market, which may entail finding new partners, hiring and training new staff with local language skills and an understanding of the local market, and learning the customs and cultures of the new country. These processes can be difficult, costly and divert management and personnel resources. Additionally, our business strategies may change from time to time, which could delay our ability to implement initiatives that we believe are important to our business. Our inability to successfully implement our strategic initiatives could result in, among others, the loss of clients and personnel, the loss of market share, the impairment of assets and inefficiencies from operating in new markets, any of which could have a material adverse effect on our business, prospects, financial condition and results of operations.

Subsubsection Title: We may be unable to successfully identify and acquire or integrate future acquisitions into our business.
Subsubsection Text: Our growth has been, in part, attributable to the acquisition of other businesses, and we may continue to expand our business through acquisitions and other business combinations in the future. The success of our acquisition strategy will depend on our ability to identify suitable acquisition candidates, to assess the value, strengths, weaknesses, contingent or other liabilities and potential profitability of acquisition candidates, to negotiate acceptable purchase terms, to obtain any necessary permits or approvals and to integrate the operations of such businesses, once acquired. Successful integration of future acquisitions will depend on our ability to effect any necessary changes in operations or personnel resulting from the acquisition. Acquisitions may also expose us to new risks, including difficulties in integrating and operating businesses in countries that are new to us, difficulties integrating acquired businesses in a cost-effective manner, unforeseen legal, regulatory, contractual, employment or other issues or expenses arising out of an acquisition, potential disruptions to our ongoing business caused by acquisitions, including pressure on management’s time and resources, or an acquired business’ failure to meet our expectations or business plans. The occurrence of any ----- of these risks could have an adverse impact on our ability to make acquisitions and may limit our growth, which could have a material adverse effect on our business, prospects, financial condition and results of operations.

Subsubsection Title: We may not be able to provide financing in order to offer stock funding (trade finance) to registered dealers through BCA Partner Finance or to repossess the financed vehicles serving as collateral.
Subsubsection Text: To support the attractiveness of our offering, we seek to help certain registered dealers in the UK by offering stock funding (trade finance). To this end, we have entered into a £220 million non-recourse receivables facility (the “Receivables Facility”) with a syndicate of banks, who provide the liquidity to support our BCA Partner Finance business, of which £148.3 million was drawn as of March 28, 2021. If these banks are no longer willing to provide financing to us or only grant such financing on disadvantageous terms, we may not be able to offer attractive financing options to registered dealers. As a result, demand for our used vehicles may suffer and we may not be able to grow our business as envisaged. In addition, we use our sold vehicles as security when offering stock funding (trade finance) and cooperate with third-party collection agents to repossess such vehicles, should registered dealers default on their obligations. We may, however, not be able to locate the relevant vehicles and successfully repossess them (e.g., if they are transported outside the UK). Furthermore, the residual value of the repossessed vehicles may be lower than anticipated (e.g., if they are involved in accidents), and we may not be able to take recourse against the relevant car dealer. As a result, we may incur significant losses even where we use sold vehicles as security for BCA Partner Finance. See “Business—Operations—Value-Added Services—Post-auction Services.”

Subsubsection Title: We may not be able to protect our intellectual property rights.
Subsubsection Text: Our intellectual property rights include proprietary technology and software relating to digital auction systems as well as trademarks, trade secrets, copyrights and other intellectual property. Our increased reliance in recent years on proprietary Internet-based programs and technology have increased the relative importance of intellectual property assets to our business. Our business and IT systems and other key proprietary intellectual property generally are not protected by patents or registered design rights. As a result, we are particularly reliant on trademarks, copyright, database rights, registered domain names and the law protecting confidential information to protect our brands, technologies, software and databases. Although we have taken steps to reduce these risks, these steps may be inadequate. Effective intellectual property protection also may not be available in every country in which our services are offered, deployed or made available. Any significant impairment of our intellectual property rights or any inability to protect our intellectual property rights could have an adverse effect on our business, prospects, financial condition and results of operations. Moreover, we may be required to spend significant funds on monitoring and protecting our intellectual property rights and we may not be able to discover all infringements, misappropriations or other violations of our intellectual property. If we initiate litigation against infringements of our intellectual property, such litigation may prove costly and there is no guarantee that it will ultimately be successful and that the rulings we obtain will adequately remedy the damage we have suffered. In addition, we provide certain information to third-party service providers who help us assess the performance of our business (e.g., Google Analytics). Consequently, we only have limited control to ensure that such information is not misused by such service providers or passed on to third parties, including our competitors.

Subsubsection Title: We may be accused of infringing on the intellectual property of third parties.
Subsubsection Text: As we utilize a variety of intellectual property for our business, vendors, regulatory authorities or other third parties may allege that we infringe on their intellectual property, and we may therefore become subject to allegations and litigation against us. Even unfounded allegations of infringement may adversely affect our reputation and business and may require significant resources to defend against. If we try to obtain licenses from such third parties to settle these disputes, there is no guarantee that such licenses will be available to us on acceptable terms, or at all, in which case we may be required to alter our brands and change the way we operate. Furthermore, some of the agreements we enter into with third parties may contain clauses regarding the protection of their intellectual property licensed to us. A violation of these clauses (e.g., the unauthorized sub-licensing or disclosure of a confidential source code) may require us to pay significant penalties, prevent us from utilizing such intellectual property in the future and result in litigation against us. In addition, some of our proprietary technology was developed on the basis of proprietary and non-proprietary software licensed from third parties. If these licenses were to be challenged or found invalid through litigation or other ----- proceedings, we may not be able to continue to utilize such proprietary technology. In addition, the licensors or other third parties may claim that the use of such technology is outside the scope of the relevant license and therefore infringes upon their intellectual property.

Subsubsection Title: We may be adversely affected by changes in laws and regulations, in particular those governing the trading of used vehicles and the automotive industry in general.
Subsubsection Text: We are required to comply with a wide range of laws and regulations relating to, among other things, the purchase and sale of used vehicles, the state of such vehicles, the use of the internet, online payments, consumer protection, data protection as well as road traffic, environmental, planning and employment matters, and the application of such laws and regulations by local authorities may vary. We may face risks associated with unexpected changes in the regulatory environment, particularly in relation to complexity of domestic and international customs and tariffs, potentially adverse tax consequences, restrictions on foreign trade or investment, currency exchange and capital controls, nationalization and expropriation and cancelation of our contractual relationships without full compensation for loss. Any changes in the laws and regulations, applicable to our business and operations, including used vehicles in our inventory, as well as the Marketplace, or changes to the application and interpretation of such laws and regulations by authorities and courts, may adversely affect our operations (such as the supply of vehicles) or may give rise to substantial compliance costs, adjustment expenses and other costs as well as fines in connection with our business activities, or prevent us from executing our strategy as planned. Even legislative initiatives and the corresponding public debates could result in significant uncertainty, regardless of whether such initiatives ultimately become law. We must comply with such regulations to the extent they are applicable to us as noncompliance could lead to the imposition of fines or other sanctions.

Subsubsection Title: Our failure to prevent unauthorized access to personal data or otherwise process personal data in accordance with applicable data protection laws could result in legal liability for, and reputational harm.
Subsubsection Text: We process and store personal data as part of our business, including in relation to our employees, vendors and buyers. Strict data protection laws exist in both the UK and throughout continental Europe. These data protection laws require us to ensure an appropriate level of security of personal data, having regard to the possibility of damage to and the nature of the data. Failure to take appropriate information security measures could result in personal data being processed in an unauthorized or potentially unlawful manner. The General Data Protection Regulation (Regulation (EU) 2016/679) (the “GDPR”) and the UK Data Protection Act 2018 significantly change the data protection landscape in the EU and the UK. Such laws and regulations strengthen the rights of individuals (data subjects), impose stricter controls over the processing of personal data by both controllers and processors of personal data and impose stricter sanctions with substantial administrative fines and potential claims for damages from data subjects for breach of their rights. The GDPR also offers data subjects the option to allow privacy organizations to litigate on their behalf, including collecting potential damages, which may result in a substantial increase in claims being brought. Should a serious data breach occur, the GDPR provides for increased obligations to notify regulators and data subjects whose personal data has been compromised and may result in the imposition of significant sanctions and penalties, which will require heightened escalation and notification processes with associated response plans. Complying with all relevant data protection laws and regulation is relatively complex. We, or the entities or businesses acquired by us, may have entered in the past or may enter in the future into employment agreements or other types of material contracts that may not be compliant with applicable data protection laws and regulations. Moreover, our customers frequently require that we demonstrate our compliance with data protection laws as they deem appropriate with respect to any personal data we may process on their behalf. Failure to demonstrate such compliance to their satisfaction may result in action including, but not limited to, the loss of contracts with such customers. The failure to comply with our obligations under applicable data protection laws could potentially result in us being issued with undertakings, enforcement notices (the failure with which to comply would be a criminal offence) and fines, as well as suffer damage to our brand and reputation, any of which could have a material adverse effect on our business, prospects, financial condition and results of operations.

Subsubsection Title: We are subject to a variety of laws and regulations across the jurisdictions in which we operate, some of which are unsettled and still developing.
Subsubsection Text: Our operations are subject to compliance with extensive laws and regulations, both in the UK and across continental Europe, including, but not limited to, laws relating to vehicle brokerages and auctions, currency ----- reporting obligations, data protection, competition, consumer protection, advertising, the Internet, property usage, money laundering, bribery and taxation. A failure to comply with these laws and regulations could result in fines, criminal sanctions, liability to third parties, license revocation and reputational damage, which in turn could adversely affect our ability to conduct our business as well as our profitability. Furthermore, if laws and regulations are not enforced equally against our competitors in a particular market, our compliance with laws and regulations may put us at a competitive disadvantage vis-à-vis non-complying competitors. Changes in laws or regulations or the adoption of new laws and regulations applicable to us may also increase the costs of providing services or limit our ability to expand our service offerings, any of which could adversely impact our business, prospects, financial condition and results of operations. More stringent laws or regulations may impose additional burdens on us, and it is difficult to predict the impact of new or amended laws or regulations to which we may become subject. There is, and will likely continue to be, an increasing number of laws, regulations and court decisions pertaining to the Internet and online commerce, which may relate to liability for information retrieved from or transmitted over the Internet. For example, in certain jurisdictions where we operate, local regulations impose restrictions on or prohibit credit and debit card operations in order to protect the privacy and security of personal information that is collected, processed and transmitted in or from the governing jurisdiction. The growth and development of online commerce has also prompted calls for more stringent consumer protection laws and more aggressive enforcement efforts by regulatory authorities that may impose additional burdens on online businesses generally. Because of our relatively large physical property portfolio, we are also subject to the risk that we could be compelled by government authorities to sell or vacate the property on which we operate or to make significant changes to the operations and activities we undertake to comply with changes to planning regulations. Furthermore, because of our international operations, the various regulatory regimes to which we are subject may conflict so that compliance with the regulatory requirements in one jurisdiction may create regulatory issues in another, thereby making compliance more difficult and increasing the costs of conducting our business. In addition, if we were to expand into new countries, we could face legal, regulatory or tax requirements with which we are not familiar. Compliance with current or future laws and regulations to which we are subject could place significant demands on our resources, as well as subject us to unforeseen and potentially adverse legal, regulatory or tax consequences, which could adversely impact our business, prospects, financial condition and results of operations.

Our largest cost is payroll, driven primarily by the number of our employees and their wages and salaries. If relationships with our employees were to deteriorate, we could experience strikes, unionization efforts or other types of conflicts, which could lead to interruption to our operations and increased costs. In addition, payroll costs could increase because we compete with other service providers to recruit and retain skilled employees, which has become more challenging as a result of Brexit and the related restrictions on free movement of labor across the English Channel. High employment levels can lead to scarcity of staff and a corresponding increase in the wages and salaries necessary to attract and retain suitable employees may be indispensable in the future. In addition, future legislative changes relating to the minimum wage could necessitate an increase in payroll costs. We also undertake significant marketing activities, in particular for our Vehicle Buying division, and any increase in television, radio and Internet advertising rates could increase our operating expenses. Moreover, we incur significant fuel, power and other consumable supply costs across our operations that may escalate and there can be no assurance that our costs will not grow at a faster rate than our revenue. If we are unable to pass on future cost increases to our vendors or buyers, our operating profit margin could be adversely affected, which could adversely impact our business, prospects, financial condition and results of operations.

Subsubsection Title: We rely on the strength of our brands, and the costs of maintaining and enhancing our brand awareness may increase.
Subsubsection Text: Our brands, corporate image and reputation constitute a significant part of our value proposition. Our success over the years has largely depended on our ability to develop our brands and corporate image as a leading vehicle auction company in the UK and continental Europe. In addition, the WeBuyAnyCar consumer brand in the UK is particularly important to the Vehicle Buying division, and the development of the WeBuyAnyCar brand historically has required significant financial expenditure, particularly on marketing and advertising. ----- In order to maintain WeBuyAnyCar’s reputation, we have to be able to respond to changes in marketing and advertising rules, consumer sentiment and consumer preferences, all of which may change rapidly and as a result of factors outside of our control. Our brands could be adversely affected by the actions of other companies that damage the reputation of our industry as a whole, in particular in relation to the Vehicle Buying division, as several companies operate under names similar to WeBuyAnyCar’s name. As we seek to expand our operations, maintaining and increasing the awareness and perceived quality of our brands and corporate image will be important to attract and expand our vendor and buyer base. We use Internet search engines, in particular Google, to generate traffic to our websites. The purchase of keywords consists of anticipating words and terms consumers will use to search on Internet search engines and then bidding on those words and terms in the applicable search engine’s auction system. Search engines, including Google, frequently update and change the logic that determines the placement and display of results of a search, such that the purchased or algorithmic placement of links to our websites can be adversely affected. Our positioning on a search engine’s search results depends on algorithms designed by the search engine provider and are based on various criteria including, in particular, the historical level of traffic on our websites. As a result, if search engine providers change their search algorithms in a manner that is competitively disadvantageous to us, our ability to generate traffic to our websites would be harmed. Furthermore, our mobile applications rely on app stores operated by third parties, in particular Apple, which make mobile applications available for download. The structure of these app stores may change and third-party operators may decide to exclude our mobile applications from their offering (e.g., if we do not agree to changes in terms and conditions), which may adversely affect the availability of our mobile applications. These operators may also charge us fees to list our mobile applications for download, which could adversely affect our margins or result in us discontinuing to offer our mobile applications through third-party app stores. We will continue to invest in, and devote resources to, advertising and marketing, as well as other efforts to preserve and enhance customer awareness of our brands. In particular, we expect to spend significant amounts on television, radio and Internet advertising to support WeBuyAnyCar, which is a purely customer brand. There can be no assurance, however, that our advertising campaigns will successfully maintain or enhance customer awareness of our brands. Advertising campaigns may be ineffective and may even have adverse effects on website traffic and brand perception as a result of factors potentially out of our control, such as changes in consumer preferences and regulatory reforms impacting advertising and marketing rules. Even if we are successful in our branding efforts, significant costs are incurred in order to develop, deploy and update our advertising campaigns, and as a result our efforts may not be cost-effective because, among others, assumptions regarding required customer acquisition costs and resulting revenue prove to be incorrect. In addition, we cannot guarantee that our current marketing channels will continue to be effective, permissible and generally available to us in the future. For television marketing, the program during which we broadcast our commercials may not achieve the anticipated number of viewers. For our online marketing, the relevant partners may be unable to deliver the anticipated traffic to our website and mobile applications. In particular, the popularity of social media channels tends to fluctuate, making it difficult to predict which channels are best suited to reach a mass audience. Moreover, any negative publicity may be accelerated through social media (e.g., Facebook, Instagram and Twitter) due to its immediacy and accessibility as a means of communication. Social media and websites immediately publish posts from users, often without filters or checks on the accuracy of the content posted. New and existing customers value readily available information concerning digital offerings and often act on such posts without further investigation or authentication. Allegations against us may be posted on social media, in Internet chat rooms or on blogs or websites by anyone on an anonymous basis. Any negative publicity, even if factually incorrect or based on isolated incidents, or the failure to maintain or enhance customer awareness of our brands and generate demand in a cost-effective manner could damage our reputation, diminish the strength of our brands, undermine the trust and credibility we have established, have a negative impact on our ability to attract new or retain existing customers and require us to spend significant time and money to address such negative publicity.

Subsubsection Title: We may not be able to effectively communicate with our customers through email and other messages.
Subsubsection Text: We use newsletters (e.g., emails) as a free marketing tool to promote our digital and physical offering, website and mobile applications. Our emails may, however, be shown as “spam”or given a lower priority, which could reduce the likelihood of addresses opening or responding positively to them.
