See “Description of the Notes—Change of Control” and “Description of the _Notes—Certain Definitions—Specified Change of Control Event.”_ The definition of “Change of Control”in the Indenture includes a disposition of all or substantially all of the assets of the Parent and its restricted subsidiaries, taken as a whole, to any person. Although there is a limited body of case law interpreting the phrase “all or substantially all,” there is no precise established definition of the phrase under applicable law. Accordingly, in certain circumstances, there may be a degree of uncertainty as to whether a particular transaction would involve a disposition of all or substantially all of the Parent’s and its restricted subsidiaries’ assets, taken as a whole. As a result, it may be unclear as to whether a change of control has occurred and whether the Issuer is required to make an offer to repurchase the Notes.

Subsection Title: Risks Related to Our Financial Profile, Our Structure, the Notes and the Guarantees
Subsubsection Title: Certain covenants may be suspended upon the occurrence of a change in our ratings.
Subsubsection Text: The Indenture will provide that, if at any time following the date of the Indenture, the Notes receive Investment Grade Status (as defined under “Description of the Notes—Certain Definitions”) and no default or event of default has occurred and is continuing, then beginning that day the following provisions of the Indenture will not apply to the Notes: “Description of the Notes—Certain Covenants—Limitation on _Indebtedness,” “Description of the Notes—Certain Covenants—Limitation on Restricted Payments,”_ “Description of the Notes—Certain Covenants—Limitation on Restrictions on Distributions from Restricted _Subsidiaries,” “Description of the Notes—Certain Covenants—Limitation on Sales of Assets and Subsidiary Stock,” “Description of the Notes—Certain Covenants—Limitation on Affiliate Transactions,” “Description of the Notes—Certain Covenants—Additional Guarantees and Collateral” and the provisions of clause (3) of the_ first paragraph of the covenant described under “—Merger and Consolidation—The Issuer and the Parent” and, in each case, any related default provision of the Indenture. Notwithstanding the foregoing, if the rating assigned by any such rating agency to such Notes should subsequently decline to below “Baa3” or “BBB,” as applicable, the foregoing covenants will be reinstituted as at and from the date of such rating decline. If these covenants were to be suspended, we would be able to incur additional debt or make payments, including dividends or investments, without restrictions under the Notes which may conflict with the interests of the holders of the Notes. There can be no assurance that the Notes will ever achieve an investment grade rating or that any such rating will be maintained. -----

Subsection Title: Risks Related to Our Financial Profile, Our Structure, the Notes and the Guarantees
Subsubsection Title: If the Notes are redeemed early, an investor may not be able to reinvest such proceeds in a comparable security.
Subsubsection Text: In the event that the Notes are redeemed early in accordance with the provisions described under “Description _of the Notes—Optional Redemption” and depending on prevailing market conditions at the time, an investor_ who receives proceeds due to such an early redemption may not be able to reinvest such proceeds in a comparable security at an effective interest rate as high as that carried by the Notes.

Subsection Title: Risks Related to Our Financial Profile, Our Structure, the Notes and the Guarantees
Subsubsection Title: If certain changes to tax law were to occur, we would have the option to redeem the Notes.
Subsubsection Text: If certain changes in the law of any Relevant Taxing Jurisdiction (as defined under “Description of the _Notes—Additional Amounts”) affecting taxation become effective that would impose withholding taxes or_ other deductions on the payments on the Notes or the Guarantees, we may redeem the Notes in whole, but not in part, at a redemption price of 100% of the principal amount, plus accrued and unpaid interest and Additional Amounts, if any, to the date of redemption. We are unable to determine whether such developments affecting taxation will be enacted, but if such change do occur, the Notes will be redeemable at our option.

Subsection Title: Risks Related to Our Financial Profile, Our Structure, the Notes and the Guarantees
Subsubsection Title: Credit ratings may not reflect all risks, are not recommendations to buy or hold securities and may be subject to revision, suspension or withdrawal at any time.
Subsubsection Text: One or more independent credit rating agencies may assign credit ratings to the Notes. The credit ratings address our ability to perform our obligations under the terms of the Notes and credit risks in determining the likelihood that payments will be made when due under the Notes. The ratings may not reflect the potential impact of all risks related to the structure, market, additional risk factors discussed in this section of this Offering Memorandum entitled “Risk Factors” and other factors that may affect the value of the Notes. A credit rating is not a recommendation to buy, sell or hold securities and may be subject to revision, suspension or withdrawal by the rating agency at any time. No assurance can be given that a credit rating will be assigned at all, or that any credit rating will remain constant for any given period of time or that a credit rating will not be lowered or withdrawn entirely by the credit rating agency if, in its judgment, circumstances in the future so warrant. A suspension, reduction or withdrawal at any time of the credit rating assigned to the Notes by one or more of the credit rating agencies may adversely affect the cost and terms and conditions of our financings and could adversely affect the value and trading of the Notes.

Subsection Title: Risks Related to Our Financial Profile, Our Structure, the Notes and the Guarantees
Subsubsection Title: The Notes will initially be held in book-entry form, and therefore you must rely on the procedures of the relevant clearing systems to exercise any rights and remedies.
Subsubsection Text: The Notes will initially only be issued in global certificated form and held through Euroclear and Clearstream. Interests in the global Notes will trade in book-entry form only, and Notes in definitive registered form, or definitive registered Notes, will be issued in exchange for book entry interests only in very limited circumstances. Owners of the book-entry interests will not be considered owners or holders of Notes unless and until definitive notes are issued in exchange for book-entry interests. Instead, the common depositary (or its nominee) for Euroclear and Clearstream will be the sole registered holder of the Notes in global form. Payments of principal, interest and other amounts owing on or in respect of the Notes in global form will be made to the Paying Agent, which will make payments to Euroclear and Clearstream. Thereafter, such payments will be credited to participants’ accounts of Euroclear and Clearstream that hold book-entry interests in the Notes in global form and credited by such participants to indirect participants. After payment to the common depositary for Euroclear and Clearstream, none of the Issuer, the Guarantors, the Trustee, the Paying Agent, any other paying agent or any registrar will have any responsibility or liability for any aspect of the records relating to or payments of interest, principal or other amounts to Euroclear and Clearstream, or to owners of book-entry interests. Accordingly, if you own a book-entry interest in the Notes, you must rely on the procedures of Euroclear and Clearstream and, if you are not a participant in Euroclear and/or Clearstream, on the procedures of the participant through which you own your interest, to exercise any rights and obligations of a holder of the Notes under the Indenture. Owners of book-entry interests will not have the direct right to act upon our solicitations for consents or requests for waivers or other actions from holders of the Notes, including enforcement of security for the Notes and the Guarantees. Instead, if you own a book-entry interest, you will be reliant on the common depositary (as registered holder of the Notes) to act on your instructions and/or will be permitted to act directly only to the extent you have received appropriate proxies to do so from Euroclear and Clearstream or, if applicable, from a participant. We cannot assure you that procedures implemented for the granting of such proxies will be sufficient to enable you to vote on any requested actions or to take any other action on a timely basis. -----

Subsection Title: Risks Related to Our Financial Profile, Our Structure, the Notes and the Guarantees
Subsubsection Title: The Notes may not become, or remain, listed on the Official List of the Exchange.
Subsubsection Text: Although the Issuer will agree to use its commercially reasonable efforts to have the Notes listed on the Exchange and admitted to dealing on the Official List thereof and to maintain such listing as long as the Notes are outstanding, the Issuer cannot assure you that the Notes will become or remain listed. If the Issuer cannot maintain the listing on the Exchange and the admission to dealing on the Official List thereof, or if it becomes unduly burdensome to make or maintain such listing, the Issuer may cease to make or maintain such listing on the Official List of the Exchange. Although no assurance is made as to the liquidity of the Notes as a result of listing on the Official List of the Exchange or another recognized listing exchange for comparable issuers in accordance with the Indenture, failure to be approved for listing or the delisting of the Notes from the Official List of the Exchange or another listing exchange in accordance with the Indenture may have a material adverse effect on a holder’s ability to resell Notes in the secondary market.

Subsection Title: Risks Related to Our Financial Profile, Our Structure, the Notes and the Guarantees
Subsubsection Title: There may not be an active trading market for the Notes, in which case your ability to sell the Notes may be limited.
Subsubsection Text: We cannot assure you as to: - the liquidity of any market in the Notes; - your ability to sell your Notes; or - the prices at which you would be able to sell your Notes. Future trading prices for the Notes will depend on many factors, including, among others, prevailing interest rates, our operating results and the market for similar securities. Historically, the market for non-investment grade securities has been subject to disruptions that have caused substantial volatility in the prices of securities similar to the Notes. The liquidity of a trading market for the Notes may be adversely affected by a general decline in the market for similar securities and is subject to disruptions that may cause volatility in prices. The trading market for the Notes may attract different investors and this may affect the extent to which the Notes may trade. It is possible that the market for the Notes will be subject to disruptions. Any such disruption may have a negative effect on you, as a holder of the Notes, regardless of our prospects and financial performance. As a result, there is no assurance that there will be an active trading market for the Notes. If no active trading market develops, you may not be able to resell your holding of the Notes at a fair value, if at all. Although an application will be made to the Exchange for the listing of and permission to deal in the Notes on the Official List of the Exchange, we cannot assure you that the Notes will be or remain listed. Although no assurance is made as to the liquidity of the Notes as a result of the permission to deal in the Notes on the Official List of the Exchange being granted, failure to be approved for listing or the delisting (whether or not for an alternative admission to listing on another stock exchange) of the Notes, as applicable, from the Official List of the Exchange may have a material effect on a holder’s ability to resell the Notes, as applicable, in the secondary market. In addition, the Indenture allows us to issue additional notes in the future, which could adversely impact the liquidity of the Notes. See “Description of the Notes—Additional Notes.”

Subsection Title: Risks Related to Our Financial Profile, Our Structure, the Notes and the Guarantees
Subsubsection Title: The interests of the holders of the Notes and additional notes issued under the Indenture from time to time may be inconsistent.
Subsubsection Text: The Notes will be issued pursuant to a single Indenture. Subject to certain restrictions, further series of additional notes may be issued under the Indenture which may have different terms in respect of currency, interest rate and certain other matters. Accordingly, holders of such additional notes may have interests that differ from the holders of other series of notes issued under the Indenture, including the Notes. However, holders of such additional notes will generally vote as a single class with holders of other series of notes issued under the Indenture, including the Notes, with respect to amendments, waivers or other modifications of the Indenture. Accordingly, to the extent any amendment, waiver or modification is approved by the holders of a majority in aggregate principal amount of the Notes then outstanding under the Indenture (subject to the limited exceptions), all holders of Notes under the Indenture will be bound by such amendment, waiver or modification.

Subsection Title: Risks Related to Our Financial Profile, Our Structure, the Notes and the Guarantees
Subsubsection Title: Additional Notes sold pursuant to Regulation S may not be fungible with existing Notes for U.S. federal income tax purposes.
Subsubsection Text: Additional Notes sold pursuant to Regulation S from time to time may be issued with the same ISIN, Common Code, CUSIP or other securities identification number as the applicable series of notes previously issued under the Indenture without being fungible with such series of notes for U.S. federal income tax purposes. ----- If you are a U.S. holder (as defined under “Tax Considerations—Certain U.S. Federal Income Tax _Consequences”) considering the purchase of Notes sold pursuant to Regulation S as part of this offering of_ Notes or in the secondary market, you should consult your tax advisors concerning the particular U.S. federal income tax consequences to you of the purchase, ownership and disposition of such Notes, including with respect to the potential issuance of additional Notes that are not fungible with the applicable series of initial Notes issued under the Indenture for U.S. federal income tax purposes, but which, nevertheless, are not capable of being separately identified. In the event Additional Notes are issued pursuant to Regulation S that bear the same ISIN, Common Code, CUSIP or other securities identification number as Notes belonging to the same series previously issued, without being fungible with such series of initial Notes for U.S. federal income tax purposes, Book-Entry Interests in the Regulation S Global Notes that form part of that series, including in respect of investors that hold Book-Entry Interests in the Regulation S Global Notes on or prior to the date of issuance of such Additional Notes, will not be eligible for transfer to Book-Entry Interests in a Rule 144A Global Note, if any, representing Notes of that same series. Such a restriction could adversely impact the liquidity of sales of Book-Entry Interests in the Regulation S Global Notes. See “Book-Entry, Delivery and Form—Transfers” and _“Description of the Notes—Additional Notes.”_

Subsection Title: Risks Related to Our Financial Profile, Our Structure, the Notes and the Guarantees
Subsubsection Title: The transferability of the Notes may be limited under applicable securities laws.
Subsubsection Text: The Notes and the Guarantees have not been, and will not be, registered under the Securities Act or the securities laws of any state or any other jurisdiction and, unless so registered, may not be offered or sold in the United States, except pursuant to an exemption from, or in a transaction not subject to, the registration requirements of the Securities Act and the applicable securities laws of any state or any other jurisdiction. See “Transfer Restrictions.” It is the obligation of holders of the Notes to ensure that their offers and sales of the Notes within the United States and other countries comply with applicable securities laws.

Subsection Title: Risks Related to Our Financial Profile, Our Structure, the Notes and the Guarantees
Subsubsection Title: Investors may not be able to recover in civil proceedings for U.S. securities law violations.
Subsubsection Text: The Issuer and the Guarantors and their respective subsidiaries are organized outside the United States, and their business is conducted outside the United States. The directors and executive officers of the Issuer and the Guarantors are non-residents of the United States. Although the Issuer and the Guarantors will submit to the jurisdiction of certain New York courts in connection with any action under U.S. securities laws or under the Indenture, you may be unable to effect service of process within the United States on the directors and executive officers of the Issuer and the Guarantors. In addition, because the assets of the Issuer and the Guarantors and the assets of their directors and executive officers are located outside of the United States, you may be unable to enforce against them judgments obtained in U.S. courts. Moreover, in light of recent decisions of the U.S. Supreme Court, actions of the Issuer and the Guarantors may not be subject to the civil liability provisions of the federal securities laws of the United States. See “Enforcement of Civil Liabilities.”

Subsection Title: Risks Related to Our Financial Profile, Our Structure, the Notes and the Guarantees
Subsubsection Title: The Indenture will not be qualified under the TIA.
Subsubsection Text: The Indenture with respect to the Notes offered hereby is not required to be, nor will it be, qualified under the U.S. Trust Indenture Act of 1939, as amended (the “TIA”) and will not incorporate or include or be subject to any of the provisions of the TIA. Consequently, the holders of the Notes will not be entitled to the protections provided under the TIA to holders of debt securities issued under a qualified indenture, including those respecting preferential collections by the Trustee or conflicting interests of the Trustee. See “Description of the _Notes.”_

Subsection Title: Risks Related to Our Financial Profile, Our Structure, the Notes and the Guarantees
Subsubsection Title: Investors may face foreign exchange risks by investing in the Notes.
Subsubsection Text: The Notes will be denominated and payable in pound sterling. An investment in the Notes denominated in a currency other than the currency by reference to which you measure the return on your investments will entail foreign exchange related risks due to, among others, possible significant changes in the value of the pound sterling relative to other relevant currencies because of economic, political or other factors over which we have no control. Depreciation of the pound sterling against other relevant currencies could cause a decrease in the effective yield of the Notes below their stated coupon rates and could result in a loss to you when the return on the Notes is translated into the currency by reference to which you measure the return on your investments. In addition, an investment in the Notes by U.S. investors may have significant tax consequences. See “Tax Considerations—Certain U.S. Federal Income Tax Consequences.” -----

Subsection Title: Risks Related to Our Financial Profile, Our Structure, the Notes and the Guarantees
Subsubsection Title: Investors in and purchasers of the Notes may have limited or no recourse against our independent auditor.
Subsubsection Text: See “Independent Auditor” for a description of the reports of PricewaterhouseCoopers LLP (“PwC”), our independent auditor, including language limiting their scope of responsibility in relation to their audit work. Investors in and purchasers of the Notes may have limited or no recourse against PwC. Investors in and purchasers of the Notes should understand that consistent with guidance issued by the Institute of Chartered Accountants in England and Wales, PwC’s reports included elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum each states that the relevant report has been prepared for and only for the Parent’s members as a body in accordance with Chapter 3 of Part 16 of the Companies Act 2006 and for no other purpose and that PwC will does not accept responsibility or liability in respect of the report to any party save where expressly agreed by its prior consent in writing. The SEC would not permit such limiting language to be included in a registration statement or a prospectus used in connection with an offering of securities registered under the Securities Act, or in a report filed under the Exchange Act. If a U.S. court (or any other court) were to give effect to the language set out above, the recourse that investors in and purchasers of the Notes may have against PwC based on its reports or the directors’ reports and financial statements to which they relate could be limited. The extent to which PwC may have responsibility or liability to third parties can be unclear under the laws of many jurisdictions, including the United Kingdom. The inclusion of the language referred to above, however, may limit the ability of holders of the Notes to bring any action against PwC for damages arising out of an investment in or purchase of the Notes.

Subsubsection Title: The interests of our controlling shareholder may differ from the interests of the holders of the Notes.
Subsubsection Text: TDR Capital indirectly beneficially owns approximately 74% of the outstanding shares of the Parent. As a result, TDR Capital is able to control matters requiring shareholder approval, including the election and removal of our directors, our corporate and management policies, potential mergers or acquisitions, payment of dividends, asset sales and other significant corporate transactions. The interests of TDR Capital may differ from yours in material respects. For example, if we encounter financial difficulties or are unable to pay our debts as they mature, the interests of TDR Capital, as ultimate majority shareholder, may be in pursuing acquisitions, divestitures, financings or other transactions that, in their judgment, could enhance their equity investment, even though such transactions might involve risks to you as a holder of the Notes. TDR Capital has no contractual obligations to fund our business and may not have sufficient liquidity to fund our business if we require additional funding. Additionally, the Indenture permits us to pay management fees, dividends or make other restricted payments under certain circumstances, and TDR Capital may have an interest in our doing so. See “Certain Relationships and Related Party Transactions.” Furthermore, TDR Capital and their affiliates are in the business of making investments in companies and may from time to time acquire and hold interests in businesses that compete directly and indirectly with us, or with which we conduct business. TDR Capital and their affiliates may also pursue acquisition opportunities that may be complementary to our business and, as a result, those acquisition opportunities may not be available to us. You should consider that the interests of these holders may differ from yours in material respects. See “Principal Shareholders” and “Certain Relationships and Related Party Transactions.” -----

_An investment in the Notes involves a high degree of risk. You should carefully consider the following risks, together with the other information provided to you in this Offering Memorandum, in deciding whether to invest in the Notes. The occurrence of any of the events discussed below could be detrimental to our financial performance. If any of these events occur, the trading price of the Notes could decline, we may not be able to pay all or part of the interest or principal on the Notes, and you may lose all or part of your investment. Additional risks not currently known to us or which are presently deemed immaterial may also harm our business and affect your investment. This Offering Memorandum contains forward-looking statements that involve risks and uncertainties. Our actual results may differ significantly from the results discussed in such forward-looking statements. Factors that might cause such differences include those discussed below. See “Forward-looking Statements.”_

Notes offered hereby[(1)] . . . . . . . . . . . . 650 Senior Term Loan Facility[(2)] . . . . . . . . 785 Revolving Credit Facility[(3)] . . . . . . . . . — Second Lien Facility[(4)] . . . . . . . . . . . . 325

Repayment of the outstanding borrowings under the Existing Facilities[(5)] . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . 1,305 Distribution to the direct parent company of the Parent[(6)] . . . . . . . . . 400 Costs, fees and expenses[(7)] . . . . . . . . . . 55

(1) Represents the gross proceeds of the Notes expected to be issued pursuant to the Offering on the Issue Date, assuming an issuance at par. (2) Represents the £785,000,000 (equivalent) senior term loan facility (the “Senior Term Loan Facility”) made available pursuant to the Senior Facilities Agreement. See “Description of Other Financial Arrangements—Senior Facilities Agreement.” (3) Represents the £250,000,000 multi-currency revolving credit facility (the “Revolving Credit Facility”) made available pursuant to the Senior Facilities Agreement. We do not expect to borrow cash under the Revolving Credit Facility on the Issue Date but expect to utilize ancillary facilities and letters of credit under the Revolving Credit Facility for ordinary course operations. See “Description _of Other Financial Arrangements—Senior Facilities Agreement.”_ (4) Represents the £325,000,000 second lien facility (the “Second Lien Facility”) made available pursuant to the Second Lien Facility Agreement. See “Description of Other Financial Arrangements—Second Lien Facility Agreement.” (5) Represents estimated repayment in full of outstanding indebtedness and estimated accrued interest under the Existing Facilities. The outstanding principal amount comprises of borrowings of (i) £525,000,000 and €534,492,800 (which would have translated into £457,200,000, assuming an exchange rate of €1.1691 per £1.00, which represents the closing exchange rate for the 52-week period ended March 28, 2021 used in the Fiscal Year 2021 Consolidated Financial Statements) under the Existing Senior Facilities Agreement, (ii) £265,000,000 under the Existing Second Lien Facility Agreement and (iii) €67,000,000 (which would have translated into £57,300,000 assuming an exchange rate of €1.1691 per £1.00, which represents the closing exchange rate for the 52-week period ended March 28, 2021 used in the Fiscal Year 2021 Consolidated Financial Statements) under the Existing Liquidity Facility Agreement. This amount does not include borrowing of £40,000,000 under the Existing Revolving Credit Facility available pursuant to the Existing Senior Facilities Agreement, which was repaid in full subsequent to March 28, 2021. See “Capitalization.” (6) Represents a cash distribution to Constellation Automotive Group S.à r.l., the direct parent company of the Parent. See “Principal _Shareholders.”_ (7) Represents our estimate of costs, fees and expenses associated with the Refinancing Transactions, including estimated underwriting, financial advisory, legal, accounting, ratings advisory and other transaction costs (including prepayment costs) and professional fees. The actual amount of transaction fees and expenses may differ from the estimated amount depending on several factors, including differences between our estimates of costs, fees and expenses (including prepayment costs) and the actual costs, fees and expenses as of the Issue Date. -----

We intend to use the proceeds from the Offering, together with the proceeds from other Refinancing Transactions described herein, to: - repay in full the outstanding borrowings under the Existing Facilities; - make a distribution to the direct parent company of the Parent; and - pay costs, fees and expenses (including prepayment costs) incurred in connection with the Refinancing Transactions. Actual amounts are subject to adjustments and may vary from estimated amounts depending on several factors, including differences from the estimate of costs, fees and expenses (including prepayment costs), currency exchange rate movements, accrued interest and the actual amount of proceeds raised in connection with the Refinancing Transactions.

Subsection Title: As of March 28, 2021 (in £ million)** **Actual** **As Adjusted Cash and cash equivalents[(1)]** . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . **113** **113 Financial Indebtedness:

Total financial indebtedness (excluding finance leases and borrowings under the Receivables Facility)[(9)]** . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . **1,344** **1,760

Subsubsection Text: (1) Represents the amount of cash and cash equivalents as of March 28, 2021, including £15.8 million of cash held in an unrestricted subsidiary. The amount does not give effect to events or movements in cash occurring after March 28, 2021. (2) Represents indebtedness under the Existing Senior Facilities Agreement, comprising of borrowings of £525,000,000 and €534,492,800 (which translated into £457,200,000, assuming an exchange rate of €1.1691 per £1.00, which represents the closing exchange rate for the 52-week period ended March 28, 2021 used in the Fiscal Year 2021 Consolidated Financial Statements). We intend to repay in full the outstanding borrowings under the Existing Senior Term Loan Facilities with the proceeds of the Offering. See “Use of Proceeds.” (3) Represents indebtedness under the Existing Revolving Facilities Agreement, which was repaid in full subsequent to March 28, 2021. (4) Represents the indebtedness under the Existing Second Lien Facility Agreement. We intend to repay in full the outstanding borrowings under the Existing Second Lien Facility with the proceeds of the Offering. See “Use of Proceeds.” (5) Represents indebtedness under the Existing Liquidity Facility Agreement, comprising of €67,000,000 (which would have translated into £57,300,000, assuming an exchange rate of €1.1691 per £1.00, which represents the closing exchange rate for the 52-week period ended March 28, 2021 used in the Fiscal Year 2021 Consolidated Financial Statements) (the “Existing Liquidity Facility”). We intend to repay in full the outstanding borrowings under the Existing Liquidity Facility with the proceeds of the Offering. See “Use of Proceeds.” (6) Represents the face value of the £650,000,000 senior secured notes offered hereby (the “Notes”). (7) Represents indebtedness under the £785,000,000 (equivalent) senior term loan facility (the “Senior Term Loan Facility”) made available pursuant to the Senior Facilities Agreement. See “Description of Other Financial Arrangements—Senior Facilities _Agreement.” We do not expect to borrow cash under the Revolving Credit Facility on the Issue Date but expect to utilize ancillary_ facilities and letters of credit under the Revolving Credit Facility for ordinary course operations. See “Description of Other Financial _Arrangements—Senior Facilities Agreement.”_ (8) Represents indebtedness under the £325,000,000 second lien facility (the “Second Lien Facility”) made available pursuant to the Second Lien Facility Agreement. See “Description of Other Financial Arrangements—Second Lien Facility Agreement.” (9) Represents total financial indebtedness excluding (i) £148.3 million of borrowings under the Receivables Facility Agreement as of March 28, 2021, (ii) an aggregate amount of £508.6 million of finance leases as of March 28, 2021, (iii) the write-off of unamortized debt issuance costs, in relation to the repayment, cancellation and discharge of the Existing Facilities in connection with the Refinancing Transactions and (iv) estimated unamortized debt issuance costs in connection with the Notes, the Senior Term Loan Facility, the Revolving Credit Facility and the Second Lien Facility. (10) Represents (i) the actual amount of shareholders’ equity and (ii) shareholders’ equity, as adjusted to give effect to the Refinancing Transactions, including a distribution to the direct parent company of the Parent of £400 million, which does not take into account the impact of transaction costs on shareholders’ equity and the write-off of fees associated with the Existing Facilities. (11) Total capitalization comprises total financial indebtedness (excluding finance leases and borrowings under the Receivables Facility) and shareholders’ equity. -----

Subsubsection Text: _The following tables summarize certain audited and unaudited financial information as of the dates and for the periods indicated. The results of operations for prior fiscal years may not be necessarily indicative of the results to be expected for any future period. This selected historical financial consolidated financial information should be read in conjunction with the financial information included in this Offering Memorandum, including the Consolidated Financial Statements discussed in “Presentation of Financial and Other Information” and “Operating and Financial Review.” The audited financial information for the fiscal years 2021, 2020 and 2019 has been derived from (i) the audited consolidated financial statements of the Parent as of and for the 52-week period ended March 28, 2021, (ii) the audited consolidated financial statements of the Parent as of and for the 42-week period ended March 29, 2020 and (iii) the audited consolidated financial statements of BCA Marketplace as of and for the 52-week period ended March 31, 2019, respectively and included elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum. These financial statements have been prepared in accordance with the recognition and measurement requirements of IFRS. The unaudited financial information has been derived from the unaudited consolidated financial information of BCA Marketplace and its subsidiaries as of and for the 219-day period from and including April 1, 2019 to and including November 5, 2019 (together with comparative consolidated financial information as of and for the 210-day period from and including April 2, 2018 to and including October 28, 2018) and included elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum. These financial statements have been prepared in accordance with IAS 34. We have not included financial information prepared in accordance with U.S. GAAP in this Offering Memorandum. IFRS differs in certain significant respects from U.S. GAAP. In making an investment decision, you should rely upon your own examination of the terms of the Offering and the financial information contained in this Offering Memorandum. You should consult your own professional advisors for an understanding of the differences between IFRS and U.S. GAAP, and how those differences could affect the financial information contained in this Offering Memorandum._

We operate leading digital used vehicle marketplaces (both business to business (“B2B”) and consumer to business (“C2B”)) in the UK and B2B marketplaces in continental Europe and are a leading provider of associated automotive services, including vehicle movement, logistics, storage, pre-delivery inspections, fleet management, de-fleeting services and refurbishment in the UK. We have physical presence in 10 countries across the UK and continental Europe as well as unmatched sourcing, data, technology and logistics capabilities. As of March 28, 2021, our business comprises: - a leading B2B digital used vehicle marketplace across the UK and continental Europe, which facilitated the sale of approximately 1.5 million vehicles in the fiscal year 2020 and 1.2 million vehicles in the fiscal year 2021; - a leading C2B digital used vehicle marketplace in the UK, WeBuyAnyCar, with sold volumes of 321,000 vehicles and 300,000 vehicles in the fiscal years 2020 and 2021, respectively, reflecting the COVID 19 restrictions on the business that now has an annualized run rate of 461,000 vehicles (based on trading in March, April and May 2021, which was the most recent three-month period); and - a leading automotive logistics service business in the UK, which moved more than 2.8 million vehicles in the UK in the fiscal year 2020 and 2.4 million vehicles in the fiscal year 2021, and stored, refurbished and processed more than 950,000 vehicles in the fiscal year 2020 and 675,000 in the fiscal year 2021. We estimate that for the fiscal year 2020 we came in contact with approximately one in every three vehicles in the UK (approximately 29 million touch points, of which approximately 13 million were unique vehicles out of a vehicle parc of approximately 41 million, and including approximately 24 million digital touch points). Through our digital used vehicle marketplaces (the “Marketplace”), we are a critical liquidity provider to the used vehicles market across the UK and continental Europe, matching the complex requirements of both vendors and buyers and also facilitating the purchase of individual vehicles from consumers. The Marketplace facilitates speedy disposal of high volumes of vehicles and offers a broad range of consistently graded vehicle stock, thereby providing efficiency, liquidity (i.e., fast disposal of vehicle stock) and choice. Moreover, we are the UK’s leading provider of automotive services solutions. By providing a full suite of auction and automotive services, we offer our customers solutions for almost all stages of the vehicle life-cycle, beginning as soon as the new car arrives at the port. Our scope of services provides synergistic benefits across our divisions, as our vehicle sales platforms, together with our automotive services solutions, generate vehicle and pricing data used in both our vehicle remarketing and vehicle buying operations. ----- Throughout the COVID 19 pandemic, we have accelerated our digital transition and now transact digitally almost 100% of our volumes through online channels. We integrate our digital and physical assets to provide innovative multi-service solutions, maximizing speed, intelligence and performance across our comprehensive offerings. In the fiscal year 2021, 100% (2020: 37%) of our auction volumes in the UK Vehicle Remarketing division and 96% (2020: 84%) of our auction volumes in the International Vehicle Remarketing division were transacted online, which is a testament to our successful shift towards a predominantly digital online business model moving forward. In the 53-week period ended May 30, 2021, we generated £253.1 million of IAS 17 COVID Adjusted EBITDA, as compared to £232.8 million, £204.1 million and £174.4 million in the 52-week period ended March 28, 2021, the aggregated 52-week period ended March 29, 2020 and the 52-week period ended March 31, 2019, respectively. We operate through three main business lines: (i) the B2B Marketplace business line, which is comprised of our UK Vehicle Remarketing division, our International Vehicle Remarketing division and our Vehicle Buying division’s operations in continental Europe, (ii) the C2B Marketplace business line, which is WeBuyAnyCar, our Vehicle Buying division’s operations in the UK, and (iii) the Automotive Services business line, which is accounted for in our Automotive Services division. - B2B Marketplace: B2B Marketplace is our core business that facilitates the exchange of used vehicles between vendors and buyers through primarily digital auctions. As of March 28, 2021, our digital auctions are supported by 21 physical sites in the UK (23 as of June 1, 2021) and 30 physical sites in continental Europe at which vehicles are stored, inspected, repaired and refurbished. B2B Marketplace (which excludes WeBuyAnyCar) does not take title to the majority of vehicles that it sells, but instead serves as an agent between vendor and buyer and recognizes revenues through auction transaction fees as well as fees for a suite of value-added digital and physical pre- and post- auction services such as inspections, appraisals, repairs, refurbishment, imaging, storage and handling. We also purchase vehicles directly from certain corporate vendors under outsourced remarketing contracts, whereby we directly buy our vendors’ inventory and have discretion over the remarketing channel through which we sell the vehicle. B2B Marketplace takes title to such vehicles until the time of resale and recognizes revenues for the full sale value of the vehicle less the cost of acquisition. Vehicles acquired pursuant to outsourced remarketing contracts are typically resold within 15 to 30 days of acquisition and in turn generate additional revenue above the auction fees. B2B Marketplace also includes our Vehicle Buying division’s operations in continental Europe, which is focused on purchasing batches of vehicles primarily from corporates in continental Europe. In the 52-week period ended March 28, 2021, our UK Vehicle Remarketing division generated £90.5 million of IAS 17 Adjusted EBITDA (aggregated 52-week period ended March 29, 2020: £116.3 million; 52-week period ended March 31, 2019: £109.4 million). In the fiscal year 2021, our UK Vehicle Remarketing division sold approximately 867,000 vehicles (2020: 1,063,000 vehicles; 2019: 1,030,0000 vehicles). In the 52-week period ended March 28, 2021, our International Vehicle Remarketing division generated £29.2 million of IAS 17 Adjusted EBITDA (aggregated 52-week period ended March 29, 2020: £34.2 million; 52-week period ended March 31, 2019: £33.7 million). In the fiscal year 2021, our International Vehicle Remarketing division sold approximately 334,000 vehicles (2020: 401,000 vehicles; 2019: 388,000 vehicles). - C2B Marketplace: C2B Marketplace is our C2B vehicle buying business which operates in the UK through WeBuyAnyCar. WeBuyAnyCar purchases used vehicles directly from consumers, leveraging its proprietary online pricing quotation systems and efficient physical inspection processes to facilitate purchases from such consumers. WeBuyAnyCar has carried out a total of 2.2 million vehicle purchases since its inception in 2006, and in the fiscal year ended March 28, 2021, WeBuyAnyCar recorded more than 22 million unique visitors to its website and performed approximately 15.6 million valuations online. As of March 28, 2021, WeBuyAnyCar operates in 357 locations across the UK, which are located within an average drive time of under 14 minutes to customers. In addition, WeBuyAnyCar offers swift services to its consumers, allowing them to obtain a quote in under 60 seconds and to then subsequently receive monies for the purchase of their vehicle within 30 minutes of the sale being concluded. C2B Marketplace remarkets the vehicles it purchases exclusively through B2B Marketplace within approximately 10 days and accounted for 35% of the vehicles sold in the UK Vehicle Remarketing division in the 52-week period ended March 28, 2021. This allows us to actively manage the volumes and mix on the Marketplace, while helping to de-risk the supply of vehicles to the auction. ----- C2B Marketplace’s consistent and growing profitability over the past years demonstrates our ability to generate “metal margin” (accounted for in our Vehicle Buying division) on C2B vehicles in addition to core auction buyer fees (accounted for in our UK Vehicle Remarketing division). Vehicles sourced via our C2B Marketplace therefore result in higher profitability per vehicle for the CA Group. Our sophisticated and proprietary pricing mechanism and real-time market data enable us to more accurately price the purchase of vehicles to generate a profitable onward sale. In the 52-week period ended March 28, 2021, the Vehicle Buying division generated £44.0 million of IAS 17 Adjusted EBITDA (aggregated 52-week period ended March 29, 2020: £27.7 million; 52-week period ended March 31, 2019: £24.1 million), which was predominantly generated through C2B Marketplace (i.e., WeBuyAnyCar). - Automotive Services: Automotive Services provides vehicle movement, logistics, storage, pre-delivery inspections, fleet management, de-fleeting services and refurbishment in the UK. With our refurbishment offering (which has a 250,000 yearly vehicle refurbishment capacity), we are able to bring vehicles to either wholesale standard or a “Retail Ready” standard (which refers to vehicles that are cosmetically and mechanically prepared to be immediately placed for sale to end consumers and are therefore particularly attractive to online car dealers). These standards increase prices achieved at auction and render it simpler for dealers to on-sell the vehicle to consumers. We seek to develop a relationship with vendors and endeavor to act as a one-stop shop for vehicles throughout the majority of their lifecycle, expanding our revenue streams along the value chain and also positioning ourselves to be the preferred provider of remarketing services when the vehicles come off lease or roll out of the fleet. Our overall infrastructure and logistics network allow us to efficiently cover all key locations and major transport hubs in the UK. Automotive Services helps maximize the benefit of operational leverage and intragroup efficiencies derived from the wide-ranging scope of services offered, benefitting both our customers as well as our own operations. Automotive Services generates revenue in the form of service fees. In the 52-week period ended March 28, 2021, Automotive Services generated £12.5 million of IAS 17 Adjusted EBITDA (aggregated 52-week period ended March 29, 2020: £22.6 million; 52-week period ended March 31, 2019: £19.1 million).

Subsection Title: Factors Affecting Our Results of Operations
Subsubsection Text: _General Impact_ Due to the unprecedented level of disruption to society and the automotive industry, including to car dealers, leasing companies, fleet providers, original equipment manufacturers (“OEMs”), wholesale traders and private consumers, as well as our employees and the way we operate our business, interactions at the Marketplace were significantly reduced during the fiscal year 2021 with average weekly trading volume dipping to 4,000 at the start of the first quarter of the fiscal year 2021, compared to 29,000 at the start of the fourth quarter of the fiscal year 2020. The changes in operating environment spurred by the COVID 19 pandemic have accelerated our shift towards a fully digital online business model with increased focus on the functionality and usability of our digital platforms, as a result of which we were able to earn new contracts and increase our market share in spite of the challenging market conditions. The scale of the transformation is demonstrated by the fiscal year 2021 ending with 100% of UK auction sales having occurred online, compared to 37% in the fiscal year 2020. In addition to the enforced cessation of physical auctions in the UK, we faced restrictions such as site closures impacting the operation of the WeBuyAnyCar retail estate and recorded a reduction in the movement and inspection of vehicles within Automotive Services. Our customers evolved their business models, for example by motor dealers operating a click-and-collect process during 2020 to be able to better deal with social distancing restrictions and, by August 2020, average weekly trading volumes recovered to 31,000. With the continuing progress on vaccinations across European countries, and the UK in particular, as well as governments lifting restrictions to public life, we expect the demand for our services increase. The shift towards a more digital operation model has, to an extent, mitigated the impact of COVID 19 and the lifting of COVID 19 restrictions is expected to increase demand in the long term as dealers look to restock their inventory. ----- _Impact on Results of Operations_ For the unaudited aggregated 52-week period ended March 29, 2020, IAS 17 Adjusted EBITDA and IAS 17 COVID Adjusted EBITDA were £190.1 million and £204.1 million, respectively, reflecting an estimated COVID 19 impact of £14.0 million in the fiscal year 2020. For the 52-week period ended March 28, 2021, IAS 17 Adjusted EBITDA and IAS 17 COVID Adjusted EBITDA were £168.0 million and £232.8 million, respectively, reflecting an estimated COVID 19 impact of £64.8 million in the fiscal year 2021. For the 52-week period ended March 31, 2019, we reported an operating profit of £100.2 million. For the unaudited aggregated 52-week period ended March 29, 2020, we reported an operating loss of £224.5 million. For the 52-week period ended March 28, 2021, we reported an operating profit of £47.4 million. We had cash and cash equivalents of £113.2 million and £247.2 million as of March 28, 2021 and March 29, 2020, respectively. _Measures Taken in Response to the COVID 19 Pandemic_ We have been and actively continue to monitor the impact of the COVID 19 pandemic on our operations, and our priority has been the safety of our employees and other stakeholders. As governments in the jurisdictions where we operate introduced restrictions at the outset of the COVID 19 pandemic, we quickly ceased physical auctions and introduced social distancing and other modifications to our ways of working to remain compliant. In response to the closure of our physical auction sites, we adopted swift measures to significantly reduce cash outflows by reducing our operating cost and implementing cash control measures, with the aim of maximizing our liquidity position. Specifically, we adopted the following measures, which were only necessary during the time of the first lockdown in the UK during March 2020 to July 2020 and were not implemented during the subsequent second and third lockdowns: - successfully negotiated with debtors and creditors on payment terms; - put on hold all non-essential and discretionary spend within the business, including any growth, expansionary or investment capital expenditures and increased controls around the cash disbursement process, including sign off by senior members of the finance team for any payments in excess of certain reduced thresholds; - negotiated tax deferrals with HMRC in respect of VAT and employment taxes; and - entered into arrangements with landlords to defer rent payments during the period of closure and took rates relief where available. We also made furlough arrangements for those staff unable to work in the UK where we furloughed as much as 80% of our staff at the peak of the COVID 19 pandemic in April 2020 and, in parallel, applied for employee salary support schemes introduced by certain governments in continental Europe. Such schemes allow companies to place employees on paid leave or on reduced working hours, with the difference to an employee’s ordinary salary being partially reimbursed by the respective government. As of March 28, 2021, approximately 4% of our employees remained on short-term work. In the 52-week period ended March 28, 2021 furlough income across all jurisdictions totaled £35.5 million and rates relief totaled £8.3 million. As of March 28, 2021, remaining deferrals comprise VAT deferrals of £15.8 million, which are expected to be settled in full in instalments during the fiscal year 2022. As a result of the numerous cost-cutting and transitory measures taken at the beginning of the first lockdown in the UK, we came out of that lockdown with greater liquidity compared to our liquidity going into such lockdown. From the end of the first lockdown in the UK, we have managed to remain positive in terms of IAS 17 Adjusted EBITDA even in periods with government restrictions comparable with the first lockdown in the UK. Given the success of our digital offering with our clients and the level of profitability and efficiency achieved, we currently have no intention of reverting back to our previous predominantly physical auction model. _Impairment Review_ As of March 28, 2021, the intangible assets on our balance sheet totaled £1,937.9 million, including £938.5 million in goodwill relating to the CA Acquisition. While goodwill impairment is tested annually, the COVID 19 pandemic and its impact on our business constituted an impairment indicator that we assessed with respect to all intangible assets as well as goodwill. The impairment review is performed on a “value-inuse” basis, which requires estimation of future net operating cash flows, the time period over which they will occur, an appropriate discount rate and an appropriate growth rate. Any impairment charge is then recognized in the income statement for any amount by which the carrying value of goodwill exceeds its recoverable amount. As a result of our impairment review conducted as a result of the COVID 19 pandemic, we recognized an exceptional goodwill impairment relating to the CA Acquisition in the amount of £266.4 million ----- in the 42-week period ended March 29, 2020. The impairment charge thereby specifically represented a change in the timing of vehicle volumes and associated discounted cash flows, which were expected through the Marketplace over the short term as economic activity recovers. See “Risk Factors—Risks Relating to Our _Business—The COVID 19 pandemic has had, and will continue to have, a significant adverse effect on our business, operations, financial condition, operating results and liquidity, and the ultimate outcome of the COVID 19 pandemic is uncertain.” We caution you that these impairment charges should not be regarded as_ an indication, forecast or representation by us or any other person regarding impairment charges for any future period. See “Forward-looking Statements.”

Subsection Title: Factors Affecting Our Results of Operations
Subsubsection Text: Due to seasonal trends influencing both vehicle supply and demand, our revenue and operating results have varied, and likely will continue to vary, from quarter to quarter. For example, used vehicle sales in the UK tend to increase during vehicle registration plate change periods in March and September of each year. In March, in particular, new vehicle sales traditionally peak in the UK, and as a result, dealer vendors of the Vehicle Remarketing division typically experience an increase in part-exchange volumes, which has a subsequent effect of increasing sales through the Marketplace. Conversely, our revenue typically decreases during the summer and in December, a seasonality pattern that is followed by sales in both the Vehicle Buying division and the Automotive Services division. As a result of these fluctuations, our revenue tends to be lowest in the quarter ending in December and highest in the quarter ending March. In addition, there is a reduced level of activity during the Christmas and New Year holiday period.

Subsection Title: Factors Affecting Our Results of Operations
Subsubsection Text: We report our results in pound sterling, and pound sterling is also the functional currency of our UK operations. However, we conduct operations in the UK and continental Europe, as a result of which approximately 11% of our revenue in the fiscal year 2021 was denominated in currencies other than pound sterling, with the significant majority of this denominated in euro. We also conduct a limited number of transactions in a small number of other currencies. Exchange rates between the pound sterling and the euro have ranged from €1.1605 per pound sterling on March 31, 2019 to €1.1176 per pound sterling on March 29, 2020 and €1.1691 per pound sterling on March 28, 2021. Typically, our costs in a currency other than the pound sterling are matched by corresponding revenue in that same currency. Our results of operations may nevertheless be affected by the translation effects of foreign currency exchange rate fluctuations on converting the results of these operations reported in currencies other than the pound sterling to sterling for group consolidation.

Subsection Title: Factors Affecting Our Results of Operations
Subsubsection Text: The COVID 19 pandemic has had and will continue to have a significant impact on our results of operations. In addition, our revenue and profits are largely dependent on the supply of vehicles to the Vehicle Remarketing and Vehicle Buying divisions, the demand for vehicles sold by the Vehicle Remarketing divisions and the availability of vehicles which require services provided by the Automotive Services division. Our results of operations are further impacted by our acquisitions, seasonality and currency translation. Below is a detailed discussion of each of these factors affecting our results of operations.

Our fiscal year accounting periods typically run from the calendar day following the previous fiscal year end to a Sunday within seven days of March 31. For the fiscal years 2021, 2020 and 2019, the relevant Sundays were March 28, 2021, March 29, 2020 and March 31, 2019. While the Fiscal Year 2021 Consolidated Financial Statements and the Fiscal Year 2019 Consolidated Financial Statements comprise the 52-week period ended March 28, 2021 (from and including March 30, 2020 to and including March 28, 2021) and the 52-week period ended March 31, 2019 (from and including April 2, 2018 to and including March 31, 2019), respectively, the Fiscal Year 2020 Consolidated Financial Statements only comprise the 42-week period ended March 29, 2020 (from and including June 10, 2019 to and including March 29, 2020). As such, the Fiscal Year 2020 Consolidated Financial Statements are not comparable to the other Consolidated Financial Statements since they only cover the 42-week period ended March 29, 2020, representing the period from the incorporation date of the Parent on June 10, 2019. In addition, due to the CA Acquisition, which completed on November 6, 2019, the Fiscal Year 2020 Consolidated Financial Statements do not reflect our trading results during the period from April 1, 2019 to November 5, 2019. Below is an overview of the trading history covered by the Consolidated Financial Statements. - The Fiscal Year 2019 Consolidated Financial Statements reflect the results of operations of BCA Marketplace and its subsidiaries from and including April 2, 2018 to and including March 31, 2019. Accordingly, the Fiscal Year 2019 Consolidated Financial Statements represent 52 weeks of trading, reflecting our results of operations prior to the CA Acquisition. ----- - The Fiscal Year 2020 Consolidated Financial Statements reflect the results of operations of the Parent and Constellation Automotive (which were incorporated for the purpose of facilitating the CA Acquisition and, as such, are holding companies with no operations and no assets other than the shares held) from and including the date of incorporation of the Parent on June 10, 2019 to and including March 29, 2020. During the period from June 10, 2019 to the completion date of the CA Acquisition on November 6, 2019, the Parent had no activities and had very limited financial results to report. Following the consummation of the CA Acquisition on November 6, 2019, our financial results are consolidated at the Parent level. Accordingly, the Fiscal Year 2020 Consolidated Financial Statements represent 145 days of trading, reflecting our results of operations after the CA Acquisition. - The Fiscal Year 2021 Consolidated Financial Statements reflect the results of operations of the Parent group from and including March 30, 2020 to and including March 28, 2021. Accordingly, the Fiscal Year 2021 Consolidated Financial Statements represent 52 weeks of trading.

During the fiscal year 2020, we incurred certain start-up costs with respect to cinch, which was sold to an affiliate of a parent company of the Parent in September 2020. Accordingly, the financial information included in this Offering Memorandum, including the Consolidated Financial Statements, the 2020 Predecessor Financial Statements and the Fiscal Year 2020 Aggregated Financial Information, may not be comparable insofar as they relate to cinch across these periods.

IFRS 16 (Leases) became effective on January 1, 2019 and applies to the first full fiscal year commencing on or after that date. Accordingly, we have applied IFRS 16 since the fiscal year 2020. We have adopted IFRS 16 under the modified retrospective approach on April 1, 2019, with the cumulative effect of applying IFRS 16 recognized on adoption as an adjustment to opening equity. Under this approach, comparative information for the 52-week period ended March 31, 2019 is not restated and, as a result, no IFRS 16 adjustments have been made to the Fiscal Year 2019 Consolidated Financial Statements. Accordingly, the financial information included in this Offering Memorandum, including the Consolidated Financial Statements, the 2020 Predecessor Financial Statements and the Fiscal Year 2020 Aggregated Financial Information, may not be comparable insofar as they relate to the application of IFRS 16 (Leases). Following the CA Acquisition, a purchase price allocation exercise was undertaken in order to identify the fair value of the assets and liabilities acquired thereunder, in line with IFRS 3 (Business Combinations). IFRS 3 requires the revaluation of IFRS 16 right of use assets and lease liabilities using a revised incremental borrowing rate (“IBR”). The IBR we used for these purposes increased significantly following the CA Acquisition as a result of the indebtedness incurred in connection therewith. Due to the significant change in IBR used for the valuation of right of use assets and lease liabilities resulting from the CA Acquisition, the full year IFRS 16 depreciation and interest included in our Fiscal Year 2020 Aggregated Financial Information represents the aggregation of (i) the pre-CA Acquisition IFRS 16 depreciation and interest calculated with reference to the original, pre-CA Acquisition IBR and (ii) the post-CA Acquisition IFRS 16 depreciation and interest calculated with reference to the revised, post-CA Acquisition IBR. Accordingly, the financial information included in this Offering Memorandum, including the Consolidated Financial Statements, the 2020 Predecessor Financial Statements and the Fiscal Year 2020 Aggregated Financial Information, may not be comparable.

Subsection Title: Description of Key Income Statement Line Items
Subsubsection Text: Revenue consists of revenue attributable to the Vehicle Remarketing division, the Vehicle Buying division and the Automotive Services division. Revenue from the Vehicle Remarketing division predominantly represents transaction fees earned from vehicles sold, as well as revenue from value-added services. This also includes the proceeds from the sale of some vehicles sold under outsourced remarketing contracts where we obtain control and take legal title to certain vehicles, and interest and loan origination fees earned in respect of vehicle finance. Revenue from the Vehicle Buying division comprises the proceeds from the sale through the Vehicle Remarketing division of vehicles purchased from members of the public as well as expedited payment fees. Revenue from the Automotive Services division comprises fees charged in relation to automotive transport, refurbishment, storage and fulfilment services. -----

Subsection Title: Description of Key Income Statement Line Items
Subsubsection Text: Cost of sales for the Vehicle Remarketing division primarily comprises the costs of providing auction related services and includes the cost of the vehicle purchased, where we take control and legal title. For the Vehicle Buying division, cost of sales primarily comprises the cost of the vehicle purchased, as well as the labor and site costs of the purchasing locations and labor costs of the disposals team, net of transaction fees charged on each vehicle purchased. Costs of sales for the Automotive Services division primarily comprises the costs incurred in providing services to customers, including labor, equipment and parts.

Subsection Title: Description of Key Income Statement Line Items
Subsubsection Text: Operating costs consists of all costs included in operating profit that are not included in cost of sales.

Subsection Title: Description of Key Income Statement Line Items
Subsubsection Text: Finance income comprises interest receivable on funds invested and foreign exchange gains on finance balances.

Subsection Title: Description of Key Income Statement Line Items
Subsubsection Text: Finance costs comprise interest payable on borrowings, direct transaction costs, unwinding of the discount on provisions and lease liabilities, net interest cost of defined benefit pension arrangements and foreign exchange losses on finance balances.

Subsection Title: Description of Key Income Statement Line Items
Subsubsection Title: Share of Loss of Equity-accounted Investments
Subsubsection Text: Share of loss of equity-accounted investments comprises our losses in relation to our share of profits or losses from entities where we have significant influence but not control or joint control, which is generally the case where we hold between 20% and 50% of the voting rights.

Subsection Title: Description of Key Income Statement Line Items
Subsubsection Text: Income tax (charge)/benefit is based on the profit/(loss) before income tax for the period and takes into account taxation deferred because of timing differences between the treatment of certain items for taxation and accounting purposes. Deferred tax is recognized, without discounting, in respect of all timing differences between the treatment of certain items for taxation and accounting purposes which have arisen but not been reversed by the balance sheet date, except as otherwise required by IAS 12 (Income Taxes), for example tax losses where there is no expectation those losses can be utilized.

Subsubsection Title: 42-week Period Ended March 29, 2020 Compared to 52-week Period Ended March 31, 2019
Subsubsection Text: The table below sets forth certain line items from our income statement for the 42-week period ended March 29, 2020 compared to the 52-week period ended March 31, 2019.

_Revenue_ Revenue increased by £1,993.4 million from £1,460.6 million for the 42-week period ended March 29, 2020 to £3,454.0 million for the 52-week period ended March 28, 2021, primarily as a result of the longer trading period captured in the results for the 52-week period ended March 28, 2021 (i.e., 52 weeks) compared to the 42-week period ended March 29, 2020 (i.e., 145 days) as a result of the CA Acquisition. Revenue in the UK Vehicle Remarketing division (excluding inter-division revenue) increased by £762.9 million, from £546.0 million for the 42-week period ended March 29, 2020 to £1,308.9 million for the 52-week period ended March 28, 2021. Revenue in the International Vehicle Remarketing division (excluding inter-division revenue) increased by £111.3 million, from £78.8 million for the 42-week period ended March 29, 2020 to £190.1 million for the 52-week period ended March 28, 2021. Revenue in the Vehicle Buying division (excluding interdivision revenue) increased by £982.9 million, from £682.4 million for the 42-week period ended March 29, 2020 to £1,665.3 million for the 52-week period ended March 28, 2021. Revenue in the Automotive Services division (excluding inter-division revenue) increased by £135.2 million, or 88.2%, from £153.3 million for the 42-week period ended March 29, 2020 to £288.5 million for the 52-week period ended March 28, 2021. Each of these increases was primarily due to the longer trading period in the fiscal year 2021 compared to the fiscal year 2020 as described above as a result of the CA Acquisition. In addition, while revenue was heavily ----- impacted by the COVID 19 pandemic with various levels of regional and national restrictions in the UK and our continental European locations, we have only seen a marginal impact on revenue from the COVID 19 pandemic during the fiscal year 2020. _Cost of Sales_ Cost of sales increased by £1,747.1 million, from £1,260.7 million for the 42-week period ended March 29, 2020 to £3,007.8 million for the 52-week period ended March 28, 2021. This increase was primarily due to the longer trading period in the fiscal year 2021 compared to the fiscal year 2020 as described above as a result of the CA Acquisition. _Operating Costs_ Operating costs decreased by £94.3 million, or 19.1%, from £493.1 million for the 42-week period ended March 29, 2020 to £398.8 million for the 52-week period ended March 28, 2021. This decrease was primarily due to a significant goodwill impairment in the 42-week period ended March 29, 2020, offset by the longer trading period in the fiscal year 2021 compared to the fiscal year 2020 as described above as a result of the CA Acquisition. _Finance Income_ Finance income increased by £22.6 million, from £0.4 million for the 42-week period ended March 29, 2020 to £23.0 million for the 52-week period ended March 28, 2021. This increase was primarily due to foreign exchange profit primarily recognized on retranslation of euro-denominated indebtedness. _Finance Costs_ Finance costs increased by £44.5 million, or 75.6%, from £58.9 million for the 42-week period ended March 29, 2020 to £103.4 million for the 52-week period ended March 28, 2021. This increase was primarily due to the longer trading period in the fiscal year 2021 compared to the fiscal year 2020 as described above as a result of the CA Acquisition and the post-CA Acquisition financing structure. _Share of Loss of Equity-accounted Investments_ Share of loss of equity-accounted investments increased by £1.2 million, from £0.1 million for the 42-week period ended March 29, 2020 to £1.3 million for the 52-week period ended March 28, 2021. This increase was primarily due to the underlying trading performance of the relevant investments. _Income Tax Charge_ Income tax charge decreased by £30.3 million, from a tax charge of £16.7 million and an effective tax rate of (4.7%) for the 42-week period ended March 29, 2020 to a tax credit of £13.6 million and an effective tax rate of 39.6% for the 52-week period ended March 28, 2021. The changes are primarily due to the underlying profit before tax in the respective periods. In addition: - Fiscal Year 2020: The £16.7 million tax charge, on a loss before tax of £351.8 million, arose predominantly as a result of: (i) the net non-deductible impairment of goodwill of £50.6 million; (ii) net non-deductible costs associated with the CA Acquisition of £10.0 million; (iii) an increase in the UK tax rate on our deferred tax assets of £17.6 million; and (iv) a net non-deductible foreign exchange movement of £4.6 million, which collectively increased the tax charge for the period when compared to the profit before tax at the UK statutory tax rate. Excluding the effect of these items would give an effective tax rate of 21.4% for the period. - Fiscal Year 2021: The £13.6 million tax credit, on a loss before tax of £34.3 million, arose predominantly as a result of: (i) a net non-taxable foreign exchange movement of £4.0 million and £3.8 million from the payment for group relief for less than 19.0% which increased the tax credit for the period. Excluding the effect of these items would give an effective tax rate of 13.4% for the period. _Reported Adjusted EBITDA_ Reported Adjusted EBITDA increased by £125.7 million from £89.1 million for the 42-week period ended March 29, 2020 to £214.8 million for the 52-week period ended March 28, 2021. This increase was primarily ----- as a result of the shorter trading period captured in the results for the 42-week period ended March 29, 2020 (i.e., 145 days) compared to the 52-week period ended March 28, 2021 (i.e., 52 weeks) as a result of the CA Acquisition. _IAS 17 COVID Adjusted EBITDA_ IAS 17 COVID Adjusted EBITDA increased by £145.6 million from £87.2 million for the 42-week period ended March 29, 2020, 2019 to £232.8 million for the 52-week period ended March 28, 2021. This increase was primarily as a result of the shorter trading period captured in the results for the 42-week period ended March 29, 2020 (i.e., 145 days) compared to the 52-week period ended March 28, 2021 (i.e., 52 weeks) as a result of the CA Acquisition and underlying business growth.

Subsubsection Title: 219-day Period Ended November 5, 2019 Compared to 210-day Period Ended October 28, 2018
Subsubsection Text: The table below sets forth certain line items from our income statement for the 219-day period ended November 5, 2019 compared to the 210-day period ended October 28, 2018.

----- _Revenue_ Revenue decreased by £1,567.4 million, or 51.8%, from £3,028.0 million for the 52-week period ended March 31, 2019 to £1,460.6 million for the 42-week period ended March 29, 2020, primarily as a result of the shorter trading period captured in the results for the 42-week period ended March 29, 2020 (i.e., 145 days) compared to the 52-week period ended March 31, 2019 (i.e., 52 weeks) as a result of the CA Acquisition. Revenue in the UK Vehicle Remarketing division (excluding inter-division revenue) decreased by £696.5 million, or 56.1%, from £1,242.5 million for the 52-week period ended March 31, 2019 to £546.0 million for the 42-week period ended March 29, 2020. Revenue in the International Vehicle Remarketing division (excluding inter-division revenue) decreased by £105.5 million, or 57.2%, from £184.3 million for the 52-week period ended March 31, 2019 to £78.8 million for the 42-week period ended March 29, 2020. Revenue in the Vehicle Buying division (excluding inter-division revenue) decreased by £537.4 million, or 44.1%, from £1,219.8 million for the 52-week period ended March 31, 2019 to £682.4 million for the 42-week period ended March 29, 2020. Revenue in the Automotive Services division (excluding inter-division revenue) decreased by £228.1 million, or 59.8%, from £381.4 million for the 52-week period ended March 31, 2019 to £153.3 million for the 42-week period ended March 29, 2020. Each of these decreases was primarily due to the shorter trading period in the fiscal year 2020 compared to the fiscal year 2019 as described above as a result of the CA Acquisition. _Cost of Sales_ Cost of sales decreased by £1,293.4 million, or 50.6%, from £2,554.1 million for the 52-week period ended March 31, 2019 to £1,260.7 million for the 42-week period ended March 29, 2020. This decrease was primarily due to the shorter trading period in the fiscal year 2020 compared to the fiscal year 2019 as described above as a result of the CA Acquisition. _Operating Costs_ Operating costs increased by £119.4 million, or 32.0%, from £373.7 million for the 52-week period ended March 31, 2019 to £493.1 million for the 42-week period ended March 29, 2020. This increase was primarily due to the shorter trading period in the fiscal year 2020 compared to the fiscal year 2019 as described above as a result of the CA Acquisition and a significant goodwill impairment in the 42-week period ended March 29, 2020 relating to the COVID 19 pandemic. _Finance Income_ Finance income decreased by £0.1 million, or 20.0%, from £0.5 million for the 52-week period ended March 31, 2019 to £0.4 million for the 42-week period ended March 29, 2020. _Finance Costs_ Finance costs increased by £47.7 million from £11.2 million for the 52-week period ended March 31, 2019 to £58.9 million for the 42-week period ended March 29, 2020. This increase was primarily due to the post-CA Acquisition financing structure and the recognition of IFRS 16 interest costs. _Share of Loss of Equity-accounted Investments_ Share of loss of equity-accounted investments was £0.1 million for the 42-week period ended March 29, 2020. No share of loss of equity-accounted investments was recorded in the 52-week period ended March 31, 2019. _Income Tax Charge_ Income tax charge decreased by £4.2 million, from a tax charge of £20.9 million and an effective tax rate of 23.4% for the 52-week period ended March 31, 2019 to a tax charge of £16.7 million and an effective tax rate of (4.7%) for the 42-week period ended March 29, 2020. The changes are primarily due to the underlying profit before tax in the respective periods. In addition: - Fiscal Year 2020: The £16.7 million tax charge, on a loss before tax of £351.8 million, arose predominantly as a result of: (i) the net non-deductible impairment of goodwill of £50.6 million; (ii) net non-deductible costs associated with the CA Acquisition of £10.0 million; (iii) an increase in the UK tax rate on our deferred tax assets of £17.6 million; and (iv) a net non-deductible foreign exchange movement of £4.6 million, which collectively increased the tax charge for the period when compared to the profit before ----- tax at the UK statutory tax rate. Excluding the effect of these items would give an effective tax rate of 21.4% for the period. - Fiscal Year 2019: Our parent entity was a listed company and the financing structure and costs relating to significant or non-recurring items was substantially different to the period post the CA Acquisition. The effective tax rate of 23.4% therefore reflects these structural differences and the differences in tax rates in the jurisdictions in which we operate. _Reported Adjusted EBITDA_ Reported Adjusted EBITDA decreased by £82.8 million, or 48.2%, from £171.9 million for the 52-week period ended March 31, 2019 to £89.1 million for the 42-week period ended March 29, 2020. This decrease was primarily as a result of the shorter trading period captured in the results for the 42-week period ended March 29, 2020 (i.e., 145 days) compared to the 52-week period ended March 31, 2019 (i.e., 52 weeks) as a result of the CA Acquisition. _IAS 17 COVID Adjusted EBITDA_ IAS 17 COVID Adjusted EBITDA decreased by £87.2 million, or 50.0%, from £174.4 million for the 52-week period ended March 31, 2019 to £87.2 million for the 42-week period ended March 29, 2020. This decrease was primarily as a result of the shorter trading period captured in the results for the 42-week period ended March 29, 2020 (i.e., 145 days) compared to the 52-week period ended March 31, 2019 (i.e., 52 weeks) as a result of the CA Acquisition.
