Subsubsection Title: Fiscal Year 2021 compared to Unaudited Aggregated 52-week Period ended March 29, 2020
Subsubsection Text: Revenue decreased by £50.6 million from £3,504.6 million for the unaudited aggregated 52-week period ended March 29, 2020 to £3,454.0 million for the 52-week period ended March 28, 2021. IAS 17 Adjusted EBITDA decreased by £22.1 million from £190.1 million for the unaudited aggregated 52-week period ended March 29, 2020 to £168.0 million for the 52-week period ended March 28, 2021. IAS 17 COVID Adjusted EBITDA increased by £28.7 million from £204.1 million for the unaudited aggregated 52-week period ended March 29, 2020 to £232.8 million for the 52-week period ended March 28, 2021. We commenced the fiscal year 2021 with all markets operating under varying national government restrictions in response to the COVID 19 pandemic. Swift actions were taken to reduce costs and preserve cash, including furloughing a significant number of employees and utilizing government initiatives to support employment costs for employees who were not able to contribute to the ongoing operation of the business. Management also negotiated with landlords to reduce or defer rental payments and temporarily ceased all consumer vehicle buying activity. Physical auctions and the WeBuyAnyCar retail estate closed with a resulting reduction in the movement and inspection of vehicles within Automotive Services. During April 2021, all auctions took place on our online platforms initially populated with vehicles that had been imaged and graded before lockdown. At commencement of the restrictions, demand was greatest for vehicles at lower price points. Over 90% of the transporter fleet was taken off the road, with the remaining vehicle moves taking place to support key workers and provide services to organizations which were not able to cease operations, including for example the transportation of ambulances for the NHS. Vehicles continued to arrive into the UK by ship, and these vehicles were received and stored in line with working regulations. Trading was similarly impacted across continental Europe with differing lockdown restrictions impacting sales and cross-border movements. The magnitude of the COVID 19 impact on economic activity practically mitigated any post-Brexit trading impact on the business. As European countries began to ease restrictions and the UK government announced that car dealerships could reopen from June 1, 2020, we saw demand increase across our online platforms and were able to recommission our transport capabilities to support the vehicle logistics of vendors and buyers. Trading rebounded in the second quarter of the fiscal year 2021 as restrictions were lifted and the workforce largely returned from furlough. Strong stable pricing provided good operational efficiencies with predictable results for buyers and sellers. Refreshed versions of BCA Live Online and the BCA Buyer mobile application provide enhanced insight every time a buyer looks at, bids on or buys a vehicle. We were well placed to capitalize on pent-up demand with all UK auctions fully digital, utilizing BCA Live Online and the BCA Buyer mobile application. At the end of the second quarter of the fiscal year 2021, we launched the “Retail Ready” digital sales channel exclusively for trade customers to meet demand for high quality vehicles and to shorten inventory holding times. The channel offers vehicles prepared cosmetically and mechanically to a new industry retail standard allowing dealers to immediately place these vehicles onto their forecourt with little or no preparation and cost. ----- The momentum continued into the third quarter of the fiscal year 2021 despite ongoing restrictions across continental Europe and the introduction of tiered restrictions in the UK. Customers continued to develop their online as well as click and collect capabilities in order to continue trading at scale in this environment. It was not until the return of a stricter lockdown in the UK that spanned the whole of the fourth quarter of the fiscal year 2021 that activity was again significantly suppressed. The impact on trading was far less than in the first quarter of the fiscal year 2021, reflecting the adaptability and resilience of the used car sector and the incremental developments to our digital capability. The end of the Brexit transition period on December 31, 2020 provided limited disruption in comparison to the impact of COVID 19 restrictions. _Divisional Review_ UK Vehicle Remarketing The division generated revenue of £1,308.9 million and IAS 17 Adjusted EBITDA of £90.5 million for the 52-week period ended March 28, 2021 compared to £1,377.1 million and £116.3 million for the unaudited aggregated 52-week period ended March 29, 2020. The division’s volumes, revenues and Reported Adjusted EBITDA were adversely impacted by the COVID 19 pandemic restrictions during the fiscal year 2021. Our revenues are impacted by the mix of vehicles for which we take title, whereby the full auction price of vehicles sold is recognized as revenue, and those where we serve as an agent between vendor and buyer, for which revenues are recognized in relation to auction fees as well as fees for a suite of value-added digital and physical pre- and post- auction services. To enable vendors and buyers to continue to trade with confidence, UK Vehicle Remarketing accelerated its digital transformation, trading fully online during the 52-week period ended March 28, 2021 (2020: 37%). After the temporary cessation of physical auctions at the end of the fiscal year 2020, the division commenced first quarter trading using its existing online auction platforms, including BCA Buyer mobile application, BCA Live Online and BCA Buy Now with vehicles that had been imaged and prepared prior to the implementation of pandemic restrictions. Working practices were revised through April 2020 and May 2020, so vendor vehicles could be received and processed in line with working regulations. When automotive dealerships were allowed to reopen on June 1, 2020, the division saw strong demand and stable pricing which continued into the third quarter of the fiscal year 2021, with record sales volumes in September 2020 of over 25,000 units per week for four consecutive weeks. September 2020 saw the introduction of our “Retail Ready”sales channel. Utilizing our expertise in wholesale vehicle storage and refurbishment has enabled the division to introduce and define “Retail Ready” as a new vehicle condition standard. This digital channel hosts vehicles prepared cosmetically and mechanically, covering the repair of bodywork dents, stone chips, paint repairs, wheels, glass and lights, interior upholstery, and tire condition and compatibility checks. Once refurbished, the vehicles are fully retail valeted and come with a valid service for at least three months or 2,000 miles, a valid Ministry of Transport (MOT) certificate for at least 6 months and all auxiliary items such as Satellite Navigation SD cards and charging cables present. This enables customers to immediately place these vehicles onto their forecourt with no preparation time and cost required. The business has undergone significant changes to sales day operations, and during the third quarter of the fiscal year 2021, the UK Vehicle Remarketing division reorganized the workforce, resulting in redundancies of certain branch based roles. The tiered restrictions in the UK during November 2020 and December 2020, and the full lockdown across the UK in the fourth quarter of the fiscal year 2021 did not impact the business as severely as the initial lockdown as our customers had evolved their ability to operate with social distancing and other restrictions in place. Outsourced remarketing contract volumes have been impacted, reflecting reduced lease churn and de-fleet activity throughout the fiscal year 2021. BCA Partner Finance continues to support buyer demand in our marketplace with penetration at 10.6% of UK Vehicle Remarketing sales funded by BCA Partner Finance (2020: 12.7%). The reduction in penetration has been due to dealers taking a more conservative position on their volumes and also the level of government support that has been available throughout the fiscal year 2021. International Vehicle Remarketing The division generated revenue of £190.1 million and IAS 17 Adjusted EBITDA of £29.2 million for the 52-week period ended March 28, 2021 compared to £201.0 million and £34.2 million for the unaudited ----- aggregated 52-week period ended March 29, 2020. Availability of volumes was suppressed across Europe as leasing companies and OEMs experienced delays in the return of financed vehicles and there was reduced availability of new vehicles following COVID 19 disruptions. This was partially offset by some additional international cross border buying activity undertaken in response to the various levels of supply and demand seen across different markets, supported by our transport network of accredited partners. Average profitability per vehicle increased driven by changes in country mix, in part reflecting the differing impacts of COVID 19 restrictions and increased export fee penetration. In June 2020, the International Vehicle Remarketing division commissioned its first automated inspection units in continental Europe, and at the end of the fiscal year 2021 were operating a number of automated units in Denmark, France and the Netherlands. These drive-through units assess vehicle condition, reducing the need for manual inspection and ensuring a consistent and accurate assessment. The division also established a new vehicle reconditioning center in France in partnership with Emil Frey, which began operation in August 2020. This facility offers refurbishment and grade enhancement to our vendors, maximizing sales performance at auction. Towards the end of the fourth quarter of the fiscal year 2021, the division experienced renewed restrictions in some of the markets in which it operates across Europe as national governments address increased COVID19 infection levels. Vehicle Buying The division generated revenue of £1,665.3 million and IAS 17 Adjusted EBITDA of £44.0 million for the 52-week period ended March 28, 2021 compared to £1,529.8 million and £27.7 million for the unaudited aggregated 52-week period ended March 29, 2020. WeBuyAnyCar continues to maintain its place as a market leading C2B business in the UK online direct car buying market. Revenue and IAS 17 Adjusted EBITDA increased period-on-period driven by higher revenue per units sold partially offset by lower annual volume sold. Despite the significant disruption to the division’s retail estate during the fiscal year 2021, with long periods of enforced closure, the buying network continued to expand in order to provide convenience for consumers ending the year with 357 sites (2020: 315). Vehicles are sold from sites across the UK Vehicle Remarketing estate and now include three WeBuyAnyCar dedicated selling centers. The division supplies a controlled and diverse range of vehicles across all makes and marques, to support the UK Vehicle Remarketing division auction sales program. During the fiscal year 2021, WeBuyAnyCar delivered a new record volume week and purchased its 2 millionth vehicle 15 years after commencing trading and only four years after achieving the 1 millionth vehicle milestone. This accelerated volume is underpinned by the continued growth in brand recognition and consumer trust from the public. Our Christmas Day TV advertising campaign was met with strong consumer interest, with record festive period website visits. As the brand builds the division is expanding the marketing and advertising channels across digital platforms (Facebook, YouTube, etc.) to broaden engagement with a wider audience. The move to 100% online auctions in the UK Vehicle Remarketing division, and the development of three dedicated selling hubs means we are better able to track and analyze customer demand and ensure we are servicing it appropriately. Inventory at March 28, 2021 was £107.0 million (March 29, 2020: £44.2 million), reflecting the continued growth in the business compared with a period of inventory reduction in the prior year as COVID 19 restrictions came into place. Within continental Europe, Vehicle Buying has increased 17.4% on prior year as we have improved our market intelligence enabling us to better identify vehicle demand. We continue to focus on opportunities to raise awareness of auction, purchasing batches of vehicles that enrich the remarketing programs for both vendors and buyers. Automotive Services The division generated revenue of £288.5 million and IAS 17 Adjusted EBITDA of £12.5 million for the 52-week period ended March 28, 2021 compared to £396.6 million and £22.6 million for the unaudited aggregated 52-week period ended March 29, 2020. During the fiscal year 2021, the division was adversely impacted by the COVID 19 restrictions in the UK, with the majority of vehicle movements restricted, most of the fleet off the road and employees furloughed. The division did maintain some activity during COVID 19 restrictions, especially supporting key workers and the emergency services, including through the movement of ambulances for the NHS. ----- Government initiatives were used to support employment costs, and rent deferrals were negotiated with landlords and finance companies. Activity began to recommence in June 2020, following the easing of restrictions and reopening of car dealerships, with all business areas returning to profitability and delivering higher margin work that could not be performed earlier in the first quarter of the fiscal year 2021. The division continued to increase the penetration of internal moves and refurbishments for UK Vehicle Remarketing, utilizing an increased transporter fleet following the strategic acquisition of used transporters from some smaller distressed operators, driving increased internal efficiency and reduced costs. Logistics continued to see strong demand from leasing companies for inspections and collections following easing of lockdown restrictions, and vehicle flow efficiency returned to our Fleet Solutions and Vehicle Services sites as dispatches to customers returned to normal levels post-lockdown. During the fiscal year 2021, Fleet Solutions utilized the capability and expertise developed in preparing and refurbishing fleet vehicles to establish and support the newly developed “Retail Ready” industry vehicle standard. In order to support “Retail Ready,”we announced the development of the new 65-acre mega-center in Bristol. Leveraging our strong and well established integrated capability has enabled the division to accelerate the delivery of “Retail Ready” vehicles to support the new sales channel.

Subsubsection Title: Unaudited Aggregated 52-week Period ended March 29, 2020 compared to Fiscal Year 2019
Subsubsection Text: Revenue increased by £476.6 million from £3,028.0 million for the 52-week period ended March 31, 2019 to £3,504.6 million for the unaudited aggregated 52-week period ended March 29, 2020. IAS 17 Adjusted EBITDA increased by £15.7 million from £174.4 million for the 52-week period ended March 31, 2019 to £190.1 million for the unaudited aggregated 52-week period ended March 29, 2020. IAS 17 COVID Adjusted EBITDA increased by £29.7 million from £174.4 million for the 52-week period ended March 31, 2019 to £204.1 million for the unaudited aggregated 52-week period ended March 29, 2020. The period-on-period growth in revenue, IAS 17 Adjusted EBITDA and IAS 17 COVID Adjusted EBITDA has been driven by increased sales of vehicles by the Vehicle Buying division and strong performance in outsourced remarketing contracts (where we typically account for the full vehicle value within revenue), which continued to deliver growth in vehicle sold volumes. Increased sales, control over variable operating costs and overhead efficiency from greater volume throughput contributed to IAS 17 Adjusted EBITDA growth. This strong trading performance has been delivered despite the disruption to trading during the latter half of March 2020 and after taking into account additional provisions against vehicle values as a result of COVID 19. During March 2020, national governments across Europe responded to the COVID 19 pandemic and implemented restrictions including social distancing lockdown arrangements, resulting in a cessation of physical auctions, the closure of the WeBuyAnyCar retail estate and a significant reduction in the movement and inspection of vehicles within Automotive Services. This had a significant impact on financial performance during March 2020, as a large element of our operating costs relate to payroll, property and transporter leases. Given the speed at which restrictions were imposed, it was not possible to reduce costs at the same rate as the reduction in operating activity. We furloughed over 80% of employees, and utilized government initiatives across Europe to support employment costs, retail premises rents and business rates. Management negotiated with landlords to reduce or defer rental payments, to maximize liquidity throughout the restrictions. At the end of the fiscal year 2020, management recognized an exceptional COVID 19 related goodwill impairment. This reflected the impact of the time value of money on earnings and growth, following the suppression of our operational activities as a result of the COVID 19 pandemic. _Divisional Review_ UK Vehicle Remarketing The division generated revenue of £1,377.1 million and IAS 17 Adjusted EBITDA of £116.3 million for the unaudited aggregated 52-week period ended March 29, 2020 compared to £1,242.5 million and £109.4 million for the 52-week period ended March 31, 2019, respectively. The division traded strongly during the fiscal year 2020 despite the impact of the temporary cessation of physical auctions in March 2020 as a result of government restrictions in response to the COVID 19 pandemic. Revenue increased as a result of increased volumes including an extended sales program during the Christmas period. Auction activity throughout the fiscal year 2020 was driven by strong volumes from the Vehicle Buying division (WeBuyAnyCar) and outsourced remarketing contracts. This was supported by BCA Partner Finance penetration, which continues to increase. The BCA Partner Finance proposition, which includes branded auctions, part-exchange financing ----- and funding 100% of the hammer price plus fees and transport of purchases, continues to support dealer customers through the liquidity it provides. International Vehicle Remarketing The division generated revenue of £201.0 million and IAS 17 Adjusted EBITDA of £34.2 million for the unaudited aggregated 52-week period ended March 29, 2020 compared to £184.3 million and £33.7 million for the 52-week period ended March 31, 2019, respectively. The division performed strongly in the period with continued growth in remarketing volumes. Revenue for the fiscal year 2020 was driven by increased fees and including a higher proportion of cross border sales. Strong performance in Denmark and the Netherlands along with volume growth in Germany and France, contributed to an increase in revenue, IAS 17 Adjusted EBITDA and IAS 17 COVID Adjusted EBITDA. Our Danish auction successfully transitioned to a fully online auction program in fiscal year 2020. BCA Norway, which commenced trading in April 2019, generated good volumes focusing on remarketing of electric vehicles, due to the high penetration of electric vehicles in this region. Demand for cross-border sourcing of vehicles in Europe continued to rise period-on-period and is supported by our transport network of accredited partners. From the second week of March 2020, national restrictions for COVID 19 were implemented across Europe, starting with Italy and France, which were amongst the first to implement full lockdown. While all European countries were impacted, those with lighter social distancing measures, for example Denmark, Sweden, Netherlands and Germany, allowed trading at greater scale through March 2020. Vehicle Buying The division generated revenue of £1,529.8 million and IAS 17 Adjusted EBITDA of £27.7 million for the unaudited aggregated 52-week period ended March 29, 2020 compared to £1,219.8 million and £24.1 million for the 52-week period ended March 31, 2019, respectively. WeBuyAnyCar maintained double-digit volume growth with an expanded network of 315 sites providing increased convenience for consumers. During the fiscal year 2020, a record 10,200 vehicles were purchased in a single week by WeBuyAnyCar. The division supplied a controlled and diverse range of vehicles across all makes and marques, to support the UK Vehicle Remarketing division auction sales program. Inventory as of March 29, 2020 was £44.2 million (March 31, 2019: £29.3 million), reflecting the continued growth in the business, offset by the impact of COVID 19 restrictions. In line with government guidelines WeBuyAnyCar closed its retail estate from March 23, 2020, preventing the purchase of vehicles from consumers. The online channels of the UK Vehicle Remarketing division have continued to sell vehicles that were already held by WeBuyAnyCar. At the period end management made additional provisions against inventory given the price uncertainty as a result of the COVID 19 pandemic and associated restrictions. European car buying operations were paused as the impact of COVID 19 became evident, resulting in an operating loss due to costs associated with holding vehicles, and the impact of vehicles sold below purchase price due to temporarily reduced demand. Automotive Services The division generated revenue of £396.6 million and IAS 17 Adjusted EBITDA of £22.6 million for the unaudited aggregated 52-week period ended March 29, 2020 compared to £381.4 million and £19.1 million for the 52-week period ended March 31, 2019, respectively. The division continued to increase the penetration of internal moves and refurbishment completed for UK Vehicle Remarketing and WeBuyAnyCar, driving increased internal efficiency and reducing costs. In the period since the CA Acquisition, the services business performed well with increased demand for manufacturer accredited refurbishment capability.

_Revenue_ Revenue increased by £367.7 million, or 21.9%, from £1,676.3 million for the 210-day period ended October 28, 2018 to £2,044.0 million for the 219-day period ended November 5, 2019. Revenue in the UK Vehicle Remarketing division (excluding inter-division revenue) increased by £155.8 million, or 23.1%, from £675.3 million for the 210-day period ended October 28, 2018 to £831.1 million for the 219-day period ended November 5, 2019. This increase was primarily due to growth in outsourced remarketing contracts and increased supply of vehicles, particularly from the Vehicle Buying division. Revenue in the International Vehicle Remarketing division (excluding inter-division revenue) increased by £21.0 million, or 20.8%, from £101.2 million for the 210-day period ended October 28, 2018 to £122.2 million for the 219-day period ended November 5, 2019. This increase was primarily due to increased sold volumes and an increase in transport and export services. Revenue in the Vehicle Buying division (excluding inter-division revenue) increased by £159.0 million, or 23.1%, from £688.4 million for the 210-day period ended October 28, 2018 to £847.4 million for the 219-day period ended November 5, 2019. This increase was primarily due to increased volume of vehicles purchased and the continuing refinement of the valuation process. Revenue in the Automotive Services division (excluding inter-division revenue) increased by £31.9 million, or 15.1%, from £211.4 million for the 210-day period ended October 28, 2018 to £243.3 million for the 219-day period ended November 5, 2019. This increase was primarily due to the supply of vehicles returning to expected levels, increased opportunities for higher value refurbishment services and the continuing efficiencies resulting from providing integrated services to the wider CA Group. _Cost of Sales_ Cost of sales increased by £336.1 million, or 24.0%, from £1,402.8 million for the 210-day period ended October 28, 2018 to £1,738.9 million for the 219-day period ended November 5, 2019. This increase was primarily due to the increase in activity, as seen in revenue, over the same period. _Operating Costs_ Operating costs increased by £21.7 million, or 10.1%, from £214.7 million for the 210-day period ended October 28, 2018 to £236.4 million for the 219-day period ended November 5, 2019. _Finance Income_ Finance income increased by £0.8 million from £0.3 million for the 210-day period ended October 28, 2018 to £1.1 million for the 219-day period ended November 5, 2019. _Finance Costs_ Finance costs increased by £11.3 million from £5.8 million for the 210-day period ended October 28, 2018 to £17.1 million for the 219-day period ended November 5, 2019. This increase was primarily due to the recognition of IFRS 16 interest costs. ----- _Income Tax Charge_ Income tax charge decreased by £1.8 million, or 14.3%, from a tax charge of £12.6 million and an effective tax rate of 22.7% for the 210-day period ended October 28, 2018 to a tax charge of £10.8 million and an effective tax rate of 20.5% for the 219-day period ended November 5, 2019. The changes are primarily due to a net tax credit in relation to significant or non-recurring items including in relation to amortization of acquired intangible assets. Despite a lower effective tax rate for the 219-day period ended November 5, 2019, the income tax charge increased primarily as a result of an increased profitability. _Reported Adjusted EBITDA_ Reported Adjusted EBITDA increased by £37.1 million, or 37.2%, from £99.6 million for the 210-day period ended October 28, 2018 to £136.7 million for the 219-day period ended November 5, 2019. This increase was primarily due to strong performance across all divisions. _IAS 17 COVID Adjusted EBITDA_ IAS 17 COVID Adjusted EBITDA increased by £37.1 million, or 37.2%, from £99.6 million for the 210-day period ended October 28, 2018 to £136.7 million for the 219-day period ended November 5, 2019. This increase was primarily due to strong performance across all divisions.

Liquidity describes our ability to generate sufficient cash flows to meet the cash requirements of our business operations, including funding working capital and capital expenditure needs, servicing our indebtedness, paying taxes and funding operating activities. Our primary sources of liquidity consist of (i) cash flows from operating activities, (ii) borrowings under loan facilities and finance arrangements that we may incur from time to time, (iii) issuances of debt securities and (iv) borrowings under bank overdrafts borrowings. A variety of factors influence our financial condition and liquidity, including: - a reduction in cash flows from operating activities due to, for instance, volume fluctuations in our business and pricing pressures we face from our competitors; - adverse working capital developments, including increases in non-collectible receivables (to the extent we do not receive recourse through a vehicle held a security) and changes in supplier payment terms; ----- - our inability to continue to borrow funds from financial institutions; and - higher capital expenditures and funding requirements. If our future cash flows from operating activities and other capital resources (including borrowings under the Senior Term Loan Facility, the Revolving Credit Facility and the Second Lien Facility) are insufficient to pay our obligations as they mature or to fund liquidity needs, we may be forced to: - reduce or delay business activities, fixed costs and capital expenditure; - sell assets; - obtain additional debt or equity capital; or - restructure or refinance all or a portion of our debt, including the Notes, on or before maturity. As of March 28, 2021, after giving effect to the Refinancing Transactions, our primary financing arrangements will be the Notes, the Senior Term Loan Facility, the Revolving Credit Facility and the Second Lien Facility, and we would have had £113 million of Adjusted Cash. See “Capitalization.” Although we expect to have sufficient liquidity to meet our anticipated liquidity and debt service needs for the foreseeable future, no assurance can be given that we will generate sufficient cash flows from operating activities or that future debt and equity financing will be available to us in an amount sufficient to enable us to pay our debts when due, including the Notes, or to fund other liquidity needs. No assurance can be given that we would be able to accomplish any of these alternatives on a timely basis or on satisfactory terms, if at all. In addition, the terms of our current or future indebtedness, including the Notes and the Senior Term Loan Facility, the Revolving Credit Facility and the Second Lien Facility, may limit our ability to pursue any of these alternatives. See “Risk Factors—Risks Related to Our Financial Profile, _Our Structure, the Notes and the Guarantees—We are subject to restrictive debt covenants that may limit our ability to finance our future operations and capital needs and to pursue business opportunities and activities.”_

We have significant leverage and debt service obligations. As of March 28, 2021, after giving effect to the Refinancing Transactions, we would have had £1,760 million of Adjusted Total Debt, comprising the Notes, the Senior Term Loan Facility and the Second Lien Facility, excluding finance leases and borrowings under the Receivables Facility. As of March 28, 2021, we also had £40 million drawn under the Existing Revolving Credit Facility. We do not expect to borrow cash under the Revolving Credit Facility on the Issue Date but expect to utilize ancillary facilities and letters of credit under the Revolving Credit Facility for ordinary course operations. In addition, as of March 28, 2021, we had borrowings under the Receivables Facility of £148.3 million. The Indenture governing the Notes, the Senior Facilities Agreement governing the Senior Term Loan Facility and the Revolving Credit Facility and the Second Lien Facility Agreement governing the Second Lien Facility and will contain, covenants significantly restricting our ability to, among others: - incur or guarantee additional indebtedness; - pay dividends or make other distributions or purchase or redeem our stock; - make investments or other restricted payments; - enter into agreements that restrict our restricted subsidiaries’ ability to pay dividends; - transfer or sell assets; - engage in transactions with affiliates; - create liens on assets to secure indebtedness; - impair security interests; and - merge or consolidate with or into another company. Each of the covenants is subject to a number of important exceptions and qualifications. These covenants could limit our ability to finance our future operations and capital needs. The Senior Facilities Agreement also contains a financial covenant requiring us to comply with a senior secured leverage ratio on the last day ----- of each period ending on a quarter. See “Description of the Notes,” “Description of Other Financial _Arrangements—Senior Facilities Agreement”and “Description of Other Financial Arrangements—Second Lien Facility Agreement.”_ We anticipate that our significant leverage will continue for the foreseeable future. Our high level of debt may have important negative consequences for you. For further information, see “Risk Factors—Risks Related to _Our Financial Profile, Our Structure, the Notes and the Guarantees—Our substantial leverage and debt service obligations could adversely affect our business and prevent us from fulfilling our obligations with respect to the Notes and the Guarantees.”_

We experience some seasonality with respect to our working capital. In particular, used vehicle sales in the UK tend to increase during vehicle registration plate change periods in March and September of each year. In ----- March, in particular, new vehicle sales traditionally peak in the UK, and as a result, dealer vendors of the Vehicle Remarketing division typically experience an increase in part-exchange volumes, which has a subsequent effect of increasing sales through the Marketplace. Conversely, our revenue typically decreases during the summer and in December, a seasonality pattern that is followed by sales in both the Vehicle Buying division and the Automotive Services division. As a result of these fluctuations, we experience seasonal swings in our negative working capital and our negative working capital tends to decline in the quarter ending in December and to increase in the quarter ending March. See “— Factors Affecting Our Results of Operations— _Seasonality.”_ The following table presents unlevered free cash flow (pre-tax) for the periods indicated:

Finance lease repayments reflects the cash costs of servicing finance leases related to refinanced trucks and trailers (net of interest), which are refinanced through sale and leaseback transactions. Change in net working capital reflects the movements in our inventory, and volume based building and unwinding of our negative working capital auction cash cycle. At the end of fiscal year 2021, we increased our vehicle buying activities in anticipation of increased demand from our customers corresponding with the lifting of COVID 19 restrictions. In addition, we experienced positive working capital as a result of holding and preparing inventory for our “Retail Ready” sales channel, which involves cosmetically and mechanically repairing vehicles ahead of sale. At the end of fiscal year 2020, we reduced our vehicle buying activities as a result of COVID 19 and the related initial lockdown that followed the outbreak of the COVID 19 pandemic and at the same time, we sought to liquidate our existing vehicles. At the end of fiscal year 2019, we experienced a decrease in volume and in negative working capital as a result of physical auction closures over the Easter holiday period. Change in net working capital (BCA Partner Finance) represents movements in the amounts we self-fund under our buyer finance services, BCA Partner Finance. Rent cash adjustment represents the difference between contractual rent payment obligations and the accounting treatment with respect to such rent payments.

Subsection Title: Quantitative and Qualitative Disclosure About Market Risk
Subsubsection Text: Market risk is the risk that changes in market prices (principally exchange rates and interest rates) will affect our income or the value of our holdings of financial instruments.

Subsection Title: Quantitative and Qualitative Disclosure About Market Risk
Subsubsection Text: We operate in the UK and continental Europe (Belgium, France, Germany, Italy, Netherlands, Portugal, Spain, Denmark, Norway, Poland, Sweden, and Switzerland) and are therefore exposed to foreign exchange risk. Foreign exchange risk arises primarily on recognized assets and liabilities and net investments in foreign operations. These overseas operations’ revenues and costs are mainly denominated in the currencies of the countries in which our operations are located. The most significant of these is the euro. We do not have significant transactional foreign currency cash flow exposures. We monitor our exposure to currency fluctuations on an ongoing basis. We maintain part of our debt in euro to reflect the currency in which our revenue is generated. We have not hedged profit translation exposures. In the 52-week period ended March 28, 2021, we did not have any hedges in place. In the 52-week period ended March 28, 2021, if pound sterling had strengthened by 10% on average against the euro with all other variables held constant, Reported Adjusted EBITDA for the year would have been £3.8 million lower (2020: £1.3 million lower) as a result of a reduction of the equivalent value in pound sterling of profits denominated in euro.

Subsection Title: Quantitative and Qualitative Disclosure About Market Risk
Subsubsection Text: Our interest rate risk arises from our borrowings. Interest rates have been historically low and stable in terms of both LIBOR and EURIBOR rates and consequently no structured hedging has been implemented in the current period. We will continue to monitor interest rates and assess the requirement for hedging in the future. All of our finance leases are at fixed rates of interest. In the 52-week period ended March 28, 2021, if the average rate on floating rate borrowings had been 50 basis points higher with all other variables held constant, post-tax profit for the period would have been £5.7 million lower (2020: £6.6 million lower).

Subsection Title: Quantitative and Qualitative Disclosure About Market Risk
Subsubsection Text: Credit risk is the risk of financial loss if a customer or counterparty to a financial instrument fails to meet its contractual obligations and arises principally through trade receivables from customers and cash balances. -----

Subsection Title: Quantitative and Qualitative Disclosure About Market Risk
Subsubsection Text: Liquidity risk is the risk that we will not be able to meet our financial obligations as they fall due. We monitor forecasts of our liquidity requirements to ensure we have sufficient cash to meet operational needs while maintaining sufficient headroom on our undrawn committed borrowing facilities at all times so that we minimize the risk of breaching borrowing limits or covenants on any of our borrowing facilities. Such forecasting takes into consideration our debt financing plan and covenant compliance requirements on our borrowings. As of the date of this Offering Memorandum, we meet all liabilities from intercompany loans. Our liability for operating expenses is monitored on an ongoing basis to ensure cash resources are adequate to meet liabilities as they fall due.

Subsection Title: Quantitative and Qualitative Disclosure About Market Risk
Subsubsection Text: Our activities expose us to a variety of financial risks: market risk (including foreign exchange and interest rate risk), credit risk and liquidity risk. The responsibility for monitoring the effectiveness of risk management is carried out by the board of the Parent.

_Taxation_ Accruals for current tax and amounts payable under local indirect taxes such as sales taxes and VAT are based on management’s interpretation of country specific tax law, and require judgements about the likelihood that tax positions taken will be sustained. Management estimates the amount of taxes payable based upon their analysis and determines whether provision should be made for potential settlement of disputed positions which are under negotiation. Any estimated exposure to interest on tax liabilities is provided for in the related tax amount. _Deferred Tax_ Deferred tax assets and liabilities represent management’s best estimate in determining the amounts to be recognized. When assessing the extent to which deferred tax assets should be recognized, consideration is given to the timing and level of future taxable income.

Loss allowances for trade receivables due from customers under BCA Partner Finance arrangements are recognized under the expected credit loss model on initial recognition of the receivable. Management are required to develop estimates of credit risk using the best available information about past events, current conditions and forecasts of economic conditions. BCA Partner Finance receivables are asset backed, providing a level of protection based on the value and recovery of the asset. Management apply judgement in assessing whether there is a significant change in credit risk which would impact the expected credit loss allowance recognized.

Management use a lease specific incremental borrowing rate to discount the future lease liabilities, where the interest rate implicit in the lease is not readily available. Using an incremental borrowing rate requires management to estimate the rate of interest that would be paid to borrow over a similar term, and with similar security, the funds necessary to obtain an asset of a similar value to the right of use asset in a similar economic environment.

For all acquisitions in the period, management are required to apply judgement to determine the business combination accounting, and in relation to the identification of separable assets and liabilities arising on acquisition. Management make estimates of future cash flows to value the assets and make estimates in determining the useful economic life of intangible assets. -----

An impairment review has been conducted on all goodwill and intangible assets held by the CA Group. The impairment review is performed on a value in use basis, which requires estimation of future net operating cash flows, the time period over which they will occur, an appropriate discount rate and an appropriate growth rate. Specifically, the future cash flows are sensitive to the assumptions made about the revenue growth, profitability margin(s) and the long-term growth rate of the relevant market. Given the degree of subjectivity involved, actual outcomes could vary significantly from these estimates.

The CA Group’s net retirement benefit obligation, which is reviewed by management using assessments from independent actuaries each period, is based on key assumptions, including discount rates, inflation, future salary increases and pension costs. These assumptions may be different to the actual outcome. -----

The preparation of our consolidated financial statements under IFRS requires us to make estimates, judgements and assumptions that affect the reported amounts of assets and liabilities and the disclosure of contingent assets and liabilities. Estimates and judgements are evaluated continually and are based on historical experience and other factors including expectations of future events that are believed to be reasonable under the circumstances. Actual results may differ from these estimates, with any changes arising being recognized in the period in which the change in estimate is made or the final result determined.

Accordingly, all references to “we,” “our,” and “us” are to the Parent and its consolidated subsidiaries from time to time when used for periods after the CA Acquisition and to BCA Marketplace and its consolidated subsidiaries from time to time when used for periods prior to the CA Acquisition. See also “Presentation of Financial and Other Information.” You should read this discussion in conjunction with the Consolidated Financial Statements and the 2020 Predecessor Financial Statements included elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum, as well as “Selected Historical Consolidated Financial Information.” The following presentation and analysis contains forward- looking statements that involve risks and uncertainties. For the reasons explained under “Forward-looking Statements” and “Risk Factors” and elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum, our future results may differ materially from those expected or implied in these forward-looking statements. Some of the measures used in this discussion and analysis are not measurements of financial performance under IFRS and have important limitations as analytical tools. Such measures may not accurately reflect our performance, liquidity or our ability to incur debt, have limitations as analytical tools, and should not be considered as alternatives to operating profit or profit after taxation for the period or any other performance measures derived from or in accordance with IFRS, SEC requirements or any other generally accepted accounting principles or as alternatives to cash flow from operating activities. See “Presentation of Financial and Other Information.” PricewaterhouseCoopers LLP do not express an opinion or any other form of assurance with respect to these non-IFRS measures. The auditor reports included in this Offering Memorandum relate to the previously issued financial statements of the Parent and BCA Marketplace._

Subsubsection Title: UK and Continental European Vehicle Parc
Subsubsection Text: We operate in the UK and continental Europe used vehicle market. The number of vehicles in operation (the “vehicle parc”) across the UK and continental Europe has grown consistently since 2012, driven by a relatively stable vehicle parc churn and growing vehicle penetration rates. Vehicle penetration rates, defined as number of vehicles in circulation per capita in a country, are expected to continue to grow for most markets. The European light vehicle parc grew at a CAGR of approximately 1.7% between 2012 and 2019, and currently stands at approximately 320 million units (for the year 2020). According to IHS, the European light vehicle parc is expected to grow at a CAGR of approximately 0.8% between 2021 and 2026, driven by growth in the penetration of vehicles per population, with new additions to the vehicle parc in particular of battery electric vehicles and plug-in hybrid vehicles. Since the onset of the COVID 19 pandemic, the importance of vehicle ownership for consumers has been strengthened (see “—Key Trends”.) The below chart shows the evolution of the European light vehicle parc between 2012 and 2020, and projections between 2021 and 2026: _Source: IHS database[(1)]._ (1) “Other Europe” represents Sweden, Switzerland, Denmark, Austria, Belgium, Greece, Romania, Ireland, Bulgaria, Finland, Hungary, Czech Republic, Portugal, Latvia, Lithuania, Croatia and Estonia. Sales of new cars eventually translate into used car transactions through used car churn. Used car churn, which is used as a measure of annual turnover in the ownership of cars in operation, varies by geography. In the UK market, for the fiscal year 2019, used car churn stood at approximately 23%, compared to approximately 13% in the continental European market, in line with customary trends. As a result, used car transaction volumes as a proportion of the total vehicle parc are higher in the UK than in continental Europe. We believe that the growing popularity of PCP (Personal Contract Purchase) plans among new car sales has contributed to an increased visibility and rates of churn in the UK. An increasing amount of cars coming off PCP plans offers a stream of supply for the used car market, many of which are transacted via exchanges such as Constellation’s B2B Marketplace. In addition, used car churn across the UK and continental Europe is impacted by a number of key factors. These include: - Maturing leases and other finance agreements; - Changing consumer preferences; ----- - Necessary cost of repairs as vehicles age, as well as warranty expirations; - Tax and regulatory changes such as low emission restrictions and fees related thereto; - Dealer and OEM finance offers and promotions; - Rental and car sharing fleets, which typically churn vehicles at a faster rate than vehicles in private ownership, according to IHS; - Insurance cost, safety, recalls, reliability and technological improvements Used vehicle churn is a key factor of our business model. Given the graduated auction fee structure is relatively insensitive to vehicle price, the business model is more dependent on the volume of vehicles going through the marketplace than the overall value of the vehicles.

Subsubsection Title: UK and Continental European Used Car Market
Subsubsection Text: The continental European used car market was estimated by Roland Berger to be valued at €410 billion for the year 2020. The total volume of used car sales in Europe amounted to approximately 45 million cars during the same period, of which approximately 84% were derived from continental Europe and the remainder from the UK, according to IHS. Moreover, annual sale volume movements in the used car market have been proportionally lower than in the new car market, as the used car market is far less sensitive to economic downturns than the new car market, due in part to the greater size of the used car market and the fact that certain periods of economic stress can be a driver of used car transactions, such as de-fleeting of underutilized car rental fleets or consumers trading down cars. For example, new car sales in the UK were more volatile between 2008 and 2020 than used car sales, with a peak-to-trough maximum variance of approximately 39% compared to approximately 13% for used car sales during the same period. _Source: IHS._

Subsubsection Title: Impact of the COVID 19 Pandemic on the Used Car Market
Subsubsection Text: From the end of the first quarter of 2020, the UK and continental European used car markets were impacted by the temporary closure of bricks and mortar dealerships as a result of lockdown measures and forced temporary business closures resulting from the COVID 19 pandemic. Following the introduction of these lockdown measures, the used car markets in the UK, France, Germany and Italy recorded a significant decline through March and April 2020. However, volumes began to recover strongly from early June 2020, as lockdown restrictions gradually started to ease in these regions. The German market suffered from another sharp downturn as a result of the renewed lockdown imposed in December 2020, but the latest data from Indicata indicates that volumes have recovered close to pre-COVID levels. In France, despite a recovery from a trough in April 2020, French used car sale volumes have remained below pre-COVID 19 levels. The latest trading data from Indicata indicates that used car volumes in Italy and the Netherlands have recovered to pre-COVID levels. In our largest market, the UK, used car sales suffered a year-on-year decline of approximately 11% in the fiscal year 2020, to approximately 7.4 million in 2020 from approximately 8.3 million in 2019, according to IHS, driven by mandatory retail closures during periods of lockdown. Despite the ongoing global pandemic, the UK recorded periods of strong recovery when such restrictions were subsequently lifted and retailers ----- reopened, driving monthly used car transaction volumes from July to October 2020 above those for the same period in 2019 and demonstrating the continued strong demand for used cars by end consumers. The continued strength of demand for used cars throughout this period is also evidenced by the fact that average transaction prices remained above pre-pandemic levels from July to October 2020, during which retailers were open. The impact on the used car market of the varying forms of lockdown from November 2020 to April 2021 was less severe than the initial lockdown from March 2020 to June 2020, primarily due to the increased use by dealers of click-and-collect channels, which they were able to develop and improve during the periods of mandatory closures from March 2020. Following the easing of COVID 19-related restrictions and the reopening of retailers on April 12, 2021 in the UK, used car transactions have bounced back strongly, as evidenced by the chart below: _Source: Indicata Market Watch (Edition 16, May 2021), SMMT._ The used car market, especially in the UK, is expected to remain strong in the near-term, supported by renewed appetite for individual vehicle ownership (Source: Roland Berger). Moreover, an increased amount of household savings accumulated through the COVID 19 pandemic bolsters the consumption outlook (Source: _HSBC)._ Vehicle parc growth rates in key markets across Europe are expected to grow at CAGR ranging from 0.5% to 1.8% between 2021 and 2026 (Source: IHS).

Our UK Vehicle Remarketing and International Vehicle Remarketing divisions, which trade under the BCA brand name, as well as WeBuyAnyCar, our C2B Marketplace business line which represents our Vehicle Buying division’s operations in the UK, constitute significant parts of the value chain within which we are active, as illustrated by the below chart: _Source: Management Information._ Market participants include: - Vendors, who are looking to dispose of vehicles, and are divided into the below groups: - Corporate fleet, including finance and leasing companies (looking to dispose over-age or overmileage vehicles, repossessed vehicles, off-lease vehicles, including vehicles after PCP plans); ----- - Dealers and car supermarkets (looking to move unwanted part-exchange stock or liquidate aged inventory); - OEMs (looking to dispose vehicles after corporate fleet or other ownership); and - C2B marketplaces or vehicle buying platforms (consumer-facing companies that seek to liquidate stock purchased directly from consumers). - Marketplaces and exchanges, which comprise of firms looking to enable vendors to sell used vehicles to a variety of buyers, as well as to provide a logistics solution from sellers to buyers; - Classifieds, which comprise of online automotive classified websites that generate leads for traditional dealers, car supermarkets and consumers looking to dispose of used vehicles, and provide purely advertising and lead-generation services without end-to-end transaction capabilities; - Trade Buyers, who comprise of mainly professional players, including traditional dealers, car supermarkets and online B2C players; and - Consumers, who comprise of private individuals looking to buy or dispose of vehicles, and who may also trade vehicles amongst themselves (C2C transactions), in addition to the other channels described above. Marketplaces and exchanges are at the center of the used car value chain, offering transparency, speed, certainty and liquidity for both vendors and buyers. They form a key part of the fleet management infrastructure for vendors by outsourcing non-core competencies and helping to extract maximum value quickly, as well as representing a significant channel for buyers, driven by their ability to offer on-market pricing and maximum choice of vehicles on used vehicle marketplaces. A significant fragmentation of buyers and vendors across the UK and continental European markets enhances the prominence of used car marketplaces as a critical channel for transactions. By way of illustration, the largest used car dealership in the UK has a market share of approximately 3%, while the largest European used car dealership has a market share inferior to 1%. Leading marketplaces could be seen to benefit from self-reinforcing dynamics whereby as they grow in both scale and geographic breadth, their attractiveness to both buyers and vendors increases, which in turn reinforces their leadership position. By adding ancillary services such as logistics, vehicle refurbishment and buyer financing, among others, an automotive marketplace can also strengthen the attractiveness of its services to its customers and thereby increase customer stickiness, while also growing the level of profit achieved per vehicle transacted through its platform. A key success factor for a leading automotive marketplace is also having a reliable and diverse source of vehicles flowing through its platform. Our Marketplace is a key participant in the used car market value chain throughout both the UK and continental Europe. Notably, in the UK, we came into contact with approximately 13 million unique vehicles in the fiscal year 2020, representing approximately one in three of all registered cars in the UK. WeBuyAnyCar, our Vehicle Buying division’s operations in the UK, is a leading online C2B used vehicle buying company, with more than 2.2 million cars bought since its inception and 461,000 vehicles purchased and sold annually, on an annualized run-rated basis based on March, April and May 2021. WeBuyAnyCar provides UK Vehicle Remarketing with used vehicles that would otherwise go to C2C markets or partexchanges. Once acquired on the WeBuyAnyCar platform, the purchased vehicles are sold through the auctions conducted by UK Vehicle Remarketing, with an acquisition to sale cycle of approximately 10 days, on average (fiscal year 2020, which is representative of our ordinary course business operations in a steady state). WeBuyAnyCar provided approximately 35% of the UK Vehicle Remarketing sale volumes in the fiscal year 2021. Our integrated suite of services, both transactional (such as auctioning and vehicle buying) and transactionenabling (such as refurbishment, transport, valuation and other services) places us at the center of the automotive value chain.

Subsubsection Title: Increased consumer perception of the importance of car ownership
Subsubsection Text: Partly as a result of the COVID 19 pandemic, consumers now place an increased emphasis on the importance of car ownership. This has been driven by a variety of different reasons, including a demographic move away from urban areas due to the ability to work from home and a decline in the use of public transport and shared ----- mobility (Source: BCG report). According to the OC&C survey (2021), the number of non-drivers who definitely expect to own a car in the future has risen by 21% in the UK since 2019, and 40% of drivers in the UK and Italy also stated that the COVID 19 pandemic has increased the importance they place on car ownership. This is also true of younger drivers, with the proportion of drivers aged 18 to 29 against car ownership falling from 11% to 5% during the same period.

Subsubsection Title: Digitalization of the used car value chain
Subsubsection Text: The used car value chain has long been reliant on physical transactions via bricks and mortar institutions, and has also had a very low digital penetration relative to other industries. However, the change towards an online business model has been accelerated, in particular as a result of and in response to the COVID 19 pandemic, which forced businesses and consumers to resort to online channels while traditional retailers were closed. This trend towards an increased digitalization has impacted both the B2B and B2C channels: _B2B Channels_ The changes in operating environment spurred by the COVID 19 pandemic have led us to accelerate our shift towards a fully digital online business model with increased focus on the functionality and usability of our digital platforms, with a 100% online penetration in UK Vehicle Remarketing and an online penetration in excess of 90% in International Vehicle Remarketing, in each case in the fiscal year 2021. Increasing online penetration of auctions presents a unique opportunity to increase the cost efficiency of used car marketplaces and facilitates a more flexible utilization of real estate. In addition, digitalization also increases businesses’ resilience in the event of further lockdowns as a result of the COVID 19 pandemic or other adverse economic conditions by continuing to trade largely online. Lastly, the digitalization of the used car value chain also bolsters operators’ data collection and analytics capabilities thanks to the higher number of transactions concluded online. This trend is likely to disproportionately benefit large players, such as ourselves, for two reasons. Firstly, because of their broader geographical presence, as digital auctions increase the scope to pair buyers and sellers that are located far away from one another, and such pairing requires significant logistical capabilities. Secondly, because of their overall scale and data infrastructure, since small players are less likely to have the digital expertise and scale to support the costs of digital investments. _B2C Channels_ Trends resulting from the COVID 19 pandemic have also accelerated consumers’ willingness to accept digital purchasing as a means to buy a car, which has historically been at very low levels according to Roland Berger. This trend has facilitated the growth of online B2C retailers, such as cinch, with an increase in transparency and convenience for consumers buying used cars, thereby potentially helping increase used car churn over time, as well as an increase in the demand for the sourcing of high quality used cars from vehicle exchanges such as ours, and in turn the demand for high quality used cars from vehicle buying platforms.

Subsubsection Title: Continued structural growth opportunity for digital vehicle purchasing platforms
Subsubsection Text: There is significant potential for vehicle buying platforms to continue to increase their penetration of the large, fragmented and sometimes inefficient C2C and part-exchange segments of the used car market. As the growth of platforms such as WeBuyAnyCar in the UK and other C2B sourcing businesses in parts of continental Europe have shown, such vehicle buying platforms offer a convenient, transparent and efficient way for consumers to sell their cars. With consumers becoming increasingly comfortable using online channels for car transactions (Source: Roland Berger) and with such vehicle buying services still typically operating at low levels of overall market penetration, we believe that leading vehicle buying platforms can continue to exhibit structural growth.

Subsubsection Title: Technological and regulatory changes driving faster vehicle churn
Subsubsection Text: The pace of both technological and regulatory changes in the European automotive market has substantially increased in recent years. A confluence of technological changes, such as more cost efficient batteries and advancement of automotive sensors, and regulatory measures, such as EU-wide fleet emission legislation to reduce light vehicle CO2 emissions has resulted in the rapid advancement of light vehicle technology on offer to consumers. In addition, other car technologies, such as autonomous driving features and advanced car connectivity, are rapidly evolving. To seek up-to-date technology and adapt to changing regulation, consumers therefore have an increasing number of reasons to change their choice of vehicle on a more regular basis. -----

Our key competitors vary between our business lines: - B2B Marketplace: key competitors include other exchanges, such as Manheim and Aston Barclay in the UK and Auto1 in continental Europe, as well as numerous smaller players. - C2B Marketplace: key competitors include other car buying platforms competing with WeBuyAnyCar such as WeWantAnyCar. -----

We operate leading digital used vehicle marketplaces (both business to business (“B2B”) and consumer to business (“C2B”)) in the UK and B2B marketplaces in continental Europe and are a leading provider of associated automotive services, including vehicle movement, logistics, storage, pre-delivery inspections, fleet management, de-fleeting services and refurbishment in the UK. We have physical presence in 10 countries across the UK and continental Europe as well as unmatched sourcing, data, technology and logistics capabilities. As of March 28, 2021, our business comprises: - a leading B2B digital used vehicle marketplace across the UK and continental Europe, which facilitated the sale of approximately 1.5 million vehicles in the fiscal year 2020 and 1.2 million vehicles in the fiscal year 2021; - a leading C2B digital used vehicle marketplace in the UK, WeBuyAnyCar, with sold volumes of 321,000 vehicles and 300,000 vehicles in the fiscal years 2020 and 2021, respectively, reflecting the COVID 19 restrictions on the business that now has an annualized run rate of 461,000 vehicles (based on trading in March, April and May 2021, which was the most recent three-month period); and - a leading automotive logistics service business in the UK, which moved more than 2.8 million vehicles in the UK in the fiscal year 2020 and 2.4 million vehicles in the fiscal year 2021, and stored, refurbished and processed more than 950,000 vehicles in the fiscal year 2020 and 675,000 in the fiscal year 2021. We estimate that for the fiscal year 2020 we came in contact with approximately one in every three vehicles in the UK (approximately 29 million touch points, of which approximately 13 million were unique vehicles out of a vehicle parc of approximately 41 million, and including approximately 24 million digital touch points). Through our digital used vehicle marketplaces (the “Marketplace”), we are a critical liquidity provider to the used vehicles market across the UK and continental Europe, matching the complex requirements of both vendors and buyers and also facilitating the purchase of individual vehicles from consumers. The Marketplace facilitates speedy disposal of high volumes of vehicles and offers a broad range of consistently graded vehicle stock, thereby providing efficiency, liquidity (i.e., fast disposal of vehicle stock) and choice. Moreover, we are the UK’s leading provider of automotive services solutions. By providing a full suite of auction and automotive services, we offer our customers solutions for almost all stages of the vehicle life-cycle, beginning as soon as the new car arrives at the port. Our scope of services provides synergistic benefits across our divisions, as our vehicle sales platforms, together with our automotive services solutions, generate vehicle and pricing data used in both our vehicle remarketing and vehicle buying operations. Throughout the COVID 19 pandemic, we have accelerated our digital transition and now transact digitally almost 100% of our volumes through online channels. We integrate our digital and physical assets to provide innovative multi-service solutions, maximizing speed, intelligence and performance across our comprehensive offerings. In the fiscal year 2021, 100% (2020: 37%) of our auction volumes in the UK Vehicle Remarketing division and 96% (2020: 84%) of our auction volumes in the International Vehicle Remarketing division were transacted online, which is a testament to our successful shift towards a predominantly digital online business model moving forward. In the 53-week period ended May 30, 2021, we generated £253.1 million of IAS 17 COVID Adjusted EBITDA, as compared to £232.8 million, £204.1 million and £174.4 million in the 52-week period ended March 28, 2021, the aggregated 52-week period ended March 29, 2020 and the 52-week period ended March 31, 2019, respectively. We operate through three main business lines: (i) the B2B Marketplace business line, which is comprised of our UK Vehicle Remarketing division, our International Vehicle Remarketing division and our Vehicle Buying division’s operations in continental Europe, (ii) the C2B Marketplace business line, which is WeBuyAnyCar, our Vehicle Buying division’s operations in the UK, and (iii) the Automotive Services business line, which is accounted for in our Automotive Services division. - B2B Marketplace: B2B Marketplace is our core business that facilitates the exchange of used vehicles between vendors and buyers through primarily digital auctions. As of March 28, 2021, our digital auctions are supported by 21 physical sites in the UK (23 as of June 1, 2021) and 30 physical sites in continental Europe at which vehicles are stored, inspected, repaired and refurbished. ----- B2B Marketplace (which excludes WeBuyAnyCar) does not take title to the majority of vehicles that it sells, but instead serves as an agent between vendor and buyer and recognizes revenues through auction transaction fees as well as fees for a suite of value-added digital and physical pre- and post- auction services such as inspections, appraisals, repairs, refurbishment, imaging, storage and handling. We also purchase vehicles directly from certain corporate vendors under outsourced remarketing contracts, whereby we directly buy our vendors’ inventory and have discretion over the remarketing channel through which we sell the vehicle. B2B Marketplace takes title to such vehicles until the time of resale and recognizes revenues for the full sale value of the vehicle less the cost of acquisition. Vehicles acquired pursuant to outsourced remarketing contracts are typically resold within 15 to 30 days of acquisition and in turn generate additional revenue above the auction fees. B2B Marketplace also includes our Vehicle Buying division’s operations in continental Europe, which is focused on purchasing batches of vehicles primarily from corporates in continental Europe. In the 52-week period ended March 28, 2021, our UK Vehicle Remarketing division generated £90.5 million of IAS 17 Adjusted EBITDA (aggregated 52-week period ended March 29, 2020: £116.3 million; 52-week period ended March 31, 2019: £109.4 million). In the fiscal year 2021, our UK Vehicle Remarketing division sold approximately 867,000 vehicles (2020: 1,063,000 vehicles; 2019: 1,030,0000 vehicles). In the 52-week period ended March 28, 2021, our International Vehicle Remarketing division generated £29.2 million of IAS 17 Adjusted EBITDA (aggregated 52-week period ended March 29, 2020: £34.2 million; 52-week period ended March 31, 2019: £33.7 million). In the fiscal year 2021, our International Vehicle Remarketing division sold approximately 334,000 vehicles (2020: 401,000 vehicles; 2019: 388,000 vehicles). - C2B Marketplace: C2B Marketplace is our C2B vehicle buying business which operates in the UK through WeBuyAnyCar. WeBuyAnyCar purchases used vehicles directly from consumers, leveraging its proprietary online pricing quotation systems and efficient physical inspection processes to facilitate purchases from such consumers. WeBuyAnyCar has carried out a total of 2.2 million vehicle purchases since its inception in 2006, and in the fiscal year ended March 28, 2021, WeBuyAnyCar recorded more than 22 million unique visitors to its website and performed approximately 15.6 million valuations online. As of March 28, 2021, WeBuyAnyCar operates in 357 locations across the UK, which are located within an average drive time of under 14 minutes to customers. In addition, WeBuyAnyCar offers swift services to its consumers, allowing them to obtain a quote in under 60 seconds and to then subsequently receive monies for the purchase of their vehicle within 30 minutes of the sale being concluded. C2B Marketplace remarkets the vehicles it purchases exclusively through B2B Marketplace within approximately 10 days and accounted for 35% of the vehicles sold in the UK Vehicle Remarketing division in the 52-week period ended March 28, 2021. This allows us to actively manage the volumes and mix on the Marketplace, while helping to de-risk the supply of vehicles to the auction. C2B Marketplace’s consistent and growing profitability over the past years demonstrates our ability to generate “metal margin” (accounted for in our Vehicle Buying division) on C2B vehicles in addition to core auction buyer fees (accounted for in our UK Vehicle Remarketing division). Vehicles sourced via our C2B Marketplace therefore result in higher profitability per vehicle for the CA Group. Our sophisticated and proprietary pricing mechanism and real-time market data enable us to more accurately price the purchase of vehicles to generate a profitable onward sale. In the 52-week period ended March 28, 2021, the Vehicle Buying division generated £44.0 million of IAS 17 Adjusted EBITDA (aggregated 52-week period ended March 29, 2020: £27.7 million; 52-week period ended March 31, 2019: £24.1 million), which was predominantly generated through C2B Marketplace (i.e., WeBuyAnyCar). - Automotive Services: Automotive Services provides vehicle movement, logistics, storage, pre-delivery inspections, fleet management, de-fleeting services and refurbishment in the UK. With our refurbishment offering (which has a 250,000 yearly vehicle refurbishment capacity), we are able to bring vehicles to either wholesale standard or a “Retail Ready” standard (which refers to vehicles that are cosmetically and mechanically prepared to be immediately placed for sale to end consumers and are therefore particularly attractive to online car dealers). These standards increase prices achieved at auction and render it simpler for dealers to on-sell the vehicle to consumers. We seek to develop a relationship with vendors and endeavor to act as a one-stop shop for vehicles throughout the majority of their lifecycle, expanding our revenue streams along the value chain and also positioning ourselves to be the preferred provider of remarketing services when the vehicles come off lease or roll out of the fleet. Our overall infrastructure and logistics network allow us to efficiently cover all key locations and major transport hubs in the UK. Automotive Services helps maximize the benefit of operational leverage and intragroup efficiencies derived from the wide-ranging scope of services offered, benefitting both our customers as well as our own operations. ----- Automotive Services generates revenue in the form of service fees. In the 52-week period ended March 28, 2021, Automotive Services generated £12.5 million of IAS 17 Adjusted EBITDA (aggregated 52-week period ended March 29, 2020: £22.6 million; 52-week period ended March 31, 2019: £19.1 million).

We have a history dating back to our first auction in 1946. Since then, we have undergone a number of changes in ownership and also shifted our strategic focus in an effort to adapt to changes in the post-factory automotive market. We have gradually expanded our operations through a mix of organic developments and selective, value-enhancing strategic acquisitions, including WeBuyAnyCar (2013), Ambrosetti (2016) and Supreme Wheels (2017). In 2019, we were acquired by TDR Capital, who believed in our potential to become a truly pan-European leader in the used vehicle auction market and saw an opportunity to drive efficiencies by digitalization of the used vehicle market, thereby strengthening the cash generative nature of our business and building a platform for growth across our marketplaces. Under TDR Capital’s ownership, we continue to focus on growing the breadth and scale of our services offering to build a more complete and integrated automotive services solution across the life-cycle of the vehicle.

We are a leading operator of digital used vehicle auctions in the UK and continental Europe and associated automotive services across the UK. From continental Europe, we serve over 40 countries, leveraging our ability to engage in cross-border activity across continental Europe. We believe our leading market positioning and scale enable us to better serve used car buyers and sellers compared to many of our competitors as we are able to price, source, inspect, refurbish, transport, service, market, arrange auctions and provide digital and physical services and solutions in an efficient, comprehensive and effective way. We believe our B2B Marketplace is the largest used vehicle auction operator across the UK and continental Europe combined, with approximately £10 billion in gross merchandise value in connection with sales for the fiscal year 2020. We believe that B2B Marketplace is the clear leader in the UK, having sold approximately 1.1 million vehicles in the UK in the aggregated 52-week period ended March 29, 2020, as well as approximately 400,000 vehicles sold in continental Europe in the same period. These attributes mean that we can continuously meet the requirements of both professional vendors and buyers, including improved value, liquidity, efficiency and choice, and are a key part of the reason that more than 25,000 active buyers used the exchange in the fiscal year 2021. Through our UK Vehicle Remarketing division, our Automotive Services offering in the UK and our brand WeBuyAnyCar, we come into contact with approximately one third of all vehicles exchanged in the UK each year. We believe that C2B Marketplace, through our brand WeBuyAnyCar, is the leading vehicle buying service in the UK, purchasing and selling over 321,000 vehicles in the fiscal year 2020. On an annualized basis based on trading in March, April and May 2021, which was the most recent three-month period, we purchased and sold approximately 461,000 vehicles through WeBuyAnyCar. With greater than 22 million unique visitors to its website in the fiscal year ended March 28, 2021 and having performed approximately 15.6 million valuations online and purchasing vehicles at 357 physical sites, each as of and for the 52-week period ended March 28, 2021, we believe that C2B Marketplace is significantly larger and has a significantly greater presence than any other vehicle buying service in the UK. C2B Marketplace’s leadership position is continuing to strengthen with an increase in the number of repeat customers in recent years, demonstrating consumers’ trust in the brand and satisfaction around the value attached to the vehicle disposal process. As of the date of this Offering Memorandum, WeBuyAnyCar has over 100,000 Trust Pilot reviews with an average 4.6 rating. In Automotive Services, we operate one of the largest automotive vehicle movement, logistics, storage, predelivery inspections, fleet management, de-fleeting services and refurbishment capability in the UK. As of March 28, 2021, we own the largest transporter fleet in the UK, comprising 901 trucks capable of providing bulk vehicle movements, thereby connecting the physical marketplace and increasing the integration between our divisions. We also offer the full range of single vehicle movement services to support customers through the process of vehicle delivery, handover and collection. In the fiscal year 2021, we moved 2.4 million vehicles (2020: 2.8 million), including 563,000 single vehicle movements, and our in-house and sub-contracted transporter fleet completed 94% of transport arranged for customers by the UK Vehicle Remarketing division. ----- We offer the full range of single vehicle movement services to support customers through the process of vehicle delivery, handover and collection. We also operate one of the UK’s largest inspect and collect businesses with over 400,000 vehicle inspections made in the fiscal year 2021, are one of the UK’s leading new vehicle storage handling and preparation businesses and are among the UK’s leading de-fleet, refurbishment and alloy wheel businesses with more than 675,000 vehicles stored, refurbished and processed in the fiscal year 2021.

Subsubsection Title: Superior Business Model Addressing the Full Value Chain and Difficult to Replicate
Subsubsection Text: We operate under a marketplace model and benefit from self-reinforcing dynamics where each of our business lines feeds into and reinforces the others. Our business model enables us to extract intragroup efficiencies and synergies derived from operating across almost all stages of the vehicle life-cycle, at high volumes sufficient to provide a level of information, liquidity and market recognition that drives further volume growth. Our B2B Marketplace operates vehicle auctions that bring together vendors with a highly fragmented and diverse buyer base. Our large, robust and transparent digital platforms combined with our full suite of preand post-auction digital and physical value-added services provide an efficient marketplace to facilitate the exchange of used vehicles. B2B Marketplace sold approximately 1.5 million vehicles across the UK and continental Europe in the fiscal year 2020. This significant scale creates a virtuous business cycle by providing access to a wide variety and large volume of vehicles through our auctions, thereby attracting more buyers to our platform and enabling optimum pricing and quick throughput, which in turn attracts more sellers and provides more volumes. Moreover, we obtain valuable insights for our pricing engines based on the information we have available about a vehicle and its condition, color, auction sale price and bid levels.
